headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Texas Instruments 4Q 2014 and 2014 Year-end Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Texas Instruments 4Q 2014 and 2014 Year-end Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter and year-end 2014 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and rele
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter and year-end 2014 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.
For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant and non-GAAP reconciliations on our web at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through TI's website. A replay will be available through the web.
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the Safe Harbor statement contained in the earnings release published today as well as TI's most recent SEC filings for a more complete description.
Before I review the quarter, let me provide some information that's important to your calendar. We plan to hold a call on February 4 at 10:00 a.m. Central time to update our capital management strategy. Similar to what we've done in the -- for the last 2 years on this topic, Kevin March will provide insight into our strategy and also answer some of the most frequently asked questions.
Turning to our earnings update. The fourth quarter marked another quarter of strong progress. Our core businesses of Analog and Embedded Processing grew again with combined revenue up 13% from a year ago. Revenue of $3.27 billion came in at the middle of the expected range that we communicated to you in October. Earnings per share were $0.76 and included a $0.05 benefit for the reinstatement of the federal research tax credit and a $0.02 benefit from gains on sales of assets. Without these 2 items, our earnings would have been in the middle of our expected range.
In the fourth quarter, our cash flow from operations was $1.3 billion. We believe that free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term. Free cash flow for the year was $3.5 billion, up 18% from a year ago. Free cash flow with 27% of revenue, consistent with our targeted range of 20% to 30%. This is a 3 percentage point increase improvement from a year ago period. We believe this reflects our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy, which includes our growing 300-millimeter output and the opportunistic purchase of assets ahead of demand. We also believe that free cash flow will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business.
In 2014, we returned $4.2 billion of cash to investors through a combination of stock repurchases and dividends. In the fourth quarter, TI revenue grew 8% from a year ago, with growth in both Analog and Embedded Processing.
Analog revenue grew 14% from a year ago, led by Power Management. High Value Analog & Logic, High Performance Analog and Silicon Valley Analog also grew. This is the sixth quarter in a row of year-over-year growth for Analog.
Embedded Processing revenue grew 11% from a year ago due to growth in processors, microcontrollers and connectivity, each of which increased by about the same amount. It is notable that connectivity grew at the fastest rate as we continue to see more products being connected. This is the ninth consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth for Embedded Processing.
In our Other segment, revenue declined 14% from a year ago due to legacy Wireless and custom ASIC products.
Turning to distribution. Resales increased 14% from a year ago, consistent with our combined revenue growth of Analog and Embedded Processing. Weeks of inventory decreased by a week from a year ago to a historically low level of just under 4.5 weeks. This level has decreased over the past 2 years because we've structurally changed how our inventories managed in the distribution channel with our consignment program. This quarter, we continue to support more of our distribution sales from consignment inventory and now have about 60% of our distribution revenue on consignment, up about 15 percentage points from a year ago. With this program, inventory sits on TI's balance sheet and revenue is recognized when our distributors pull products from our consignment inventory that's stored at the distributors' location. We carry higher levels of inventory on TI's balance sheet with this program, which had several benefits such as minimizing impact due the changes in distribution channel inventory and giving us greater flexibility to meet customer demand.
Turning to our end markets. In 2014, industrial and automotive combined were 44% of TI's revenue, up a couple of percentage points from last year. Specifically, industrial made up 31% of TI's revenue; automotive, 13%; personal electronics, 29%; communications equipment, 17%; enterprise systems, 6%; and Other, 4%.
We continue to refine our understanding of customers end markets with better tools and software. On our website, we've included the last 2 years of updated markets estimates, and we've identified the sectors inside of each of those markets for your reference.
Finally, let me make a few observations about the year overall. For 2014, Analog and Embedded Processing revenue grew a combined 12%, with Analog up 13% and Embedded up 12%. We gained market share in both businesses again in 2014. These 2 key businesses were 83% of TI's revenue for the year, up from 79% in 2013. Because they now make up more of our revenue, they're driving top line growth for the company. TI revenue overall grew 7% in 2014.
Now Kevin will review profitability, capital management and our outlook.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone.Gross profit in the quarter was $1.90 billion or 58% of revenue. Gross profit increased 16% from a year ago quarter. This gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased loaded and an improved product portfolio
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone.
Gross profit in the quarter was $1.90 billion or 58% of revenue. Gross profit increased 16% from a year ago quarter. This gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased loaded and an improved product portfolio focused on Analog and Embedded Processing that benefits from our efficient manufacturing strategy.
Moving to operating expenses. Combined R&D and SG&A expense of $740 million was down $67 million from a year ago. The decline primarily reflects the targeted reductions in Embedded Processing in Japan that were previously announced. That restructuring is now essentially complete, and we achieved a little more than our estimated annualized savings.
Acquisition charges were $82 million, almost all of which was the ongoing amortization of intangibles, a noncash expense. Restructuring and other charges were a $27 million benefit due to gains on sales of assets. Operating profit was $1.10 billion or 33.6% of revenue. Operating profit was up 60% from the year-ago quarter. Operating margin for Analog was 38.7%. Operating margin for Embedded Processing was 17.0%, more than doubling from a year ago as we benefit from our investments for growth and as we our restructuring plan to better align resources with the opportunities that we are pursuing.
While this is a solid progress, we still have work to do in this business. We expect Embedded operating margins to continue to increase as our investments in R&D and SG&A will continue to drive top line growth while we hold these expenses flat.
Net income in the fourth quarter was $825 million or $0.76 per share. As a reminder, earnings per share included a $0.05 benefit for the reinstatement of the federal research tax credit and a benefit of $0.02 from the gains on sales of assets.
Let me now to comment on our capital management result, starting with our cash generation. Cash flow from operations was $1.27 billion in the quarter. Inventory days were 117, slightly above our model range but a number that we are quite comfortable with. it is with a growing portion of our product demands being supported by consignment inventory versus customer-owned inventory. We believe these consignment arrangements give us better real-time feedback to end market demand, allowing us to better manage our factories and maintain short lead times. We expect consignment inventory to continue to increase over the coming years as distribution becomes a growing portion of our business. We will monitor the appropriateness of our current model of 105 to 115 days investment and possibly update this model in the next year or so.
Capital expenditures were $125 million in the quarter. In 2014, cash flow from operations was $3.89 billion, up 15% from the same period a year ago. For the year, capital expenditures were $385 million or 3% of revenue. As a reminder, our long-term expectation is for capital expenditures to be about 4% [ph] revenue.
Free cash flow for the year was $3.50 billion [ph] or 27% of revenue. Free cash flow was 18% higher than a year ago. As we've said, we believe free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term and will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or potentially reinvested in the business. As we've noted, our intention to return 100% of our free cash flow, plus any proceeds we receive from exercises of equity compensation, minus net debt retirement.
In the fourth quarter, TI paid $356 million in dividends and repurchased $698 million of our stock, for a total return of $1.05 billion. Total cash returned in 2014 was $4.15 billion, which is 3% higher than the prior year. Outstanding share count was reduced by 3.3% over the past 12 months and by 39% since the beginning of 2005. These returns demonstrate our confidence in TI's business model and our to return excess cash to our shareholders.
Fundamental to our to return cash and in our cash management -- on our tax practices, we need -- ended the fourth quarter with $3.54 billion of cash and short-term investments. TI U.S. entities own 82% of our cash. Because our cash is largely onshore, it is available for a variety of uses, including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock.
TI's orders in the quarter were $3.18 billion, up 11% from a year ago.
Turning to our outlook. We expect TI revenue in the range of $3.07 billion to $3.33 billion in the first quarter. At the middle of this range, revenue would increase 7% from a year ago. We expect first quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $0.57 to $0.67. [ph] Restructuring charges will be essentially 0. Acquisition charges, which are noncash amortization charges, will remain about even and hold at about $80 million to $85 million per quarter for the next 5 years.
Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate in 2015 is about 30%, and this is the tax rate you should use for the first quarter and for the year. The rate is higher than last year because of an expected increase in profits and does not assume the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit.
In summary, the fourth quarter demonstrates the growing strength of TI's business model. Our strategy is anchored in Analog and Embedded Processing and is bolstered by an efficient manufacturing operation and a broad sales channel. The result is a diverse and long-lived positions in many markets. We remain intent on excellence in execution, being disciplined in allocating our capital and our firm believers that free cash flow per share is the best indicator for long-term value.
With that, let me turn it back to Dave.

componenttext: Kevin, I guess if you had to characterize the overall environment now versus, say, a quarter ago or a year ago, would you say, broadly speaking, not much has changed? We're still in this seasonal environment? Or have you seen any changes in visibility of your overall business?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, Chris. I think is headed well. It probably hasn't really changed all that much. There was a slight change in our book-to-bill on a year-over-year basis. This quarter was about 0.97, the year ago quarter was 0.94. But frankly, because more and more ord
componenttext: No, Chris. I think is headed well. It probably hasn't really changed all that much. There was a slight change in our book-to-bill on a year-over-year basis. This quarter was about 0.97, the year ago quarter was 0.94. But frankly, because more and more order are consignment, I think both the less and less about a particular where revenue is going. So I think that's the summarize our sense, it's more steady as she goes, just like we've seen for the last few years of an economy just kind of growing along on a steady basis, and we're trying to take advantage from that.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Chris, let me add to that the other things that we see. If you look at our inventory, it's at a healthy level. Our channel inventories are actually down a week, as I said earlier, from a year ago, just under 4.5 weeks. Our lead times remained con
componenttext: Yes. And Chris, let me add to that the other things that we see. If you look at our inventory, it's at a healthy level. Our channel inventories are actually down a week, as I said earlier, from a year ago, just under 4.5 weeks. Our lead times remained consistent. Our cancellations and reschedules remain very, very low. And in addition, we continue to deliver products on time for customers. So those types of things are always a good indication for the environment too. Do you have a follow-up?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it sounds like things are pretty normal [indiscernible]. Can you give us any sense of the relative growth rate of your major product lines this year? What you're expected between Analog, Embedded and the other stuff?
componenttext: Yes. So it sounds like things are pretty normal [indiscernible]. Can you give us any sense of the relative growth rate of your major product lines this year? What you're expected between Analog, Embedded and the other stuff?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we don't try to forecast out a year on the major product lines or even at the company level. I will point out that both of those product lines turned in another year of market share gain. And certainly, we're working very hard to do that for another y
componenttext: No, we don't try to forecast out a year on the major product lines or even at the company level. I will point out that both of those product lines turned in another year of market share gain. And certainly, we're working very hard to do that for another year, and we'll just have to see how the year turns out. So thanks, Chris.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

componenttext: We'll go next to Ambrish Srivastava with BMO Capital Markets.

componenttext: On the inventory front, are we to assume now that your visibility now vis-à-vis in the past is higher also because of higher percentage is consignment of the disti? And within that, that gives you better visibility? Is that the right way to think about it? So the days are coming up versus what your targeted range is and really, not comparable to if you look at the last 5 and 10-year median? And then I had a quick follow-up.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, Rich, I don't know that I would go to improve visibility but we do get I would say a much more improve the real-time feedback from what's actually going on in our true and demand for products. And the real benefit for that is that we can adjust our fa
componenttext: No, Rich, I don't know that I would go to improve visibility but we do get I would say a much more improve the real-time feedback from what's actually going on in our true and demand for products. And the real benefit for that is that we can adjust our factories on a real-time basis, whereas, as you point out, if you went back a number of years, we carried far fewer days of inventory. But the signal as to how fast our product is being consumed in the end market also took a lot longer to get to us, and so we respond later. Now we can respond much more quickly. So it's less the question of improved visibility as it is the question of much more real-time feedback or just how fast our products are being consumed.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

componenttext: Yes. I'd continue to recommend that you would assume that we will average about 4% of our revenues on CapEx, on average over multiyear. Some must have been lighter like it was in this past year where he came in about 3% [ph] in 2014, but on average we expect 4% and I would say.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: On a result. Kevin, 90 days ago when your were talking about OpEx for the December quarter, you said that looking back a year ago and how it flowed a year ago was probably a good model. And you even mentioned it would probably be a good modeling going to
componenttext: On a result. Kevin, 90 days ago when your were talking about OpEx for the December quarter, you said that looking back a year ago and how it flowed a year ago was probably a good model. And you even mentioned it would probably be a good modeling going to calendar first quarter. Is that statement still holds? Or can you help us understand the puts and takes on OpEx going to the March quarter, especially around some seasonal costs?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. You're exactly right. So going from the fourth quarter to the first quarter, the best way to model that is to take a look -- last year's a good starting point. We typically are up in the mid-single digits from fourth to first on OpEx, and that'
componenttext: Yes, John. You're exactly right. So going from the fourth quarter to the first quarter, the best way to model that is to take a look -- last year's a good starting point. We typically are up in the mid-single digits from fourth to first on OpEx, and that's because of the absence of the holiday periods that we have in fourth quarter and the annual startup of benefit increases that we have in the first quarter. This year, we might be up just little bit more than that versus a year ago simply because on the higher profitability that we're expecting for the year. We also expect higher compensation accruals. So that may take our first up a little bit higher than what you saw about a year ago.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow-on, John?
componenttext: Do you have a follow-on, John?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. Just kind of going Analog space. are you guys put up double-digit growth year-over-year this quarter against pretty hard compares from the year-ago quarter. So I'm just kind of curious, to what extent do you think your market shares could be co
componenttext: Yes, I do. Just kind of going Analog space. are you guys put up double-digit growth year-over-year this quarter against pretty hard compares from the year-ago quarter. So I'm just kind of curious, to what extent do you think your market shares could be consolidating around her consignment efforts? Or can you help you understand a little bit better. I know you talked about kind of power leading the way this quarter. Can you help me understand a little bit more why the growth seems to be doing much better than some of your peers?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. I think when you look year-over-year -- first of all, it's good to have all 4 of those businesses contributing to the growth. Certainly, Power is benefiting from just a secular trend of things wanting to run more off batteries and things that d
componenttext: Well, yes. I think when you look year-over-year -- first of all, it's good to have all 4 of those businesses contributing to the growth. Certainly, Power is benefiting from just a secular trend of things wanting to run more off batteries and things that do get plugged in becoming more efficient. We also have a very strong product line there too. So I think that those things are helping us to gain share. And we talked about for some time that it's not one thing business like Analog or Embedded Processing that allows you to gain share. There's a lot of things that you have to do a good Analog company, and we've got a lot of competitors that fit that category. But we've got other things like the scale -- and reach of our salesforce, our presence on the web, our manufacturing footprint, the technology that we bring to bear and the breadth of the product portfolio. So I think it's just all those things kind of working together.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd probably add one more thing there too. Our strategy that we've discussed for a couple of years now, buy in our capacity ahead of our needs and always have ample capacity, quite frankly, gives our customers new and old increased confidence that we had
componenttext: I'd probably add one more thing there too. Our strategy that we've discussed for a couple of years now, buy in our capacity ahead of our needs and always have ample capacity, quite frankly, gives our customers new and old increased confidence that we had adequate capacity that meet their demand requirement. And they see us consistently maintaining short lead times. And so that's just another element that helps us be able to win market share versus some of the other competitors we're up against.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's good. Thanks, John.
componenttext: That's good. Thanks, John.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you for step up in Q1. Now with most of the embedded in Japan restructuring kind of behind you but continued discipline on the team's part, how should we think about OpEx trends beyond the first quarter? I think, Kevin, I heard you mention your embe
componenttext: Thank you for step up in Q1. Now with most of the embedded in Japan restructuring kind of behind you but continued discipline on the team's part, how should we think about OpEx trends beyond the first quarter? I think, Kevin, I heard you mention your embedded OpEx kind of holding flattish. How should we think about the overall business in Q1?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Harlan, I think the best way to think about that is -- and we discussed -- I think it was back in 2011 that on average, we'd expect our OpEx to run between 20% and 30% of revenue. So like in a weak, market is will be 30% level, in stronger market, 20%
componenttext: So Harlan, I think the best way to think about that is -- and we discussed -- I think it was back in 2011 that on average, we'd expect our OpEx to run between 20% and 30% of revenue. So like in a weak, market is will be 30% level, in stronger market, 20% level. We're in a pretty good -- our performance is running slide you see that OpEx come down. In fact, most recently, the second half of 2014, we were running around 23% of revenue. And so I would say that you would want to model us in the lower half of that range as you try to think about how much our OpEx spend will be in 2015.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow-on, Harlan?
componenttext: Do you have a follow-on, Harlan?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Your thoughts directionally on utilization levels here in Q1 given sort of the seasonality in your business. I would assume that it's down again given the book-to-bill ratio and the revenue guidance for Q1. Is that kind of also how we should think di
componenttext: Yes. Your thoughts directionally on utilization levels here in Q1 given sort of the seasonality in your business. I would assume that it's down again given the book-to-bill ratio and the revenue guidance for Q1. Is that kind of also how we should think directionally about gross margins as well?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the way you need to think about utilization is first by definition because we by capacity ahead of time we will by in an underutilized environment managed theoretical capacity. But that aside, because of manufacturing cycle times, the materi
componenttext: Well, I think the way you need to think about utilization is first by definition because we by capacity ahead of time we will by in an underutilized environment managed theoretical capacity. But that aside, because of manufacturing cycle times, the material that we're starting in the first quarter, especially as we move into the second month of the first quarter, really is destined for second quarter shipment. And so your utilization tends to preceed the quarter you're moving as to what your expectations are. And as the second quarter for the last 3, 4, 5 years now, you would growth quarter compared to the first quarter, we will adjust our factor accordingly to our expectations to the second quarter revenue expectations.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Harlan.
componenttext: Thank you, Harlan.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

componenttext: We'll go next to Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think to follow-up on that gross margin question. Looks to me, your imply guidance for margins is maybe 57, maybe a little higher so low 57 down a bit, our revenues are down slightly, with inventories a little higher. Can you give us, I guess, just give
componenttext: I think to follow-up on that gross margin question. Looks to me, your imply guidance for margins is maybe 57, maybe a little higher so low 57 down a bit, our revenues are down slightly, with inventories a little higher. Can you give us, I guess, just give us some feeling if you don't want to give numbers of the some of the drivers for gross margins into Q1. and In particular, what you're doing on the balance sheet how will that trend?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know that I necessarily have -- I don't want to get into the GPM per se. Let me just talk a little bit more about what our inventory levels might look sound that. We don't have an inventory forecast per se. But given the growth in consignment
componenttext: Yes, I don't know that I necessarily have -- I don't want to get into the GPM per se. Let me just talk a little bit more about what our inventory levels might look sound that. We don't have an inventory forecast per se. But given the growth in consignment and the typically strong 2Q, we expect our to move in the quarter, as I mentioned a moment ago. One of the things to keep in mind when you adjust your factory loadings, if your quarterly loadings are really for the following quarter's expectations, then if you think about the pattern of movement through the quarter, you take your loadings coming in the fourth quarter dropping coming into the quarter and going in the first quarter, our start to increase in the quarter. And so you're always going to have a bit of a lag when you try to track the GPM, which I think is what you're asking for there, Stacy. I think more importantly, what we see going forward is that our margin we expect to continue to improve along with our free cash flow by virtue of the fact that Analog and Embedded Processing continue to become a larger portion of our total revenues and by virtue of the fact that 300-millimeter manufacturing can be a larger portion of our total production as we go forward in both of those result in both higher margins and higher free cash flow.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: For my follow-up, just a touch on the tax rate. So your guide for next year 30, a little higher than your guidance for 2014 was which I think was 28. I just want to verify their only real source of that just a higher profit versus expectation. I think you
componenttext: For my follow-up, just a touch on the tax rate. So your guide for next year 30, a little higher than your guidance for 2014 was which I think was 28. I just want to verify their only real source of that just a higher profit versus expectation. I think you had told us before the sort of tax every incremental profit of dollar at the incremental tax rate 35%?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stacy, that's correct. In fact, our tax rate in 2014 -- our guidance was, they rounded down to 28%. It actually came a little bit higher than that if it weren't for the our R&D credit. So we're looking at it rounding up to 30% as we move into 2015. S
componenttext: Yes, Stacy, that's correct. In fact, our tax rate in 2014 -- our guidance was, they rounded down to 28%. It actually came a little bit higher than that if it weren't for the our R&D credit. So we're looking at it rounding up to 30% as we move into 2015. So you're exactly right. As you model, what you would expect our earnings and fall-through to be, you should tax that of approximately 35% delta profit as it comes through during the year.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll just point out too, Stacy, that does not -- assuming the reinstate of the R&D tax credit that we got for 2014.
componenttext: And I'll just point out too, Stacy, that does not -- assuming the reinstate of the R&D tax credit that we got for 2014.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, if that those reinstate, that'll be between 1 and 2 points of tax benefits.
componenttext: Yes, if that those reinstate, that'll be between 1 and 2 points of tax benefits.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great.
componenttext: Great.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

componenttext: We'll go next to Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, when I look at your Q4 results versus consensus estimates, you did better in your core Analog and Embedded segments. But there was some shortfall in the Other sales, which are actually down 6% year-on-year. I think they were down almost 11% last
componenttext: Actually, when I look at your Q4 results versus consensus estimates, you did better in your core Analog and Embedded segments. But there was some shortfall in the Other sales, which are actually down 6% year-on-year. I think they were down almost 11% last year. And I believe you mentioned some loss of ASIC business. I'm wondering, what is the right way, Kevin or Dave, to model this segment? Because it is a very profitable segment for you. It is still a decent sized segment. I think in the past, you had mentioned that it could be sort of flattish, plus minus 2% or so. So just conceptually, what is the right way to model this segment?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look, Vivek, at the Other segment -- the first thing I would point out is that it has our calculator revenue. And the seasonally strong back-to-school season happens in the second and third quarter. So those tend to be the longest quarter, thi
componenttext: Yes, if you look, Vivek, at the Other segment -- the first thing I would point out is that it has our calculator revenue. And the seasonally strong back-to-school season happens in the second and third quarter. So those tend to be the longest quarter, third to fourth, that biggest transition, sequentially of course is due to the change in -- the change of that business. If you look overall, you can look at the components that sit inside of Other. The first is DLP. And I'd described that as a more steady business and one that may have some we describe wild cards of new opportunities. The vast majority of that business is in front projectors today as well as in cinema. And we've got some what the call pico projectors or small form factors that make up the revenue. But there are some opportunities inside of automotive and other embedded opportunities that could provide growth in the future. The next biggest piece of that revenue is calculators. And that business has been, I'd say flat to maybe slightly down over time. And then royalties have run steady, about $40 million to $50 million a quarter. And that's probably a good thing to look. And then we will have ASIC business that will transition over EP over time. And that is some business that is in communications infrastructure, and we believe that, that will move over. So we kind of net all that stuff together we kind of thing that the Other segment will be flat, may be up or down a percentage point as we've described in the past.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

componenttext: And I think, Vivek, also asked about year-over-year. Recall that last year still we had about $55 million or so of Wireless revenue in this, and this year is essentially 0. So that's your biggest decline on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

componenttext: Yes, as my follow on, back to your core business. Do think you have the right scale in your Embedded business to take margins into the 20s? So when I look to the 3 areas within that business, processors, connectivity, microcontrollers, how would you rank TI against the best competitor in that segment? And really, I'm trying to understand how you can grow that segment, gain share, improve margins while keeping investments flattish while all your competitors are all investing in their respective businesses?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Vivek, I'll leave it to you to analyze the competitors. I'll speak to TI's doing. You can recall late 10, early 11 time frame, we kept up our investments in that particular segment in order to accelerate our product introductions and therefore, to a
componenttext: Well, Vivek, I'll leave it to you to analyze the competitors. I'll speak to TI's doing. You can recall late 10, early 11 time frame, we kept up our investments in that particular segment in order to accelerate our product introductions and therefore, to accelerate our revenue growth. And if you take a look at what had happened over the last, as we've mentioned in our opening remarks, 9 quarters of sequential of continuous year-over-year growth, has paid off so those found that. And as you know, those kinds of products didn't have very long shelf lives so we expect to see more on that. And while we took spending down this past year as a result of the restructuring actions we announced this time a year ago, we didn't eliminate them. The amount that we're investing is still quite high, and that's why the operating profit is still not quite will take the dues we continue to invest that quite a healthy level, just not at the level that you saw us invest in the prior few years. So those combined, high levels of investment, a expanding product portfolio from heavier levels of investment in the prior few years, have all given us very strong growth in that segment and will continue to give us growth. And quite frankly, based upon some of the best-in-class performance that you can look out there we have shall we say, expectations the murder to at least what their companies are operating.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'd also add, Vivek, if you look at our product portfolio like inside the microcontrollers, we've got 2 architectures there where we'll introduce new products with new interfaces and -- that meet new standards inside of that. A lot of our competi
componenttext: Yes. And I'd also add, Vivek, if you look at our product portfolio like inside the microcontrollers, we've got 2 architectures there where we'll introduce new products with new interfaces and -- that meet new standards inside of that. A lot of our competitors would have half a dozen or dozens different architecture where they've got to spread their R&D efforts, so we can be very efficient with that. So in addition, if you remember, as part of the Wireless restructuring, we brought over those connectivity products that really already had a pretty significant investment in those Wireless technology. So we're supporting nearly a dozen different Wireless standards today. And that group is really focused on growing the top line rather than having to develop baseline technologies. So with that -- thanks for that question, Vivek.

componenttext: [indiscernible] my one question is just around the long-term segment goals that you might have. Auto is kind of low double-digits. Personal electronic is almost 30%, although that's coming down. Is the goal really from a segment diversification to continue to increase in particular that auto subcategory and decrease the personal electronics category, say, over the next 2 or 3 years?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim, I don't -- our goal is not necessarily to try to optimize that mix per se. I would say that, if you look inside of personal electronics for an example , we'll look for places we can find sustainable revenue with a differentiated position. And if
componenttext: Yes, Jim, I don't -- our goal is not necessarily to try to optimize that mix per se. I would say that, if you look inside of personal electronics for an example , we'll look for places we can find sustainable revenue with a differentiated position. And if you look at some of our largest customers that we sell products into, we'll sell several hundred devices into those customers. And those products could be anywhere from $0.75 [ph] down to a net go. [ph] And oftentimes, they may have lives that lived from 1 generation of a product to another. So those are the types of opportunities that we try to look for in a space like comms equipment. Now certainly from an incremental investment profile, if we had an extra dollar to spend than we had an opportunity to spend that in neither industrial our automotive, those products in general just tend to have longer life cycles and better characteristics. So that may see an increase in investment. And then lastly, I just add that those 2 markets have the secular trend that you're well aware off. So we'll benefit from that as the rest of the industry will. And of course, we hope to benefit disproportionately from those investments. Do you have a follow-up, Jim?

componenttext: Yes, Craig, I would say that we're probably I'll walk that we had to entertain a question like that. Our focus for the next few years is managing the total spend inside that business and driving top line growth. And frankly, if we begin to see top line growth, then begins a net kind of bottom line results that we can see happening in other players in that space. headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the follow-up is really taking a swing at something that Chris brought up, which is longer-term growth on a segment basis. At least in my model, calendar '14 was the first year 4 and 5 were Embedded Processing and Analog have similar growth rate
componenttext: Okay. And the follow-up is really taking a swing at something that Chris brought up, which is longer-term growth on a segment basis. At least in my model, calendar '14 was the first year 4 and 5 were Embedded Processing and Analog have similar growth rates, and they were both double-digits. Just, as you look at those 2 businesses which have had 2 different histories, are there reasons why they should have materially different growth rates going forward? Or given that they're both closer to operating on more optimal levels, should they be fairly similar?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think when you begun to look longer term of the growth rate and the potential of those business. I'd start with what do you believe the our [indiscernible] grow at?  We have held the position that we think that the semiconductor market roughly grow
componenttext: Yes, I think when you begun to look longer term of the growth rate and the potential of those business. I'd start with what do you believe the our [indiscernible] grow at?  We have held the position that we think that the semiconductor market roughly grows at twice the rate of GDP. There will some that will violently agree with this, and some that will disagree with that basic assumption. But whatever that assumption is, we think that both the Analog and Embedded Processing are big enough portions of the market that they will grow in line with that. If you look at those businesses, certainly over the last 5 years, they both have continued to gain share. And we believe that we're continuing to invest, and we've got a lot of room to gain share. In fact, in Analog, we've got 18.3% market share. And inside of Embedded Processing, we've got around 15 percentage points. So lots of headroom to do that. So -- and we've gained probably 30%, 40% sometimes more than market share on a given year. We stopped to have everyone report before the final numbers are in, but we're confident that we'll gain again share this year. So Kevin, do you have anything to add to that?

componenttext: Yes, Craig, one thing recommending may be taking a look at. componenttext: Okay, Doug. Well, I can -- let me share some end market trends that we see. I think that that may address some of those issues, not down at the level that you're quite asking. So I think you are talking about PCs, and those would fall into our personal electronics products. Those were, on a year-on-year basis, they were up despite the declines that Kevin had mentioned earlier in legacy Wireless. And that growth rate was led by mobile phones. If you look at industrial -- and I want to point out, when we talk about industrial, we've been very intentional about how to measure that. And it's different than when investors talk about the industrial market. And the sectors, we've got a dozen sectors that make up industrial. And they include things like factory automation and control, medical, healthcare, fitness, building, automation, smart grid, motor drives, display, those types of things, the full list is out on our website. And we've seen that was up, led by medical and healthcare fitness. Appliance, factory, automation and smart grid were also up from a year ago. Comms equipment was up due to Wireless infrastructure. And then enterprise systems were up primarily due to projectors. So with that, do you have a follow-on?

componenttext: Great. I guess, for my follow-on, just what are you seeing in terms of any shift in the competitive landscape? I know investors are somewhat concerned over what we're seeing in China from an investment standpoint. Is there anything in your markets that you're seeing that would point to any change in the competitive landscape?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: You know, Doug, as it relates to China, in particular that you mentioned out there, we've been in China for a very long time now. We have over -- I think over a dozen sales and R&D sites there. We have both a wafer fabrication facility and an assembly tes
componenttext: You know, Doug, as it relates to China, in particular that you mentioned out there, we've been in China for a very long time now. We have over -- I think over a dozen sales and R&D sites there. We have both a wafer fabrication facility and an assembly test site there. In addition, we have thousands of customers buying thousands of parts, and consequently, we are becoming very important supplier to a large number of Chinese companies across a very diverse set of markets. So we continue to see China as a great opportunity for TI regardless of the any competitive environment out there. Our goal is to operate in China with the rest of the world, which is make as part of the incremental and an supplier. And we've got a great, how do I say a long way -- we're a long way into that already, and we feel pretty good about our position.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter and year-end 2014 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and rele
componenttext:
Thank you, and good afternoon, and thank you for joining our fourth quarter and year-end 2014 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.
For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations on our web at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through TI's website. A replay will be available through the web.
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the safe harbor statement contained in the earnings release published today as well as TI's most recent SEC filings for a more complete description.
Before I review the quarter, let me provide some information that's important to your calendar. We plan to hold a call on February 4 at 10:00 a.m. Central time to update our capital management strategy. Similar to what we've done in the -- for the last 2 years on this topic, Kevin March will provide insight into our strategy and also answer some of the most frequently asked questions.
Turning to our earnings update. The fourth quarter marked another quarter of strong progress. Our core businesses of Analog and Embedded Processing grew again with combined revenue up 13% from a year ago. Revenue of $3.27 billion came in at the middle of the expected range that we communicated to you in October. Earnings per share were $0.76 and included a $0.05 benefit for the reinstatement of the federal research tax credit and a $0.02 benefit from gains on sales of assets. Without these 2 items, our earnings would have been in the middle of our expected range.
In the fourth quarter, our cash flow from operations was $1.3 billion. We believe that free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term. Free cash flow for the year was $3.5 billion, up 18% from a year ago. Free cash flow was 27% of revenue, consistent with our targeted range of 20% to 30%. This is a 3 percentage point increase improvement from a year ago period. We believe this reflects our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy, which includes our growing 300-millimeter output and the opportunistic purchase of assets ahead of demand. We also believe that free cash flow will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business.
In 2014, we returned $4.2 billion of cash to investors through a combination of stock repurchases and dividends. 
In the fourth quarter, TI revenue grew 8% from a year ago, with growth in both Analog and Embedded Processing.
Analog revenue grew 14% from a year ago, led by Power Management. High Volume Analog & Logic, High Performance Analog and Silicon Valley Analog also grew. This is the sixth quarter in a row of year-over-year growth for Analog. 
Embedded Processing revenue grew 11% from a year ago due to growth in processors, microcontrollers and connectivity, each of which increased by about the same amount. It is notable that connectivity grew at the fastest rate as we continue to see more products being connected. This is the ninth consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth for Embedded Processing.
In our Other segment, revenue declined 14% from a year ago due to legacy Wireless and custom ASIC products.
Turning to distribution. Resales increased 14% from a year ago, consistent with our combined revenue growth of Analog and Embedded Processing. Weeks of inventory decreased by a week from a year ago to a historically low level of just under 4.5 weeks. This level has decreased over the past 2 years because we've structurally changed how our inventory is managed in the distribution channel with our consignment program. This quarter, we continue to support more of our distribution sales from consignment inventory and now have about 60% of our distribution revenue on consignment, up about 15 percentage points from a year ago. 
With this program, inventory sits on TI's balance sheet and revenue is recognized when our distributors pull products from our consignment inventory that's stored at the distributors' location. We carry higher levels of inventory on TI's balance sheet with this program, which has several benefits such as minimizing impact due to changes in distribution channel inventory and giving us greater flexibility to meet customer demand.
Turning to our end markets. In 2014, industrial and automotive combined were 44% of TI's revenue, up a couple of percentage points from last year. Specifically, industrial made up 31% of TI's revenue; automotive, 13%; personal electronics, 29%; communications equipment, 17%; enterprise systems, 6%; and other, 4%. We continue to refine our understanding of customers' end markets with better tools and software. On our website, we've included the last 2 years of updated market estimates, and we've identified the sectors inside of each of those markets for your reference.
Finally, let me make a few observations about the year overall. For 2014, Analog and Embedded Processing revenue grew a combined 12%, with Analog up 13% and Embedded up 12%. We gained market share in both businesses again in 2014. These 2 key businesses were 83% of TI's revenue for the year, up from 79% in 2013. Because they now make up more of our revenue, they're driving top line growth for the company. TI revenue overall grew 7% in 2014.
Now Kevin will review profitability, capital management and our outlook.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone.Gross profit in the quarter was $1.90 billion or 58% of revenue. Gross profit increased 16% from the year ago quarter. This gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased factory loadings and an improved produ
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone.
Gross profit in the quarter was $1.90 billion or 58% of revenue. Gross profit increased 16% from the year ago quarter. This gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased factory loadings and an improved product portfolio focused on Analog and Embedded Processing that benefits from our efficient manufacturing strategy.
Moving to operating expenses. Combined R&D and SG&A expense of $740 million was down $67 million from a year ago. The decline primarily reflects the targeted reductions in Embedded Processing in Japan that were previously announced. That restructuring is now essentially complete, and we achieved a little more than our estimated annualized savings.
Acquisition charges were $82 million, almost all of which were the ongoing amortization of intangibles, a noncash expense. Restructuring and other charges were a $27 million benefit due to gains on sales of assets. 
Operating profit was $1.10 billion or 33.6% of revenue. Operating profit was up 60% from the year-ago quarter. 
Operating margin for Analog was 38.7%. Operating margin for Embedded Processing was 17.0%, more than doubling from a year ago as we benefit from our investments for growth and as we executed our restructuring plan to better align resources with the opportunities that we are pursuing. While there's a solid progress, we still have work to do in this business. We expect Embedded operating margins to continue to increase as our investments in R&D and SG&A will continue to drive top line growth while we hold these expenses flat.
Net income in the fourth quarter was $825 million or $0.76 per share. As a reminder, earnings per share included a $0.05 benefit for the reinstatement of the federal research tax credit and a benefit of $0.02 from the gains on sales of assets.
Let me now to comment on our capital management results, starting with our cash generation. Cash flow from operations was $1.27 billion in the quarter. Inventory days were 117, slightly above our model range but a number that we are quite comfortable with. It is consistent with the growing portion of our product demands being supported with consignment inventory versus customer-owned inventory. We believe these consignment arrangements give us better real-time feedback to end market demand, allowing us to better manage our factories and maintain short lead times. We'll expect consignment inventory to continue to increase over the coming years as distribution becomes a growing portion of our business. We will monitor the appropriateness of our current model of 105 to 115 days of inventory and possibly update this model in the next year or so.
Capital expenditures were $125 million in the quarter. In 2014, cash flow from operations was $3.89 billion, up 15% from the same period a year ago. For the year, capital expenditures were $385 million or 3% of revenue. As a reminder, our long-term expectation is for capital expenditures to be about 4% of revenue.
Free cash flow for the year was $3.50 billion or 27% of revenue. Free cash flow was 18% higher than a year ago. As we've said, we believe free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term and will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or productively reinvested in the business. As we've noted, our intention is to return 100% of our free cash flow plus any proceeds we receive from exercises of equity compensation minus net debt retirement.
In the fourth quarter, TI paid $356 million in dividends and repurchased $698 million of our stock, for a total return of $1.05 billion. Total cash returned in 2014 was $4.15 billion, which is 3% higher than the prior year. Outstanding share count was reduced by 3.3% over the past 12 months and by 39% since the beginning of 2005. These returns demonstrate our confidence in TI's business model and our commitment to return excess cash to our shareholders.
Fundamental to our commitment to return cash in (sic) are our cash management and our tax practices. We need the fourth -- ended the fourth quarter with $3.54 billion of cash and short-term investments. TI's U.S. entities own 82% of our cash. Because our cash is largely onshore, it is readily available for a variety of uses, including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock.
TI orders in the quarter were $3.18 billion, up 11% from a year ago.
Turning to our outlook. We expect TI revenue in the range of $3.07 billion to $3.33 billion in the first quarter. At the middle of this range, revenue would increase 7% from a year ago. We expect first quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $0.57 to $0.67. Restructuring charges will be essentially 0. Acquisition charges, which are noncash amortization charges, will remain about even and hold at about $80 million to $85 million per quarter for the next 5 years.
Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate in 2015 is about 30%, and this is the tax rate you should use for the first quarter and for the year. The rate is higher than last year because of an expected increase in profits and does not assume the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit.
In summary, the fourth quarter demonstrates the growing strength of TI's business model. Our strategy is anchored in Analog and Embedded Processing and is bolstered by an efficient manufacturing operation and a broad sales channel. The result is a diverse and long-lived positions in many markets. We remain intent on excellence in execution, being disciplined in allocating our capital, and our firm belief that free cash flow per share is the best long-term indicator of shareholder value.
With that, let me turn it back to Dave.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
