componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Chris Danely with Citi.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kevin, I guess if you had to characterize the overall environment now versus, say, a quarter ago or a year ago, would you say, broadly speaking, not much has changed, we're still in this kind of fine [ph], roughly seasonal environment? Or have you seen an
componenttext: Kevin, I guess if you had to characterize the overall environment now versus, say, a quarter ago or a year ago, would you say, broadly speaking, not much has changed, we're still in this kind of fine [ph], roughly seasonal environment? Or have you seen any changes in visibility of your overall business?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, Chris, I think you said it well. It probably hasn't really changed all that much. There was a slight change in our book-to-bill on a year-over-year basis. This quarter, it was about 0.97. The year ago quarter was 0.94. But frankly, because more and mo
componenttext: No, Chris, I think you said it well. It probably hasn't really changed all that much. There was a slight change in our book-to-bill on a year-over-year basis. This quarter, it was about 0.97. The year ago quarter was 0.94. But frankly, because more and more of our orders are coming in on consignment, I think book-to-bill means less and less about a predictor of where our revenue is going. So I think that summarizes our sense. It's more steady as she goes, just like we've seen for the last few years of an economy just kind of growing along on a steady basis, and we're trying to take advantage and grow a little bit faster than that.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Chris, let me add just the other things that we see. If you look at our inventory, it's at a healthy level. Our channel inventories are actually down a week, as I said earlier, from a year ago, just to under 4.5 weeks. Our lead times remain consi
componenttext: Yes. And Chris, let me add just the other things that we see. If you look at our inventory, it's at a healthy level. Our channel inventories are actually down a week, as I said earlier, from a year ago, just to under 4.5 weeks. Our lead times remain consistent. Our cancellations and reschedules remain very, very low. And in addition, we continue to deliver products on time for customers. So those types of things are always a good indication for the overall environment, too. Do you have a follow-up?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it sounds like things are pretty normal, seasonal at the distis too. Can you give us any sense of the relative growth rates of your major product lines this year, what you're expecting between Analog, Embedded and the other stuff?
componenttext: Yes. So it sounds like things are pretty normal, seasonal at the distis too. Can you give us any sense of the relative growth rates of your major product lines this year, what you're expecting between Analog, Embedded and the other stuff?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we don't try to forecast out a year on the major product lines or even at the company level. I will point out that both of those product lines turned in another year of market share gains. And certainly, we're working really hard to do that for anothe
componenttext: No, we don't try to forecast out a year on the major product lines or even at the company level. I will point out that both of those product lines turned in another year of market share gains. And certainly, we're working really hard to do that for another year, and we'll just have to see how the year turns out. So thanks, Chris.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Ambrish Srivastava with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: We'll go next to Ambrish Srivastava with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the inventory front, are we to assume now that your visibility now vis-à-vis in the past is higher also because of a higher percentage is consignment off the disti? And within that, that gives you better visibility? Is that the right way to think abou
componenttext: On the inventory front, are we to assume now that your visibility now vis-à-vis in the past is higher also because of a higher percentage is consignment off the disti? And within that, that gives you better visibility? Is that the right way to think about it? So the days are going up versus what your targeted range is and really not comparable to -- if we look at the last 5- and 10-year median? And then I had a quick follow-up.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ambrish, I don't know that I would necessarily go to improved visibility. But we do get, I'd say, a much more improved or real-time feedback from what's actually going on with true end demand for our products. And the real benefit of that is that we
componenttext: Yes, Ambrish, I don't know that I would necessarily go to improved visibility. But we do get, I'd say, a much more improved or real-time feedback from what's actually going on with true end demand for our products. And the real benefit of that is that we can adjust our factories on a real-time basis, whereas, as you pointed out, if you went back a number of years, we carried far fewer days of inventory. But the signal as to how fast our products were actually being consumed in the end market also took a lot longer to get to us, and so we'd respond later. Now we can respond much more quickly. So it's less a question of improved visibility as it is a question of much more real-time feedback as to just how fast our products are being consumed.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Kevin, that's what I meant because we always get into this debate in cycles about sell-in and sell-through. My quick clarification question is what should we be modeling for CapEx for this year?
componenttext: Okay. Kevin, that's what I meant because we always get into this debate in cycles about sell-in and sell-through. My quick clarification question is what should we be modeling for CapEx for this year?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd continue to recommend that you would assume that we will average about 4% of our revenues on CapEx on average over multiyear periods. Some years might be a little lighter like it was this past year, where we came in at about 3% in 2014. But on av
componenttext: Yes. I'd continue to recommend that you would assume that we will average about 4% of our revenues on CapEx on average over multiyear periods. Some years might be a little lighter like it was this past year, where we came in at about 3% in 2014. But on average, we expect 4%, and that's how we build our own internal models.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Ambrish.
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Ambrish.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question is from John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Next question is from John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kevin, 90 days ago, when you were talking about OpEx for the December quarter, you said that looking back a year ago and how it flowed a year ago was probably a good model. And you even mentioned that it would probably be a good model going into the calen
componenttext: Kevin, 90 days ago, when you were talking about OpEx for the December quarter, you said that looking back a year ago and how it flowed a year ago was probably a good model. And you even mentioned that it would probably be a good model going into the calendar first quarter. Does that statement still hold? Or can you help us understand the puts and takes on OpEx going into the March quarter, especially around some seasonal costs?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, you're exactly right. So going from the fourth quarter to the first quarter, the best way to model that is to take a look -- really, last year is a good starting point. We typically are up in the mid-single digits from fourth to first on OpEx,
componenttext: Yes, John, you're exactly right. So going from the fourth quarter to the first quarter, the best way to model that is to take a look -- really, last year is a good starting point. We typically are up in the mid-single digits from fourth to first on OpEx, and that's because of the absence of the holiday periods that we have in fourth quarter and the annual startup of pay and benefit increases that we have in first quarter. This year, we might be up just a little bit more than that versus a year ago simply because on higher profitability that we're expecting for the year, we also expect higher variable compensation accruals. And so that may take our first up a little bit higher than what you saw about a year ago.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow-on, John?
componenttext: Do you have a follow-on, John?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. Just going back to kind of the Analog space, Dave, maybe you can give us a little bit more color, because it's pretty impressive. You guys put up double-digit growth year-over-year this quarter against pretty hard compares from the year-ago qua
componenttext: Yes, I do. Just going back to kind of the Analog space, Dave, maybe you can give us a little bit more color, because it's pretty impressive. You guys put up double-digit growth year-over-year this quarter against pretty hard compares from the year-ago quarter. So I'm just kind of curious, to what extent do you think your market share gains could be accelerating around your consignment efforts? Or if you can just help me understand a little bit better. I know you talked about Power kind of leading the way this quarter. Can you help me understand a little bit more why the growth seems to be doing much better than some of your peers?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. I think when you look year-over-year -- first of all, it's good to have all 4 of those businesses contributing to the growth. But certainly, Power is benefiting from just a secular trend of things wanting to run more off of batteries and things
componenttext: Well, yes. I think when you look year-over-year -- first of all, it's good to have all 4 of those businesses contributing to the growth. But certainly, Power is benefiting from just a secular trend of things wanting to run more off of batteries and things that do get plugged in becoming more efficient. We also have a very strong product line there, too. So I think that those things are helping us to gain share. And we've talked about for some time that it's not one thing inside of a business like Analog or Embedded Processing that allows you to gain share. There's a lot of things that you have to do to be a good Analog company, and we've got a lot of competitors that fit that category. But we've got other things like the scale of our -- and reach of our salesforce, our presence on the web, our manufacturing footprint, the technology that we bring to bear and the breadth of the product portfolio. So I think it's just all of those things kind of working together.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd probably add one more thing there, too. Our strategy of -- that we've discussed for a couple of years now of buying our capacity ahead of our needs and always having ample capacity, quite frankly, gives our customers, new and old, increased confidence
componenttext: I'd probably add one more thing there, too. Our strategy of -- that we've discussed for a couple of years now of buying our capacity ahead of our needs and always having ample capacity, quite frankly, gives our customers, new and old, increased confidence that we have adequate capacity to meet their demand requirement. And they see us consistently maintaining short lead times. And so that's just another element that helps us be able to win market share versus some of the other competitors we're up against.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's good. Thanks, John.
componenttext: That's good. Thanks, John.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Now with most of the Embedded and Japan restructuring kind of behind you but continued discipline on the team's part, how should we think about the OpEx trends beyond the first quarter? I think, Kevin, I heard you mention your embedded OpEx kind of holdin
componenttext: Now with most of the Embedded and Japan restructuring kind of behind you but continued discipline on the team's part, how should we think about the OpEx trends beyond the first quarter? I think, Kevin, I heard you mention your embedded OpEx kind of holding flattish. But how should we think about the overall business beyond Q1?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Harlan, I think the best way to think about that is we discussed, I think it was back in 2011, that on average, we'd expect our OpEx to run between 20% and 30% of revenue. So like in a weak market, it might be at the 30% level. In stronger markets, it
componenttext: So Harlan, I think the best way to think about that is we discussed, I think it was back in 2011, that on average, we'd expect our OpEx to run between 20% and 30% of revenue. So like in a weak market, it might be at the 30% level. In stronger markets, it would be in the 20% level. We're in a pretty good -- we're performing quite well on our markets right now, and so you're seeing that OpEx come down. In fact, most recently, in the second half of 2014, we were running around 23% of revenue. And so I would say that you would want to model us in the lower half of that range as you try to think about how much our OpEx spend will be in 2015.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Do you have a follow-on, Harlan?
componenttext: Great. Do you have a follow-on, Harlan?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Your thoughts directionally on utilization levels here in Q1, given sort of the seasonality in your business, I would assume that it's down again given the book-to-bill ratio and the revenue guidance for Q1. Is that kind of also how we should think d
componenttext: Yes. Your thoughts directionally on utilization levels here in Q1, given sort of the seasonality in your business, I would assume that it's down again given the book-to-bill ratio and the revenue guidance for Q1. Is that kind of also how we should think directionally about gross margins as well?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the way you need to think about utilization is first, by definition, because we buy capacity ahead of time, we will, by definition, be operating in an underutilized environment versus our maximum capacity, theoretical capacity. But that asid
componenttext: Well, I think the way you need to think about utilization is first, by definition, because we buy capacity ahead of time, we will, by definition, be operating in an underutilized environment versus our maximum capacity, theoretical capacity. But that aside, because of manufacturing cycle times, the material that we're starting in the first quarter, especially as we move into the second month of the first quarter, really is destined for second quarter shipments. And so your utilization tends to precede the quarter you're moving into as to what your expectations are. And as the second quarter for the last 3, 4, 5 years now, and normally for us as a growth quarter compared to the first quarter, we will adjust our factory loadings accordingly to our expectation to second quarter revenue expectations.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Harlan.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you, Harlan.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein.
componenttext: We'll go next to Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think to follow-up on that gross margin question, it looks to me your implied guidance for margins is maybe 57% -- maybe a little higher, so low 57%. It's down a little bit. Our revenues are down slightly, with inventories a little higher. Can you just,
componenttext: I think to follow-up on that gross margin question, it looks to me your implied guidance for margins is maybe 57% -- maybe a little higher, so low 57%. It's down a little bit. Our revenues are down slightly, with inventories a little higher. Can you just, I guess, give us some feeling of, if you don't want to give numbers, at least some of the drivers for gross margins into Q1? And in particular, what are you planning to do with the inventory on your own balance sheet? How will that trend?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know that I necessarily have -- I don't want to get into the GPM per se. Let me just talk a little bit more about what our inventory levels might look like and how that might drive us. We don't have an inventory forecast per se. But given the
componenttext: Yes, I don't know that I necessarily have -- I don't want to get into the GPM per se. Let me just talk a little bit more about what our inventory levels might look like and how that might drive us. We don't have an inventory forecast per se. But given the growth in consignment and the typically seasonally strong 2Q, we expect our factory loadings to increase as we move through the quarter, as I mentioned a moment ago. One of the things to keep in mind when you adjust your factory loadings, if your quarterly loadings are really for the following quarter's expectations, then if you think about the pattern of movement through the quarter, if you take your loadings coming into the fourth quarter, our loadings will be dropping coming into the quarter. And going into the first quarter, our loadings start to increase during the quarter. And so you're always going to have a bit of a lag when you try to track the GPM that follows with that, which I think is what you're asking for there, Stacy. I think more importantly, what we see going forward is that our margins we expect to continue to improve, along with our free cash flow, by virtue of the fact that Analog and Embedded Processing continue to become a larger portion of our total revenues and by virtue of the fact that 300-millimeter manufacturing continues to be a larger portion of our total production as we go forward. And both of those result in both higher margins and higher free cash flow.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. For my follow-up, just a touch on the tax rate. So your guide for next year, 30%, a little higher than your guidance for 2014, which I think was 28%. I just wanted to verify, the only real source of that, just the higher profit versus expectation.
componenttext: Got it. For my follow-up, just a touch on the tax rate. So your guide for next year, 30%, a little higher than your guidance for 2014, which I think was 28%. I just wanted to verify, the only real source of that, just the higher profit versus expectation. I think you had told us before to sort of tax every incremental dollar of profit around the -- at the incremental tax rate, 35%?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stacy, that's correct. In fact, our tax rate in 2014, our guidance was, as you said, say, rounded down to 28%. It actually came in just a little bit higher than that if it weren't for the R&D credit. And so we're looking at it rounding up to 30% as w
componenttext: Yes, Stacy, that's correct. In fact, our tax rate in 2014, our guidance was, as you said, say, rounded down to 28%. It actually came in just a little bit higher than that if it weren't for the R&D credit. And so we're looking at it rounding up to 30% as we move into 2015. So you're exactly right. As you model what you would expect our earnings and fall-through to be, you should tax that at approximately 35% delta profit as it comes through during the year.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll just point out, too, Stacy, that, that does not assume the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit that we got for 2014.
componenttext: And I'll just point out, too, Stacy, that, that does not assume the reinstatement of the R&D tax credit that we got for 2014.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. If that does reinstate, that'll be between 1 and 2 points of tax benefit.
componenttext: Yes. If that does reinstate, that'll be between 1 and 2 points of tax benefit.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's right. Good.
componenttext: That's right. Good.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: We'll go next to Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually, when I look at your Q4 results versus consensus estimates, you did better in your core Analog and Embedded segments. But there were some shortfall in the Other sales, which are actually down 6% year-on-year. I think they were down almost 11% las
componenttext: Actually, when I look at your Q4 results versus consensus estimates, you did better in your core Analog and Embedded segments. But there were some shortfall in the Other sales, which are actually down 6% year-on-year. I think they were down almost 11% last year. And I believe you mentioned some loss of ASIC business. I'm wondering, what is the right way, Kevin or Dave, to model this segment? Because it is a very profitable segment for you. It is still a decent-sized segment. And I think in the past, you have mentioned that it could be sort of flattish, plus minus 2% or so. So just conceptually, what is the right way to model this segment?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. If you look, Vivek, at the Other segment, the first thing I would point out is it has our calculator revenue. And the seasonally strong back-to-school season happens in the second and third quarter. So those tend to be the seasonally strongest quarte
componenttext: Yes. If you look, Vivek, at the Other segment, the first thing I would point out is it has our calculator revenue. And the seasonally strong back-to-school season happens in the second and third quarter. So those tend to be the seasonally strongest quarters. Third to fourth, that biggest transition sequentially, of course, is due to the change in -- the change of that business. If you look overall, you can look at the components that sit inside of Other. The first is DLP. And I'd described that as a more steady business and one that may have some we'd describe as wild cards of new opportunities. The vast majority of that business is in front projectors today as well as in cinema. And we've got some what we call pico projectors or small form-factor projectors that make up the revenue. But there are some opportunities inside of automotive and other embedded opportunities that could provide growth in the future. The next biggest piece of that revenue is calculators. And that business has been, I'd say, flat to maybe slightly down over time. And then royalties have run steady, about $40 million to $50 million a quarter. And that's probably a good thing to look. And then we will have ASIC business that will transition over to EP over time. That is some business that's in communications infrastructure. And we believe that, that will move over. So you kind of net all that stuff together and we kind of think that the Other segment will be flat, maybe up or down a percentage point, as we've described in the past.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I think, Vivek, you also asked about year-over-year. Just recall that last year still had about $55 million or so of Wireless revenue in it, and this year it's essentially 0. So that's your biggest decline on a year-over-year basis.
componenttext: And I think, Vivek, you also asked about year-over-year. Just recall that last year still had about $55 million or so of Wireless revenue in it, and this year it's essentially 0. So that's your biggest decline on a year-over-year basis.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's correct. Did you have a....
componenttext: That's correct. Did you have a....

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as my follow-on, back to your core business, do think you have the right scale in your Embedded business to take op margins into the 20s? So when I look at the 3 areas within that business, processors, connectivity, microcontrollers, how would you
componenttext: Yes. So as my follow-on, back to your core business, do think you have the right scale in your Embedded business to take op margins into the 20s? So when I look at the 3 areas within that business, processors, connectivity, microcontrollers, how would you rank TI against the best competitor in that segment? And really, I'm trying to understand how you can grow that segment, gain share, improve margins while keeping investments flattish, while all your competitors are all investing in their respective businesses?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Vivek, I'll leave it to you to analyze the competitors. I'll speak to how TI is doing. You may recall that back in late '10 or early '11 time frame, we significantly stepped up our investments in that particular segment in order to accelerate our pr
componenttext: Well, Vivek, I'll leave it to you to analyze the competitors. I'll speak to how TI is doing. You may recall that back in late '10 or early '11 time frame, we significantly stepped up our investments in that particular segment in order to accelerate our product introductions and therefore, begin to accelerate our revenue growth. And if you take a look at what happened over the last, as Dave mentioned in his opening remarks, 9 quarters of sequential -- or continuous year-over-year growth, that strategy has paid off. So those products are really beginning to take. And as you know, those kinds of products tend to have very long shelf lives. So we expect to see more of the same on that. While we took spending down this past year as a result of the restructuring actions we announced this time a year ago, we didn't eliminate them. The amount that we're investing is still quite high, and that's why the operating profit is still not quite where we think entitlement would take us to. So we continue to invest at quite a healthy level, just not at the level that you saw us invest in, in the prior few years. So those combined, high levels of investment, an expanding product portfolio from heavier levels of investment in the prior few years, have all given us very strong growth in that segment and will continue to give us growth. And quite frankly, based upon some of the best-in-class performers that you can look at out there, we have, shall we say, expectations similar to at least as well as those companies are operating.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'd also add, Vivek, if you look at our product portfolio like inside the microcontrollers, we've got 2 architectures there where we'll introduce new products with new interfaces and -- that meet new standards inside of that. A lot of our competi
componenttext: Yes. And I'd also add, Vivek, if you look at our product portfolio like inside the microcontrollers, we've got 2 architectures there where we'll introduce new products with new interfaces and -- that meet new standards inside of that. A lot of our competitors will have half a dozen or a dozen different architectures where they've got to spread their R&D investment over. So we can be very efficient with that. And in addition, if you remember, as part of the Wireless restructuring, we brought over those connectivity products that really already had a pretty significant investment in those Wireless technologies. So we're supporting nearly a dozen different Wireless standards today. And that group is really focused on growing the top line rather than having to develop baseline technologies. So that will -- thanks for that question, Vivek.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: A lot of great questions asked already. My one question is just around the long-term segment goals that you might have. Auto is kind of low double-digits. Personal electronic is almost 30%, although that's coming down. Is the goal really, from a segment d
componenttext: A lot of great questions asked already. My one question is just around the long-term segment goals that you might have. Auto is kind of low double-digits. Personal electronic is almost 30%, although that's coming down. Is the goal really, from a segment diversification standpoint, to continue to increase in particular that auto subcategory and decrease the personal electronics category, say, over the next 2 or 3 years?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim, I don't -- our goal is not necessarily to try to optimize that mix per se. I would say that if you look inside of personal electronics as an example, we'll look for places where we can find sustainable revenue with a differentiated position. And
componenttext: Yes, Jim, I don't -- our goal is not necessarily to try to optimize that mix per se. I would say that if you look inside of personal electronics as an example, we'll look for places where we can find sustainable revenue with a differentiated position. And if you look at some of our largest customers that we sell products into, we'll sell several hundred devices into those customers. And those products could be anywhere from $0.75 down to $0.05. And oftentimes, they may have lives that live from one generation of a product to another. So those are the types of opportunities that we try to look for in a space like comms equipment. Now certainly from an investment -- incremental investment profile, if we had an extra dollar to spend and we had an opportunity to spend that in either industrial or automotive, those products in general just tend to have longer life cycles and better characteristics. So that may see an increase in investment. And then lastly, I'll just add that those 2 markets, I think, have the secular trends that you're well aware of. So we'll benefit from that, as the rest of the industry will. And of course, we hope to benefit disproportionately from those investments. Do you have a follow-on, Jim?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess I'll stick on that topic. So I mean, I guess personal electronics has been coming down, but your view would be it's not really a function of an intentional effort on the part of Texas Instruments. It's just more a function of the other busine
componenttext: Yes, I guess I'll stick on that topic. So I mean, I guess personal electronics has been coming down, but your view would be it's not really a function of an intentional effort on the part of Texas Instruments. It's just more a function of the other businesses that you have just happen to be better long-term growth areas and it's sort of naturally coming down. Is that the right characterization?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, and even more specific than that, I think if you back out legacy Wireless, you'll see that it's actually been fairly stable as a mix. So that change in percentage is more driven by the strategic decision to exit that one portion of the business. So
componenttext: Well, and even more specific than that, I think if you back out legacy Wireless, you'll see that it's actually been fairly stable as a mix. So that change in percentage is more driven by the strategic decision to exit that one portion of the business. So thanks, Jim.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

componenttext: We'll go next to Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: I also want to ask about the end market breakdown that you guys provide. If I look at where you were a year ago, I just -- and there was probably some reclassification, but it looks like industrial went from 24% in 2013 to 31% in 2014 and personal systems
componenttext: I also want to ask about the end market breakdown that you guys provide. If I look at where you were a year ago, I just -- and there was probably some reclassification, but it looks like industrial went from 24% in 2013 to 31% in 2014 and personal systems from 37% to 29%. Those swings seem kind of dramatic. I just want to see if there was some change in the way you're looking at the breakdown.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015

componenttext: Yes, Joe, we've continued to refine our understanding of our customers' end markets. And we've got better tools and software. So if you go out to our web now, you'll actually see 2 years of history that we have out there, as well as the identified sectors that those markets made up. So do you have a follow-on?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, that's all for me.
componenttext: No, that's all for me.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Craig Ellis with B. Riley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Craig Ellis with B. Riley.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kevin, just a follow-up to Vivek's discussion on Embedded Processing and expense control. It's really the flip side of that. Can you talk a little about what you're looking at before you would start to invest more in the business? It's clear you want high
componenttext: Kevin, just a follow-up to Vivek's discussion on Embedded Processing and expense control. It's really the flip side of that. Can you talk a little about what you're looking at before you would start to invest more in the business? It's clear you want higher operating margins than you have now. But what are the things that TI is looking at before it will commit to incremental investment in that business?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Craig, I would say that probably -- we're probably quite a ways off before we even have to entertain a question like that. Our focus for the next few years is managing the total spend inside that business and driving top line growth. And frankly, if
componenttext: Yes, Craig, I would say that probably -- we're probably quite a ways off before we even have to entertain a question like that. Our focus for the next few years is managing the total spend inside that business and driving top line growth. And frankly, if we begin to see top line growth, then begin to net the kind of bottom line results that we can see happening in other players in that space, at that point in time, we might entertain increasing our spending. But not until then.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the follow-up is really taking another swing at something that Chris brought up, which is longer-term growth on a segment basis. At least in my model, calendar '14 was the first year in the last 4 or 5 where Embedded Processing and Analog h
componenttext: Okay. And then the follow-up is really taking another swing at something that Chris brought up, which is longer-term growth on a segment basis. At least in my model, calendar '14 was the first year in the last 4 or 5 where Embedded Processing and Analog had similar growth rates, and they were both double-digits. Just philosophically, as you look at those 2 businesses, which have had very different histories, are there reasons why they should have materially different growth rates going forward? Or given that they're both closer to operating on more optimal levels, should they be fairly similar?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that when you begin to look longer term at the growth rate and the potentials of those businesses, I'd start with what do you believe the semiconductor market will grow at. We have held the position that we think that the semiconductor market
componenttext: Yes, I think that when you begin to look longer term at the growth rate and the potentials of those businesses, I'd start with what do you believe the semiconductor market will grow at. We have held the position that we think that the semiconductor market roughly grows at twice the rate of GDP. There are some that will violently agree with this and some that will violently disagree with that basic assumption. But whatever that assumption is, we think both Analog and Embedded Processing are big enough portions of the market that they will grow in line with that. If you look at those businesses, certainly over the last 5 years, they both have continued to gain share. And we believe that we're continuing to invest, and we've got a lot of room to gain share. In fact, in Analog, we've got 18.3% market share. And inside of Embedded Processing, we've got around 15 percentage points. So lots of headroom to do that. So -- and we've gained probably 30, 40, sometimes more than that, in market share on a given year. We still have to have everyone report before all the final numbers are in, but we're confident that we'll gain share again this year. So Kevin, do you have anything to add to that?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Craig, one thing I'm recommending you maybe take a look at, if you do look at those 2 segments, Analog and Embedded Processing, their quarterly growth rates, I think that was the point you were making, they can vary quite markedly from one another. I
componenttext: Yes. Craig, one thing I'm recommending you maybe take a look at, if you do look at those 2 segments, Analog and Embedded Processing, their quarterly growth rates, I think that was the point you were making, they can vary quite markedly from one another. If you look at the 2 of them on a year-over-year basis, they actually are much more correlated than you might expect. They're both gaining share, as Dave was mentioning, and they're both growing quite nicely on a year-over-year basis. So if you do some measurements for those 2 segments on year-over-year growth rates and compare that back over the last half dozen quarters or so, I think you might be pleasantly surprised to see they grow pretty similar to each other.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Craig. Thanks for that question.
componenttext: Okay, Craig. Thanks for that question.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kevin, as you go into your capital management conference call next week, could you just remind us what your historical philosophy has been on levering the balance sheet to drive shareholder value?
componenttext: Kevin, as you go into your capital management conference call next week, could you just remind us what your historical philosophy has been on levering the balance sheet to drive shareholder value?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Mark, what we talked about on debt, we have debt on the balance sheet today. It will be there until 2023 because that's when the last of the current outstanding bonds matures. And our attitude towards debt is that it will continue to be part of the
componenttext: Well, Mark, what we talked about on debt, we have debt on the balance sheet today. It will be there until 2023 because that's when the last of the current outstanding bonds matures. And our attitude towards debt is that it will continue to be part of the balance sheet when the economics makes sense. And for us, that economics making sense means that if we can borrow at interest rates that we perceive to be below what we expect our inflation rates to be, or correspondingly at less than our dividend yield, then we think that's probably a pretty good deal on behalf our shareholders. And so that will be the kind of parameters that we look at as we continue to decide how much debt to carry on the balance sheet and as bonds mature going forward. We do actually have $1 billion of debt maturing. In 2015, we have $250 million maturing in April and $750 million maturing in August of 2015.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow-on, Mark?
componenttext: Do you have a follow-on, Mark?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we -- so the Analog business, operating margins are about 2,000 basis points higher than the Embedded. As we think about the potential profitability of the Embedded business, is there -- are there structural reasons why Embedded profitability coul
componenttext: Yes. As we -- so the Analog business, operating margins are about 2,000 basis points higher than the Embedded. As we think about the potential profitability of the Embedded business, is there -- are there structural reasons why Embedded profitability could not equal the Analog profitability longer term?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mark, I think the simple answer in my mind is it's difficult for us to find evidence of somebody in the marketplace, outside of TI, who's been able to perform at those kind of levels. I think the economics are such that it will be very attractive. It's go
componenttext: Mark, I think the simple answer in my mind is it's difficult for us to find evidence of somebody in the marketplace, outside of TI, who's been able to perform at those kind of levels. I think the economics are such that it will be very attractive. It's going to be a great place to us for be in. But it probably doesn't quite get up to par on what you see in Analog. I think Analog is quite unique in what it can produce for companies and for shareholders who own those companies like we do.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great. Thanks, Mark.
componenttext: That's great. Thanks, Mark.

componenttext: Just a question again on gross margin and what the possible on headroom is. I guess if you look at the Embedded business, you're up to 17%. But if you look at some of the well-run peers in that space, they're doing sort of mid-20s. Do you have a follow-on?

componenttext: Great, okay. I do, yes. And then just relative to the inventory, certainly, some of it is structural, as you indicated. But is any of the rise in inventory related to your perception that June could be sort of a little bit better than seasonal quarter?

componenttextpreview: Tim, I would say that it's probably too early for us to call the entire second quarter. Right now, we're focused on first quarter. So the inventory that we've got staged today is designed to support our first quarter needs. And then as we adjust our facto
componenttext: Tim, I would say that it's probably too early for us to call the entire second quarter. Right now, we're focused on first quarter. So the inventory that we've got staged today is designed to support our first quarter needs. And then as we adjust our factory loadings in first quarter, that inventory that we build will be designed to start to deal with our second quarter needs. And as I mentioned earlier, we expect we will be ramping up our factories as we go through first quarter in support of second quarter. And when we get to the end of the quarter, we'll find out how much inventory we're holding at that point in time.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess if I could dig deep into some of the results that you've reported and maybe some of the outlook that you might have by sort of key markets out there. I think investors are interested to hear what you're seeing in the PC and server power markets as
componenttext: I guess if I could dig deep into some of the results that you've reported and maybe some of the outlook that you might have by sort of key markets out there. I think investors are interested to hear what you're seeing in the PC and server power markets as well as maybe the disk drive markets, and if you could offer some color on what you're seeing in the communications market as well. I think those are maybe not that overly material to the TI story, but they are to investors in general.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, Doug. Well, I can -- let me share some end-market trends that we see. And I think that, that may address some of those issues, maybe not down at the level that you're quite asking. So I think you were talking about PCs, and those would fall into our
componenttext: Okay, Doug. Well, I can -- let me share some end-market trends that we see. And I think that, that may address some of those issues, maybe not down at the level that you're quite asking. So I think you were talking about PCs, and those would fall into our personal electronics products. Those were -- on a year-on-year basis, they were up despite the declines that Kevin had mentioned earlier in legacy Wireless. And that growth rate was led by mobile phones. If you look at industrial -- and I want to point out, when we talk about industrial, we've been very intentional about how to measure that. And it's different than when investors talk about the industrial market. And the sectors, we've got a dozen sectors that make up industrial. And they include things like factory automation and control, medical, health care/fitness, building automation, smart grid, motor drives, displays, those types of things. The full list is out on our website. And we've seen that, that was up, led by medical and health care/fitness. Appliance, factory automation and smart grid were also up from a year ago. Comms equipment was up due to Wireless infrastructure. And then enterprise systems were up primarily due to projectors. So with that, do you have a follow-on?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I guess for my follow-on, just what are you seeing in terms of any shift in the competitive landscape? I know investors are somewhat concerned over what we're seeing in China from an investment standpoint. Is there anything in your markets that you
componenttext: Great. I guess for my follow-on, just what are you seeing in terms of any shift in the competitive landscape? I know investors are somewhat concerned over what we're seeing in China from an investment standpoint. Is there anything in your markets that you're seeing that would point to any change in the competitive landscape?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 26, 2015
componenttextpreview: You know, Doug, as it relates to China in particular, because I think you mentioned that there, we've been in China for a very long time now. We have over -- I think, over a dozen sales and R&D sites there. We have both a wafer fabrication facility and an
componenttext: You know, Doug, as it relates to China in particular, because I think you mentioned that there, we've been in China for a very long time now. We have over -- I think, over a dozen sales and R&D sites there. We have both a wafer fabrication facility and an assembly test site there. In addition, we have thousands of customers buying thousands of parts, and consequently, we're becoming a very important supplier to a large number of Chinese companies across a very diverse set of markets. So we see China continuing to be a great opportunity for TI regardless of any of the competitive environment out there. Our goal is to operate in China just like we do in the rest of the world, which is to make ourselves an integral part of their success and an indispensable supplier. And we've got a great, how do I say this, a long way -- we're a long way into that already, and we feel pretty good about our position.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day. Welcome to the Texas Instruments 1Q '15 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day. Welcome to the Texas Instruments 1Q '15 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2015 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2015 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.
For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations on our website at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through TI's website. A replay will be available through the web.
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI strolls to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the notice regarding forward-looking statements contained in the earnings release published today, as well as TI's most recent SEC filings for a more complete description.
Revenue growth of 6% from a year ago was within the range of expectations we provided in January. Automotive and industrial markets were strong as we expected they would be. However, revenue was in the bottom half of the range for 2 reasons: First, was weak demand in the last month of the quarter in our personal electronics market, particularly PCs and in our communications market, particularly Wireless infrastructure equipment. We believe these market specific issues were due to delay of investments by carriers and capacity upgrades for wireless infrastructure equipment and a weaker-than-expected refresh cycle for Windows XP.
The second reason a steep decline in the current exchange rate for the euro relative to the U.S. dollar. The euro dropped about 10% during the quarter and even though only about 5% of TI's revenues transacted in euros, it was a sharp enough drop that it negatively impacted our revenue by about $20 million more than we had anticipated.
Even with these pockets of weaknesses, our core business of Analog and Embedded Processing turned in their seventh and 10th consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth, respectively. Combined, these businesses grew 9% every were 86% of our total revenue.
Earnings per share were $0.61, reflecting our continued attention to cost controls. Although the vast majority of our revenue was transacted in U,S. dollar, ROE negatively impacted revenues by $20 million which translated to only about $5 million of impact to earnings and therefore, cash flow. This is due to a partial natural hedge against negative currency fluctuations due to our non-U.S.-based operations. It's nice to have a position -- to be in this when you have almost 90% of our revenue comes outside of the U.S.
With that, as a backdrop, Kevin and I will move on with our report on business performance that we believe continues to represent the ongoing strength of TI's business model.
In the first quarter, our cash flow from operations was $609 million. We believe that free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term. Free cash flow for the trailing 12-month period was $3.6 billion, up 17% from the year ago.
Free cash flow was 27% of consistent with our targeted range of 20% to 30% of revenue. This is a 2-percentage-point improvement from a year ago period and we believe reflects our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy, which includes our growing 300-millimeter output and the opportunistic purchases of assets ahead of demand.
We also believe that free cash flow will be valued only if its returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business.
For the trailing 12-month period, we returned $4.1 billion of cash to investors through a combination of stock repurchases and dividends.
In the first quarter, TI revenue grew 6% from a year ago with growth in both Analog and Embedded Processing. Analog revenue grew 11% from a year ago, primarily due to Power Management and High Volume Analog & Logic. Silicon Valley Analog and High Performance Analog also grew. As we mentioned earlier, this is the seventh quarter of year-over-year growth for Analog.
Embedded Processing revenue grew 2% from a year ago due to microcontrollers and connectivity. Processor revenue declined, which is impacted by the weakness in Wireless infrastructure. And again as I mentioned earlier, this is the 10th consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth for Embedded Processing.
In our Other segment, revenue declined 10% a year ago primarily due to custom ASIC products, which also are heavy in Wireless infrastructure as well as DLP products.
In distribution, resales increased 11% from a year ago. Weeks of inventory remained at historically low levels of just under 4.5 weeks, which is a decrease by more than a week from a year ago and is even with the fourth quarter. This level has decreased over the past few years because we have structurally changed how our inventory in the distribution channel with our consignment program.
From an end-market perspective versus a year ago, automotive grew, with most sectors inside this market, growing at double sector rates. Industrial had broad-based growth. Personal electronics group, although growth PCs was lower than we expected. Communications equipment declined due to Wireless infrastructure and enterprise systems group.
Kevin will now review profitability, capital management and our outlook.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $1.82 billion or 57.7% of revenue. Gross profit increased to 13% from the year-ago quarter and gross margin was up almost 4 points. Gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $1.82 billion or 57.7% of revenue. Gross profit increased to 13% from the year-ago quarter and gross margin was up almost 4 points. Gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased factory loadings and benefits from our efficient manufacturing strategy as we build more Analog chips on 300-millimeter wafers.
Moving to operating expenses. Combined R&D and SG&A expenses of $777 million were down $68 million from the year ago. The decline primarily reflects the targeted reductions in Embedded Processing in Japan that were previously announced. As we said, that restructuring was essentially complete at the end of last year.
Acquisition charges were $83 million, almost all of which with the ongoing of the amortization of intangibles, which is noncash expense. Operating profit was $958 million or 30.4% of revenue. Operating profit was up 39% in the year ago quarter. Operating margin for Analog was 35.4%. Operating margin for Embedded Processing was 18.3%, more than doubling from a year ago, as we executed our restructuring plan to better align resources with the opportunities we are pursuing an important for growth.
Net income in the first quarter was $656 million or $0.61 per share.
Let me now comment on our capital management results, starting with our cash generation. Cash flow from operations was $609 million in the quarter. Inventory days were 124, about 3 days more than planned due to revenue coming in at the bottom half of our expectations. Capital expenditures were $123 million in the quarter.
On a trailing 12-month basis, cash flow operations was $4.04 billion, up 16% from the same period a year ago. Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $431 million or 3% of revenue. As a reminder, our long-term expectations for capital expenditures were to be about 4% of revenue, which includes our $8 billion 300-millimeter Analog plan discussed our recent capital mentioned call.
Free cash flow in the past 12 months was $3.61 billion or 27% of revenue. Free cash flow was 17% higher than a year ago. As we said, we believe free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long-term and will be valued only if it is returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business. As we've noted, our intent is to return 100% of our free cash flow, plus any proceeds we receive from the exercise of equity compensation minus net debt retirement.
In the first quarter, TI paid $356 million in dividend and repurchased $670 million of our stock for a total return of $1.03 billion. Total cash returned in the past 12 months was $4.14 billion.
Outstanding share count was reduced by 3.2% over the past 12 months and by 39% since the beginning of 2005. These returns demonstrate our confidence in TI's business model and our commitment to return excess cash our shareholders.
Fundamental to our commitment to return cash are our cash management and tax practices. We ended the first quarter with $3.30 billion of cash and short-term investments. TI's U.S. entities owned 80% -- 82% of our cash. Because our cash is largely onshore, it is readily available for a variety of uses, including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock.
TI orders in the quarter were $3.21 billion, up 5% from a year ago.
Turning to our outlook. We expect TI revenue in the range of $3.12 billion to $3.38 billion in the second quarter. This represents continuing weakness in our communications equipment and personal electronics markets, particularly for Wireless infrastructure and PCs, respectively. We also do not expect a near-term rebound in foreign currency exchange rates.
We expect second quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $0.60 to $0.70. Acquisition charges, which are our noncash amortization charges, will remain about even and hold at about $80 million to $85 million per quarter for the next 5 years.
Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate for 2015 remains about 30%, and this is the tax rate your should use for the second quarter and for the year.
In summary, we believe that the first quarter demonstrates the strength of TI's business model. While we are not immune to demand and currency changes, their effects are softened by the diversity of our portfolio and our markets.
With that, let me turn it back to Dave.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin. Operator, you can now open the lines up for questions. [Operator Instructions]
componenttext: Thanks, Kevin. Operator, you can now open the lines up for questions. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we go first to Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we go first to Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's so much controversy in the industry today about whether the industry is as cyclical as it used to be, less so, et cetera. When I look at your year-over-year growth rates, the June quarter represents the first time you've had a year-over-year decli
componenttext: There's so much controversy in the industry today about whether the industry is as cyclical as it used to be, less so, et cetera. When I look at your year-over-year growth rates, the June quarter represents the first time you've had a year-over-year decline at the midpoint of your guidance in a long time. How do you think about that in the context of an industry where many are arguing that we're not cyclical anymore?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim. We're, as you know, we've been pretty guarded at trying to predict the cycle. It's not something obviously, that we can control. We really just go to what we can look at than what we can measure. So as you kind of tick you through the things tha
componenttext: Yes, Jim. We're, as you know, we've been pretty guarded at trying to predict the cycle. It's not something obviously, that we can control. We really just go to what we can look at than what we can measure. So as you kind of tick you through the things that you typically look at from a cyclical standpoint, we look at channel inventories are down a week from a year ago, they're lean at just under[ph] 4.5 weeks. Lead times are remaining consistent, our cancellations and reschedules are very low. In addition, we're continuing to deliver on time and very consistently with that. So we've got a couple of pockets of weaker-than-expected demand as we talk about specifically in Wireless infrastructure and PCs. And at the same time, we're seeing automotive and infrastructure continuing to be strong as we expect. So that's what we know, that's what we can see. The debates will continue on, on how cyclical our industry will be or won't be.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I might just add that we do have several significant advantages, the combination of which we believe it's pretty difficult for anybody of to replicate and it helps us deal with any notion of cyclicality or non cyclicality. And those advantages include tha
componenttext: I might just add that we do have several significant advantages, the combination of which we believe it's pretty difficult for anybody of to replicate and it helps us deal with any notion of cyclicality or non cyclicality. And those advantages include that we've got the broadest portfolio in the industry, which really means engineered design work by looking at us first. We enjoy very low cost manufacturing for all the reasons that you've heard us talk about for the last few years, including our 300-millimeter wafer fabs. We've got the broader sales channel, in fact, probably 3x to 4x larger than our nearest competitor. And we play in an [indiscernible] diverse set of markets with long-live products that enjoy significant cash return for our shareholders in the long time. So we think that's really what's important to deal with. Whatever will happen in market cycles and just really make sure that we are a lot more competitive advantaged than everybody else.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You have a follow-up, Jim?
componenttext: You have a follow-up, Jim?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That was helpful. Obviously, you're talking about weakness in PCs and comps. In the industrial segment, we're starting to see some negative news flow from the customers. Do you see pockets of weakness but there's just other pockets of strength that are of
componenttext: That was helpful. Obviously, you're talking about weakness in PCs and comps. In the industrial segment, we're starting to see some negative news flow from the customers. Do you see pockets of weakness but there's just other pockets of strength that are offsetting those industrial customers that maybe weak? Because I know it's a very broad base customer base. Or do you just not see any weakness in that segment?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim. I'll just say that like you were hinting to, it's very broad-based. So we service over 100,000 customers, most of those will reside in industrial. And again, I think, it's probably helpful for me to just go through, and when we say industrial, i
componenttext: Yes, Jim. I'll just say that like you were hinting to, it's very broad-based. So we service over 100,000 customers, most of those will reside in industrial. And again, I think, it's probably helpful for me to just go through, and when we say industrial, it means something different than I think the investment definition of industrial. So it'll include things like factory automation and control and medical, healthcare, fitness products, building automation, smart grid, energy test equipment, motor drives, avionics, appliances and other segments. So again very, very broad. Of course, we'll always see pockets of strength and weaknesses. But overall, that industrial is doing well. We've seen growth in almost all of those -- all those sectors that I described. Thank you. We'll go to the next caller, please.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go now to Chris Donnelly with Citi.
componenttext: And we'll go now to Chris Donnelly with Citi.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You did a good job of outlining the relative areas of weakness in Q1 from currency and common PC. Can you just give us what you think would be a bigger drag in company sales from PC versus communications? And then do you guys expect a negative impact from
componenttext: You did a good job of outlining the relative areas of weakness in Q1 from currency and common PC. Can you just give us what you think would be a bigger drag in company sales from PC versus communications? And then do you guys expect a negative impact from currency in Q2 as well? And if you could give us the magnitude of that negative impact.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the one that's pretty straightforward to identify because it's really just math walking through the numbers is that on a year-on-year basis, we'll probably see about a $50 million headwind due to currency exchange rates. And obviously, we're not a
componenttext: Yes. So the one that's pretty straightforward to identify because it's really just math walking through the numbers is that on a year-on-year basis, we'll probably see about a $50 million headwind due to currency exchange rates. And obviously, we're not assuming that we see a rebound in those rates. We'll still see and expect to see the weakness in PCs and Wireless infrastructure. And just kind of the balance of the business, as you know, there's always puts and takes. As an example, second quarter a year ago, DLP was very strong. If you remember, it was benefiting from several world events, one of them like the World Cup, that won't repeat. So that'll be weaker than it was a year ago and will continue for the rest of the year. But inside of the bucket, we'll continue to have puts and takes. Do you have a -- any other comment that I just made on that, although we see those pockets of weakness, if you look at the core businesses of Analog and Embedded, we do believe that those will continue to perform well. Do you have a follow-up, Chris?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Actually just a couple of clarifications. So do you expect that PC or the Wireless infrastructure to have a bigger drag on your revenue in Q2? And then it almost seems like -- do we need the dollar to weaken again for that impact to go away? i.e, if
componenttext: Yes. Actually just a couple of clarifications. So do you expect that PC or the Wireless infrastructure to have a bigger drag on your revenue in Q2? And then it almost seems like -- do we need the dollar to weaken again for that impact to go away? i.e, if the dollar remains strong, is that going to be a negative impact for you guys every quarter?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, I'm going to say that we probably don't have any detail to tell you whether Wireless infrastructure or PC, we just don't expect them to be recovering in the second quarter. As it relates to ROE, certainly with -- if we take a look at just the euro
componenttext: Chris, I'm going to say that we probably don't have any detail to tell you whether Wireless infrastructure or PC, we just don't expect them to be recovering in the second quarter. As it relates to ROE, certainly with -- if we take a look at just the euro alone versus a year ago, it's down 23%. The yen is down 14%. We've roughly average about 5% of our revenue in euros and around 3% in yen. So clearly with that kind of weakness, on a year-over-year compare, that's going to continue to be an issue that's just going to affect that kind of math. It doesn't affect our ability to sell in those markets. We'll continue to remain very competitive in those spaces as we enjoy a lot of design wins. But unless the ROE moves back and the dollar weakens, then certainly with that kind of dramatic decline in those 2 major currencies, that will be, at least on the fringes, a year-over-year compare headwind for us.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add to that, that like we saw in the first quarter where we had an impact of about $20 million because of the natural hedging, we've had an impact to operating profit and free cash flows really about $5 million. So fairly small on that front
componenttext: And I'll just add to that, that like we saw in the first quarter where we had an impact of about $20 million because of the natural hedging, we've had an impact to operating profit and free cash flows really about $5 million. So fairly small on that front. Okay. Thanks, Chris. We'll move on to the next caller, please.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We now go to John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We now go to John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, I don't want to beat a dead horse. But just on the outlook, when I look at the Q1, it looks like you guys are only missing the midpoint of your guide by about $50 million and you explained $20 million of that on currency. As I go to Q2 if I just
componenttext: I guess, I don't want to beat a dead horse. But just on the outlook, when I look at the Q1, it looks like you guys are only missing the midpoint of your guide by about $50 million and you explained $20 million of that on currency. As I go to Q2 if I just anchor again seasonality, your kind of missing it by $150 million to $200 million. And I guess, sequentially, are you expecting any kind of headwinds from currency? I understand the year-over-year compare, I'm kind of trying to figure out the sequential compare. And when I look at PCs plus comp infrastructure, help me understand the percent of the business that represents, I'm thinking around 15, maybe I'm wrong with that. I guess, I'm trying to get a sense as to why you think that the missing Q2 is going to be so much larger in those 2 buckets than the miss Q1?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, let me -- I'll take the first part of the question then Kevin can add in, if he'd like to. The first, if you look at our PC revenues as a percentage of our total is around 5%. If you were thinking hard drives into that, that will add a few poin
componenttext: Yes, John, let me -- I'll take the first part of the question then Kevin can add in, if he'd like to. The first, if you look at our PC revenues as a percentage of our total is around 5%. If you were thinking hard drives into that, that will add a few points. So you'll be just under 10% in upper single-digits. If you look at Wireless infrastructure, last year, it was about 10% of our revenues. So obviously, combined there, you're in the midteens. So that will give you an idea of what that impact is. Again, as Kevin kind of walk through the math of like the euro as an example last year, 18% of our revenue was done in Europe, about 1/3 of that, so 5%, 6% has transacted in the euro and again sequentially. I don't know if you have additional comments on the impact to the euro?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, just 1Q to 2Q, I think, is what you're trying to ask whether, John. The average ROE that we experienced on our billing in 1Q is about for the euro was about 1.13. And for the planning purposes, we're using 1.06 going into 2Q. So there's goin
componenttext: Yes. I think, just 1Q to 2Q, I think, is what you're trying to ask whether, John. The average ROE that we experienced on our billing in 1Q is about for the euro was about 1.13. And for the planning purposes, we're using 1.06 going into 2Q. So there's going to be a little bit over a quarter-over-quarter ROE impact just from that standpoint as it relates to the euro. Right now we're anticipating the yen to be flat.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow-up, John?
componenttext: Do you have a follow-up, John?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. And I know because of the comp section specifically, you were doing a little bit of pruning with the product portfolio. And I'm wondering if any of the pruning that you've done is being reflected in kind of sequentially or year-over-year growth
componenttext: Yes, I do. And I know because of the comp section specifically, you were doing a little bit of pruning with the product portfolio. And I'm wondering if any of the pruning that you've done is being reflected in kind of sequentially or year-over-year growth rate.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't believe that is a factor, John. I think if you look at the impact the Wireless infrastructure has, we sell more Analog product than we do Embedded or the custom ASIC products. So we actually hit both Analog, Embedded and Other. Of course, yo
componenttext: Yes, we don't believe that is a factor, John. I think if you look at the impact the Wireless infrastructure has, we sell more Analog product than we do Embedded or the custom ASIC products. So we actually hit both Analog, Embedded and Other. Of course, you could see the impact more significantly in Embedded because and Other because it's a higher percentage of that revenue. But again, we've got a good position really across most of the major OEMs there. And so what we're seeing is really a change in shipments and demand. So thanks, John. And we'll go to the next caller, please

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
