componenttext: We go now to Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, I was wondering if you can give us a handle on where you see OpEx rolling next quarter given the revenue short fall?
componenttext: First, I was wondering if you can give us a handle on where you see OpEx rolling next quarter given the revenue short fall?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Stacy, OpEx was about[ph] as expected fourth quarter to first quarter. And recall that in the fourth quarter, we typically are down a bit on the OpEx because of the seasonality from holidays and so on. And the absence of those seasonality, to holiday
componenttext: Yes. Stacy, OpEx was about[ph] as expected fourth quarter to first quarter. And recall that in the fourth quarter, we typically are down a bit on the OpEx because of the seasonality from holidays and so on. And the absence of those seasonality, to holidays in the first quarter, along with our annual paying benefit increases, traditionally drives our OpEx up quarter-over-quarter. Those paying benefit increases taken since February since we're only 2 months inside the OpEx right now in first quarter. So we'll have the full 3 months. So you'll see just a very slight increase going into the second quarter.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. For my follow-up, again on currency, I know you guys are pointing to sort of direct translation impact. We've got other players who have pointed to demand destruction concurrency. I was wondering if you could give us your point of view and what yo
componenttext: Got it. For my follow-up, again on currency, I know you guys are pointing to sort of direct translation impact. We've got other players who have pointed to demand destruction concurrency. I was wondering if you could give us your point of view and what you're seeing more broadly in the market, not just for your revenues but also for your customers. Are you seeing any sort of broad-based TAM destruction because of the currency movements that we have?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Stacy, no, we've talked about that, but there's no way for us to really point to something and demonstrate evidence that, that's actually occurring, given the entire tends to price in dollars for the preponderance of what's being shipped, there's not a lo
componenttext: Stacy, no, we've talked about that, but there's no way for us to really point to something and demonstrate evidence that, that's actually occurring, given the entire tends to price in dollars for the preponderance of what's being shipped, there's not a lot of other alternatives that would seem for customers in a defense standpoint. But that's not to say there might not be a second order knock-on effect like you're alluding to it. And we just don't see any way that we can quantify that with any confidence.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And there's always pluses and minuses with the currencies. It's really impossible for us to quantify that. Okay. Thank you, Stacy. We'll go to the next caller, please.
componenttext: And there's always pluses and minuses with the currencies. It's really impossible for us to quantify that. Okay. Thank you, Stacy. We'll go to the next caller, please.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We go now to Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We go now to Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Given the timing of when you started to see the weakness that you talked about in the March quarter and just given the softer-than-seasonal 2Q outlook, would you have to ratchet down your wafer fab manufacturing activity or wafer starts here in Q2?
componenttext: Given the timing of when you started to see the weakness that you talked about in the March quarter and just given the softer-than-seasonal 2Q outlook, would you have to ratchet down your wafer fab manufacturing activity or wafer starts here in Q2?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Harlan, yes, we will be lighting up the wafer starts in Q2. I would caution you though that pulling back on the wafer starts doesn't necessarily mean that will have a direct impact on our inventory as a work in progress in 1Q will become finished goods in
componenttext: Harlan, yes, we will be lighting up the wafer starts in Q2. I would caution you though that pulling back on the wafer starts doesn't necessarily mean that will have a direct impact on our inventory as a work in progress in 1Q will become finished goods in 2Q. So we would expect our inventory probably goes up a bit in 2Q even though will pull back on the wafer starts a little bit.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Analog was up nicely 10%[ph] year-over-year, despite the headwinds. Embedded was up only 2%, which is a pretty significant deceleration year-over-year versus the prior quarter. I'm assuming that the Embedded weakness was primarily driven by
componenttext: Okay. And then Analog was up nicely 10%[ph] year-over-year, despite the headwinds. Embedded was up only 2%, which is a pretty significant deceleration year-over-year versus the prior quarter. I'm assuming that the Embedded weakness was primarily driven by DSPs given the muted Wireless infrastructure spending environment?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That -- it's correct. It was impacted by the Wireless infrastructure. And in fact, if you look at the business outside of Embedded, we had good growth in microcontrollers and connectivity, but the processors were down for the exact reason that, that you i
componenttext: That -- it's correct. It was impacted by the Wireless infrastructure. And in fact, if you look at the business outside of Embedded, we had good growth in microcontrollers and connectivity, but the processors were down for the exact reason that, that you identified now. So okay. Thank you, Harlan. We'll go to the next caller, please.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We now go to Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We now go to Ross Seymore from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other avenue to get off the broad-based demand trends, are you seeing any sort of demand patterns from your distributor customers relative to the OEM customers? Are they getting any more nervous or excited and willing to carry inventory? I realized th
componenttext: One other avenue to get off the broad-based demand trends, are you seeing any sort of demand patterns from your distributor customers relative to the OEM customers? Are they getting any more nervous or excited and willing to carry inventory? I realized the weeks inventory you gave before, but from a bookings perspective, any color would be helpful.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think I'll just offer on that, Ross, is that on a year-over-year basis, bookings were up 5%. 60% of our revenue does go through [indiscernible]. So clearly, we're seeing a lot of bookings coming through the Disney Channel. The inventory levels they're c
componenttext: I think I'll just offer on that, Ross, is that on a year-over-year basis, bookings were up 5%. 60% of our revenue does go through [indiscernible]. So clearly, we're seeing a lot of bookings coming through the Disney Channel. The inventory levels they're carrying are about 4.5 weeks, which is down about a week from a year ago, so they continue to carry lean loans. And I think largely because they know that we carry inventory and consignments, we also maintained very short lead times as we have for a number of years now. And so their ability to get to inventory very quickly is pretty reliable for them when they order with us. So I don't -- from those kinds of elements inside that space, there's no rule again, science that says, geez, there's demand destruction going on because our ROE, they can't really do anything there, right?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'd add, Ross, that if you look at our resales overall, that was very consistent with our combined Analog and Embedded sales. So it was in the upper single digits, very close to the same number. You have a follow-on, Ross?
componenttext: And I'd add, Ross, that if you look at our resales overall, that was very consistent with our combined Analog and Embedded sales. So it was in the upper single digits, very close to the same number. You have a follow-on, Ross?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, quick 1 just to make sure I have all the moving parts. It sounds like in answer to a prior question, Kevin, you said OpEx will be up a little. You also said that utilization will be down. It seems like putting that together with your earnings guidanc
componenttext: Yes, quick 1 just to make sure I have all the moving parts. It sounds like in answer to a prior question, Kevin, you said OpEx will be up a little. You also said that utilization will be down. It seems like putting that together with your earnings guidance that implies that gross margin is going to be down a bit sequentially. Is that, 1, is that math directionally correct? 2, is that cost of the gross margin simply utilization or is there some mix effect that I also need to appreciate?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You might be missing the mix effect, Ross. I don't expect much change in margin.
componenttext: You might be missing the mix effect, Ross. I don't expect much change in margin.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you for that question, Ross. We'll go to the next caller, please.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you for that question, Ross. We'll go to the next caller, please.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We go now to Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We go now to Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the markets that you're seeing weakness in PCs in one of those infrastructure. Do you think there is an inventory or demand problem? And I guess, what is -- we've seen other suppliers in the PC talk about a return to sort of better-than-seasonal second
componenttext: In the markets that you're seeing weakness in PCs in one of those infrastructure. Do you think there is an inventory or demand problem? And I guess, what is -- we've seen other suppliers in the PC talk about a return to sort of better-than-seasonal second half as you get back the correction, where do you stand on that?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Joe, I just say first of all, that the Wireless infrastructure market is -- has notoriously been very choppy as you look at demand over the number of years. So there's usually a significant build as OEMs are planning to bid for the operators spend, and th
componenttext: Joe, I just say first of all, that the Wireless infrastructure market is -- has notoriously been very choppy as you look at demand over the number of years. So there's usually a significant build as OEMs are planning to bid for the operators spend, and then it typically surprises us and there's an overbuild that occurs. So 1 kind that begets the other. We think that the Wireless infrastructure market obviously, long term is a good market for us and we've got a good position in. And just as the numbers come down, they'll come up again 1 day. On the PC side, that's only a couple of percent of our revenues. I don't think we really have any unique insight on that. We believe that, that weakness is due to the inventory that's created because there wasn't as much demand in the XP refresh cycle. But really nothing, nothing beyond that. And we'll see how the rest of this quarter goes before we start making predictions on the back half. I'll just take it 1 quarter at a time. So you have a follow-on?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I guess, specifically, I think  John had mentioned the restructuring that you did, but just specifically, you did cutback on R&D in macro base stations. And I'm wondering if there's anything directly that would point to that decision versus reven
componenttext: Yes. And I guess, specifically, I think  John had mentioned the restructuring that you did, but just specifically, you did cutback on R&D in macro base stations. And I'm wondering if there's anything directly that would point to that decision versus revenues hours are separate from that?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, I think definitely, when we look at those markets, they're very long tailed in product cycles. We continue to make investments, they're just not at the same rates that we were making 5 and 10 years ago. And that's not unlike what we've done in
componenttext: Yes. Again, I think definitely, when we look at those markets, they're very long tailed in product cycles. We continue to make investments, they're just not at the same rates that we were making 5 and 10 years ago. And that's not unlike what we've done in other markets as they've begun to mature. So there's other areas of wireless infrastructure that looks like it will be very promising growth, like small cells, and we continue to invest at very high levels there while we have really high level today. So we just believe that we've got to throttle that investment based on the opportunity overall. So thanks for that question.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, Kevin, you said inventories are going to be up, I think, again you said in June despite loadings being down. I guess, my question is, what do you think is sort of the -- now that you've had a couple quarters to think about the mix,
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, Kevin, you said inventories are going to be up, I think, again you said in June despite loadings being down. I guess, my question is, what do you think is sort of the -- now that you've had a couple quarters to think about the mix, what do you think is the right normalized level of inventory? And do you think that we're going to come back down to start of that more normalized levels during the back half of the year?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tim. We are going to use 2015 to really kind of monitor the effect of all the changes we've been doing with the portfolio and with our operations to model what we think is a more appropriate overall level of the average inventories to carry. What we
componenttext: Yes, Tim. We are going to use 2015 to really kind of monitor the effect of all the changes we've been doing with the portfolio and with our operations to model what we think is a more appropriate overall level of the average inventories to carry. What we did conclude was that the prior model, which has worked for us quite well of 105 to 115 days, while is appropriate given the mix that we have, but clearly as we move to more and more consignment, as we move to keeping lead times very short across the vast abundance of our portfolio, that dictates that we've got to carry more inventory than we have in the past. And so what we'll use in 2015 to run various tests on what the appropriate level of inventories are to beat the service metrics and that our customers have come to expect from us. And probably by the time we get too early next year when we do our capital mentioned update, we'll go ahead and articulate a new model for that time.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Great. Tim, thank you. We'll go to the next caller, please.

Are you guys just being conservative in anticipation of maybe a fallout in some of your other end markets? Or am I just not fully incorporating other parts of the equation here?

componenttext: So I'll go ahead and just -- I think Dave, the last time I'll give it a try. There are several moving parts going on. If you look at 2Q and the rest compares on a year-over-year basis, so just the ROE alone impacts us at about $50 million from a year-over-year compare for growth rate. Then you go beyond that and you've got continuing weakness in Wireless infrastructure and PCs and then you've also got the absence of the benefit, the DLP had a year ago, which was meaningful due to the World Cup and other -- and large sporting events. In fact, we saw some of the that impact the DLP already occurred in the first quarter. As we mentioned, DLP was down quite a bit in the first quarter. So you got those kinds of headwinds, ROE, Wireless infrastructure, PC and the DLP. And then we've got the rest of the portfolio basically doing fine, consistent with what we've seen in the economy for the last few quarters.

componenttext: Yes. I just wanted to ask you about M&A. There's been a lot of activity over the last year. When I think about TI, M&A has certainly been part of your DNA over the last 15 years, can you just talk about how you're thinking about M&A specifically in this environment, relative to buying back your own stock?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Romit, the -- our M&A posture hasn't changed at all. Meaning, that the most important thing was that to the extent that we considered an acquisition, there's got to be something in our consistent with our portfolio interest and something that we can
componenttext: Yes, Romit, the -- our M&A posture hasn't changed at all. Meaning, that the most important thing was that to the extent that we considered an acquisition, there's got to be something in our consistent with our portfolio interest and something that we can generate long-term returns on and therefore, excess free cash flow for our shareholders. If that kind of passes the strategy test, then it's got to pass the numbers test. And frankly, we have a hard time with many of the companies that are out there to be making those kind of numbers work. Contrast that to National back in 2011, at a time when all semiconductor stock prices were considerably lower, you can certainly see in retrospect that was a very good return for our shareholders. So we tend to be very disciplined on that, we'll continue to be very disciplined on that. Buying back our own shares right now, especially as long as they trade before the intrinsic value of the companies also continues to be a good return for shareholders, especially from a free cash flow perspective.

componenttext: Kevin, you mentioned as you look at the portfolio the rest of the business is doing fine outside of the factors that you highlighted. If you go back to history and look at such a sharp deceleration -- destruction, let's use that word, and on the exchange rate, when do you expect that to manifest itself in other parts of the business? So for instance, the distributors in Europe and other pieces who got that semis go into, for instance, in industrials and autos. What does past currency issues tell us on that front? And then I have a quick follow-up.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I wish I had some clever insight on that, but I'm afraid I don't from an experience standpoint. I actually do not recall that my experience in this capacity, and I've been in this world for a very long time now, seeing currencies drop this sharply in
componenttext: Yes. I wish I had some clever insight on that, but I'm afraid I don't from an experience standpoint. I actually do not recall that my experience in this capacity, and I've been in this world for a very long time now, seeing currencies drop this sharply in this short period of time. So I have no history from which to try to get a reference point to answer your question like that. I think, we're just all going to have to wait and see where this takes us. I think, the encouraging part is, especially in industrial and automotive, is that the silicon content going to those spaces continues to increase year-over-year. And so despite ROE impacts, I don't think that's going to slow down the silicon content increase on those spaces. And frankly, if you look at the pricing of those end equipment, the cost of a $0.50 Analog chip going to $0.55 is pretty irrelevant to an automotive customer, I think. So if -- if you look at the more macro effects and especially where we see growth from semiconductors and auto and industrial, it doesn't seem likely that we would see a sharp impact in demand cause just because of ROE. There may be other factors that may lead to that kind of difference.

componenttext: Yes, Doug. On the utilization, we typically we just talk about that as something drastic has occurred. So I won't go into that right now. I will remind you on the Capital Management call, I did discuss for our fab in particular, that we have the majority of the equipment necessary to support the buildout of that factory to a $5 billion revenue level. But at the same time, we're also converting DM6[ph] from an exclusive use by Embedded Processing to also be able to use by Analog and that will add another $3 billion of 300-millimeter Analog capacity in DM6[ph]. So you could say in a sense that our utilization of 300-millimeter may actually decline, but not because of loading increasing our capacity.

componenttextpreview: No, Doug. Factory consolidation is not in our radar. What we're really interested in is very inexpensive factory acquisition with extremely low carrying cost that allows us to grow into it in a very efficient manner. As we've been talking about Analog and
componenttext: No, Doug. Factory consolidation is not in our radar. What we're really interested in is very inexpensive factory acquisition with extremely low carrying cost that allows us to grow into it in a very efficient manner. As we've been talking about Analog and Embedded Processing for combined, for an extended period of time now, having grown at about[ph] the 9% annual growth rate. And in fact, even combined for this 1Q that we just closed out, they grew another 9% year-over-year. So they continue to grow quite healthy. I would expect that as we move forward in time, we look at those factories that provide us the best cost efficiency and cash flow delivery and keep those operating loads and that's going to be biased in towards the 300-millimeter.

componenttext: Yes. And I'll just add to that, if you look at the growth rates in time and just look at what's happened in the second quarter, the overall numbers are very strong. We can do very well in a low growth environment or if things pick up, we can -- we're in a good position to support that as well. So okay, thank you, Doug. We'll go to the next caller, please.

Good day. Welcome to the Texas Instruments 1Q '15 Earnings Release Conference Call. 
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2015 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our first quarter 2015 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.
For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations on our website at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through TI's website. A replay will be available through the web.
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the notice regarding forward-looking statements contained in the earnings release published today as well as TI's most recent SEC filings for a more complete description.
Revenue growth of 6% from a year ago was within the range of expectations we provided in January. Automotive and industrial markets were strong, as we expected they would be. However, revenue was in the bottom half of the range for 2 reasons. First was weak demand in the last month of the quarter in our personal electronics market, particularly PCs, and in our communications equipment market, particularly wireless infrastructure equipment. We believe these market-specific issues were due to delay of investments by carriers in capacity upgrades for wireless infrastructure equipment and a weaker-than-expected refresh cycle for Windows XP.
The second reason was a steep decline in the currency exchange rate for the euro relative to the U.S. dollar. The euro dropped about 10% during the quarter, and even though only about 5% of TI's revenue is transacted in euros, it was a sharp enough drop that it negatively impacted our revenue by about $20 million more than we had anticipated.
Even with these pockets of weaknesses, our core business of Analog and Embedded Processing turned in their seventh and 10th consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth, respectively. Combined, these businesses grew 9% and were 86% of our total revenue.
Earnings per share were $0.61, reflecting our continued attention to cost controls. Although the vast majority of our revenue was transacted in U.S. dollars, ROE negatively impacted revenue by $20 million, which translated to only about $5 million of impact to earnings and, therefore, cash flow. This is due to a partial natural hedge against negative currency fluctuations due to our non-U.S.-based operations. It's nice to have a position -- to be in this when you have almost 90% of our revenue comes outside of the U.S.
With that as backdrop, Kevin and I will move on with our report on business performance that we believe continues to represent the ongoing strength of TI's business model.
In the first quarter, our cash flow from operations was $609 million. We believe that free cash flow growth, especially on a per-share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term. Free cash flow for the trailing 12-month period was $3.6 billion, up 17% from a year ago.
Free cash flow was 27% revenue, consistent with our targeted range of 20% to 30% of revenue. This is a 2-percentage-point improvement from a year-ago period and we believe reflects our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy, which includes our growing 300-millimeter output and the opportunistic purchases of assets ahead of demand.
We also believe that free cash flow will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or productively invested in the businesses. For the trailing 12-month period, we returned $4.1 billion of cash to investors through a combination of stock repurchases and dividends.
In the first quarter, TI revenue grew 6% from a year ago with growth in both Analog and Embedded Processing. 
Analog revenue grew 11% from a year ago, primarily due to Power Management and High Volume Analog & Logic. Silicon Valley Analog and High Performance Analog also grew. As we mentioned earlier, this is the seventh quarter of year-over-year growth for Analog.
Embedded Processing revenue grew 2% from a year ago due to Microcontrollers and Connectivity. Processor revenue declined, which was impacted by the weakness in wireless infrastructure. And again, as I mentioned earlier, this is the 10th consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth for Embedded Processing.
In our Other segment, revenue declined 10% from a year ago primarily due to custom ASIC products, which also are heavy in wireless infrastructure, as well as DLP products.
In distribution, resales increased 11% from a year ago. Weeks of inventory remained at historically low levels of just under 4.5 weeks, which is a decrease by more than a week from a year ago and is even with the fourth quarter. This level has decreased over the past few years because we have structurally changed how our inventory is managed in the distribution channel with our consignment program.
From an end-market perspective versus a year ago, automotive grew, with most sectors inside this market growing at double-digit rates; industrial had broad-based growth; personal electronics grew, although growth in PCs was lower than we expected; communications equipment declined due to wireless infrastructure; and enterprise systems grew.
Kevin will now review profitability, capital management and our outlook.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $1.82 billion or 57.7% of revenue. Gross profit increased 13% from the year-ago quarter and gross margin was up almost 4 points. Gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased fa
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $1.82 billion or 57.7% of revenue. Gross profit increased 13% from the year-ago quarter and gross margin was up almost 4 points. Gross profit reflects higher revenue, increased factory loadings and benefits from our efficient manufacturing strategy as we build more Analog chips on 300-millimeter wafers.
Moving to operating expenses, combined R&D and SG&A expenses of $777 million were down $68 million from a year ago. The decline primarily reflects the targeted reductions in Embedded Processing in Japan that were previously announced. As we said, that restructuring was essentially complete at the end of last year.
Acquisition charges were $83 million, almost all of which were the ongoing amortization of intangibles, which is noncash expense. 
Operating profit was $958 million or 30.4% of revenue. Operating profit was up 39% from the year-ago quarter. Operating margin for Analog was 35.4%. Operating margin for Embedded Processing was 18.3%, more than doubling from a year ago as we executed our restructuring plan to better align resources with the opportunities that we are pursuing as we benefit from our investments for growth.
Net income in the first quarter was $656 million or $0.61 per share.
Let me now comment on our capital management results, starting with our cash generation. 
Cash flow from operations was $609 million in the quarter. 
Inventory days were 124, about 3 days more than planned due to revenue coming in at the bottom half of our expectations. 
Capital expenditures were $123 million in the quarter.
On a trailing 12-month basis, cash flow operations was $4.04 billion, up 16% from the same period a year ago. Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $431 million or 3% of revenue. As a reminder, our long-term expectation is for capital expenditures to be about 4% of revenue, which includes our $8 billion 300-millimeter Analog plan discussed our recent capital mentioned call.
Free cash flow for the past 12 months was $3.61 billion or 27% of revenue. Free cash flow was 17% higher than a year ago. 
As we said, we believe free cash flow growth, especially on a per-share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term and will be valued only if it is returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business. As we've noted, our intent is to return 100% of our free cash flow plus any proceeds we receive from the exercise of equity compensation minus net debt retirement.
In the first quarter, TI paid $356 million in dividends and repurchased $670 million of our stock for a total return of $1.03 billion. Total cash returned in the past 12 months was $4.14 billion.
Outstanding share count was reduced by 3.2% over the past 12 months and by 39% since the beginning of 2005. These returns demonstrate our confidence in TI's business model and our commitment to return excess cash to our shareholders.
Fundamental to our commitment to return cash are our cash management and tax practices. We ended the first quarter with $3.30 billion of cash and short-term investments. TI's U.S. entities owned 80% -- 82% of our cash. Because our cash is largely onshore, it is readily available for a variety of uses, including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock.
TI orders in the quarter were $3.21 billion, up 5% from a year ago.
Turning to our outlook, we expect TI revenue in the range of $3.12 billion to $3.38 billion in the second quarter. This represents continuing weakness in our communications equipment and personal electronics markets, particularly for wireless infrastructure equipment and PCs, respectively. We also do not expect a near-term rebound in foreign currency exchange rates.
We expect second quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $0.60 to $0.70. Acquisition charges, which are noncash amortization charges, will remain about even and hold at about $80 million to $85 million per quarter for the next 5 years.
Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate in 2015 remains about 30%, and this is the tax rate you should use for the second quarter and for the year.
In summary, we believe that the first quarter demonstrates the strength of TI's business model. While we are not immune to demand and currency changes, their effects are softened by the diversity of our portfolio and our markets.
With that, let me turn it back to Dave.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin. Operator, you can now open the lines up for questions. [Operator Instructions]
componenttext:
Thanks, Kevin. 
Operator, you can now open the lines up for questions. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we go first to Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we go first to Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's so much controversy in the industry today about whether the industry is as cyclical as it used to be, less so, et cetera. I look at your year-over-year growth rates, the June quarter represents the first time you've had a year-over-year decline at
componenttext: There's so much controversy in the industry today about whether the industry is as cyclical as it used to be, less so, et cetera. I look at your year-over-year growth rates, the June quarter represents the first time you've had a year-over-year decline at the midpoint of your guidance in a long time. How do you think about that in the context of an industry where many are arguing that we're not cyclical anymore?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim. We're -- as you know, we've been pretty guarded at trying to predict the cycle. It's not something obviously that we can control. We really just go to what we can look at, what we can measure. So as you kind of tick through the things that you t
componenttext: Yes, Jim. We're -- as you know, we've been pretty guarded at trying to predict the cycle. It's not something obviously that we can control. We really just go to what we can look at, what we can measure. So as you kind of tick through the things that you typically look at from a cyclical standpoint, we look at channel inventories are down a week from a year ago, they're lean at just under 4.5 weeks. Lead times are remaining consistent. Our cancellations and reschedules are very low. In addition, we're continuing to deliver on time and very consistently with that. So we've got a couple of pockets of weaker-than-expected demand, as we talked about specifically in wireless infrastructure and PCs. At the same time, we're seeing automotive and industrial continuing to be strong as we expect. So that's what we know, that's what we can see. The debates will continue on, on how cyclical our industry will be or won't be.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I might just add that we do have several significant competitive advantages, the combination of which we believe is pretty difficult for anybody else to replicate, and it helps us deal with any notion of cyclicality or non-cyclicality. And those advantage
componenttext: I might just add that we do have several significant competitive advantages, the combination of which we believe is pretty difficult for anybody else to replicate, and it helps us deal with any notion of cyclicality or non-cyclicality. And those advantages include that we've got the broadest portfolio in the industry, which really means engineers start their design work by looking at us first. We enjoy a very low cost manufacturing for all the reasons that you've heard us talk about for the last few years, including our 300-millimeter wafer fabs. We have the broadest sales channel, in fact, probably 3x to 4x larger than our nearest competitor. And we play in an extremely diverse set of markets with long-lived products that enjoy a significant cash return for our shareholders for a long time. So we think that's what's really important to deal with whatever may be happening in market cycles and just really make sure that we're a lot more competitively advantaged than everybody else.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow-up, Jim?
componenttext: Do you have a follow-up, Jim?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. That was helpful. Obviously, you're talking about some weakness in PCs and comps. In the industrial segment, we're starting to see some negative news flow from the customers. Do you see pockets of weakness, but there's just other pockets of strength,
componenttext: Yes. That was helpful. Obviously, you're talking about some weakness in PCs and comps. In the industrial segment, we're starting to see some negative news flow from the customers. Do you see pockets of weakness, but there's just other pockets of strength, that are offsetting those industrial customers that maybe weak, because I know it's a very broad-based customer base? Or do you just not see any weakness at all in that segment at this point?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim. I'll just say that like you were hinting to, it's very broad-based. So we service over 100,000 customers, most of those will reside in industrial. And again, I think, it's probably helpful for me to just go through, and when we say industrial, i
componenttext: Yes, Jim. I'll just say that like you were hinting to, it's very broad-based. So we service over 100,000 customers, most of those will reside in industrial. And again, I think, it's probably helpful for me to just go through, and when we say industrial, it means something different than I think the investment definition of industrial. So it'll include things like factory automation and control and medical, health care, fitness products, building automation, smart grid, energy test equipment, motor drives display, space avionics, appliances, and other segments. So again, very, very broad. Of course, we'll always see pockets of strength and weaknesses. But overall, that industrial is doing well. We've seen growth in almost all those sectors that I've described. Okay, thank you.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go now to Chris Danely with Citi.
componenttext: And we'll go now to Chris Danely with Citi.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dave, you did a good job of outlining the, I guess, the relative areas of weakness in Q1 from currency and common PC. Can you just give us what you think would be a bigger drag in terms of company sales from PC versus communications? And then, do you guys
componenttext: Dave, you did a good job of outlining the, I guess, the relative areas of weakness in Q1 from currency and common PC. Can you just give us what you think would be a bigger drag in terms of company sales from PC versus communications? And then, do you guys expect a negative impact from currency in Q2 as well? And if you can give us the magnitude of that negative impact.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the one that's pretty straightforward to identify, because it's really just math walking through the numbers, is that on a year-on-year basis we'll probably see about a $50 million headwind due to currency exchange rates. And obviously, we're not
componenttext: Yes. So the one that's pretty straightforward to identify, because it's really just math walking through the numbers, is that on a year-on-year basis we'll probably see about a $50 million headwind due to currency exchange rates. And obviously, we're not assuming that we see a rebound in those rates. We'll still see and expect to see the weakness in PCs and wireless infrastructure. And just kind of the balance of the business, as you know, there's always puts and takes. As an example, second quarter a year ago, DLP was very strong. If you remember, it was benefiting from several world events, one of them like the World Cup. Well, that won't repeat, so that'll be weaker than it was a year ago and will continue for the rest of the year. But inside of that bucket, we'll continue to have puts and takes. Do you have a -- the other comment that I just made on that, although we see those pockets of weakness, if you look at the core businesses of Analog and Embedded, we do believe that those will continue to perform well. So do you have a follow-up, Chris?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, actually, just a couple of clarifications. So do you expect that PC or the wireless infrastructure to have a bigger drag on your revenue in Q2? And then, it almost seems like -- do we need the dollar to weaken again for that to -- for that impact to
componenttext: Yes, actually, just a couple of clarifications. So do you expect that PC or the wireless infrastructure to have a bigger drag on your revenue in Q2? And then, it almost seems like -- do we need the dollar to weaken again for that to -- for that impact to go away, i.e, if the dollar remains strong, is that going to be like a negative impact for you guys every quarter?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, I'm going to say that we probably don't have enough detail to tell you whether wireless infrastructure or PC, which is going to be more of a drag. We just don't expect them to be recovering in the second quarter. As it relates to ROE, certainly wit
componenttext: Chris, I'm going to say that we probably don't have enough detail to tell you whether wireless infrastructure or PC, which is going to be more of a drag. We just don't expect them to be recovering in the second quarter. As it relates to ROE, certainly with -- if we take a look at just the euro alone versus a year ago, it's down 23%. The yen is down 14%. We roughly average about 5% of our revenue in euros and around 3% in yen. So clearly with that kind of weakness, on a year-over-year compare, that's going to continue to be an issue that's going to just affect that kind of math. It doesn't affect our ability to sell in those markets. We'll continue to remain very competitive in those spaces as we enjoy a lot of design wins. But unless the ROE moves back and the dollar weakens, then certainly with that kind of dramatic decline in those 2 major currencies, that will be, at least on the fringes, a year-over-year compare headwind for us.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add to that, that like we saw in the first quarter where we had an impact of about $20 million because of the natural hedging, we've got the impact to operating profit and free cash flow's really only about $5 million. So fairly small on tha
componenttext: And I'll just add to that, that like we saw in the first quarter where we had an impact of about $20 million because of the natural hedging, we've got the impact to operating profit and free cash flow's really only about $5 million. So fairly small on that front. Okay, thanks, Chris.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We now go to John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: We now go to John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess, I don't want to beat a dead horse, but just on the outlook. When I look at the Q1, it looks like you guys are only missing the midpoint of your guide by about $50 million and you explained $20 million of that on currency. As I go to Q2, if I
componenttext: Yes. I guess, I don't want to beat a dead horse, but just on the outlook. When I look at the Q1, it looks like you guys are only missing the midpoint of your guide by about $50 million and you explained $20 million of that on currency. As I go to Q2, if I just anchor again seasonality, you're kind of missing it by $150 million to $200 million. And I guess, sequentially, are you expecting any more kind of headwinds from currency? I understand the year-over-year compare, I'm kind of trying to figure out the sequential compare. And when I look at PCs plus comp infrastructure, help me understand the percent of the business that represents, I'm thinking around 15%, maybe I'm wrong with that. And I guess I'm trying to get a sense as to why you think that the miss in Q2 is going to be so much larger in those 2 buckets than the miss in Q1?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, let me -- I'll take the first part of the question and Kevin can add in, if he'd like to. The first, if you look at our PC revenues as a percentage of our total, is around 5%. If you were thinking hard drives into that, that'll add a few points
componenttext: Yes, John, let me -- I'll take the first part of the question and Kevin can add in, if he'd like to. The first, if you look at our PC revenues as a percentage of our total, is around 5%. If you were thinking hard drives into that, that'll add a few points. So you'll be just under 10% in upper single digits. If you look at wireless infrastructure, last year, it was about 10% of our revenues. So obviously, combined there, you're in the mid-teens. So that will give you an idea of what that impact is. Again, as Kevin kind of walked through the math of like the euro as an example, last year, 18% of our revenue was done in Europe. About 1/3 of that, so 5%, 6% is transacted in euro, and again, sequentially. I don't know if you have any additional comments on the impact to the euro.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, just 1Q to 2Q, I think, is what you're trying to ask for there, John. The average ROE that we experienced on our billings in 1Q is about, for the euro, was about 1.13. And for planning purposes, we're using 1.06 going into 2Q. So there's goi
componenttext: Yes. I think, just 1Q to 2Q, I think, is what you're trying to ask for there, John. The average ROE that we experienced on our billings in 1Q is about, for the euro, was about 1.13. And for planning purposes, we're using 1.06 going into 2Q. So there's going to be a little bit of a just a quarter-over-quarter ROE impact just from that standpoint as it relates to the euro. Right now, we're anticipating the yen to be pretty flat.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow-on, John?
componenttext: Do you have a follow-on, John?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do, guys. And I know that was in the comp section, specifically. You guys were doing a little bit of pruning with the product portfolio. And I'm wondering if any of the pruning that you've done is being reflected in kind of either sequential or yea
componenttext: Yes, I do, guys. And I know that was in the comp section, specifically. You guys were doing a little bit of pruning with the product portfolio. And I'm wondering if any of the pruning that you've done is being reflected in kind of either sequential or year-over-year growth rates, or do you feel like that, that's not a factor as you look at the June guide?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't believe that, that is a factor, John. I think if you look at the impact the wireless infrastructure has, we sell more Analog product than we do Embedded, or the custom ASIC products. So it actually hit both Analog, Embedded and Other. Of cou
componenttext: Yes, we don't believe that, that is a factor, John. I think if you look at the impact the wireless infrastructure has, we sell more Analog product than we do Embedded, or the custom ASIC products. So it actually hit both Analog, Embedded and Other. Of course, you could see the impact more significantly in Embedded because -- and Other because it's a higher percentage of that revenue. But again, we've got a good position really across most of the major OEMs there. And so what we're seeing is really a change in shipments and demand. So thanks, John.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We go now to Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein.
componenttext: We go now to Stacy Rasgon with Bernstein.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, I was wondering if you can give us a handle on where you see OpEx going next quarter given the revenue shortfall?
componenttext: First, I was wondering if you can give us a handle on where you see OpEx going next quarter given the revenue shortfall?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stacy. OpEx was up about as expected fourth quarter to first quarter. And recall that in the fourth quarter, we typically are down a bit on the OpEx because of seasonality for holidays and so on. And the absence of those seasonality -- those holidays
componenttext: Yes, Stacy. OpEx was up about as expected fourth quarter to first quarter. And recall that in the fourth quarter, we typically are down a bit on the OpEx because of seasonality for holidays and so on. And the absence of those seasonality -- those holidays in the first quarter, along with our annual pay and benefit increases, traditionally drives our OpEx up quarter-over-quarter. Those pay and benefit increases kick in, in February. So it's really only 2 months' worth inside the OpEx right now in the first quarter. So we'll have the full 3 months. So you'll see just a very slight increase going into the second quarter.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. For my follow-up, again, on currency, I know you guys are pointing to sort of direct translation effects. We've had other players who have pointed to demand destruction concurrency. And I was wondering if you could give us your point of view and w
componenttext: Got it. For my follow-up, again, on currency, I know you guys are pointing to sort of direct translation effects. We've had other players who have pointed to demand destruction concurrency. And I was wondering if you could give us your point of view and what you're seeing more broadly in the market, not just for your revenues, but also for your customers. Are you seeing any sort of broad-based TAM destruction because of the currency movements that we've had?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Stacy, we've talked about that, but there's no way for us to really point to something and demonstrate evidence that, that's actually occurring. Given  that the entire industry tends to price in dollars for the preponderance of what's being shipped, there
componenttext: Stacy, we've talked about that, but there's no way for us to really point to something and demonstrate evidence that, that's actually occurring. Given  that the entire industry tends to price in dollars for the preponderance of what's being shipped, there's not a lot of other alternatives it would seem for customers from a demand standpoint. But that's not to say there might not be a second order knock-on effect like what you're alluding to. And we just don't see any way that we can quantify that with any confidence.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And there's always pluses and minuses with the currency movement. It's really impossible for us to be able to quantify that. Okay, thank you, Stacy.
componenttext: And there's always pluses and minuses with the currency movement. It's really impossible for us to be able to quantify that. Okay, thank you, Stacy.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We go now to Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We go now to Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Given the timing of when you started to see the weakness that you talked about in the March quarter and just given the softer-than-seasonal Q2 outlook, would you have to ratchet down your wafer fab manufacturing activity or wafer starts here in Q2?
componenttext: Given the timing of when you started to see the weakness that you talked about in the March quarter and just given the softer-than-seasonal Q2 outlook, would you have to ratchet down your wafer fab manufacturing activity or wafer starts here in Q2?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Harlan, yes, we will be lightening up the wafer starts in 2Q. I would caution you though that pulling back on the wafer starts doesn't necessarily mean that, that'll have a direct impact on our inventory as the work in progress in 1Q will become finished
componenttext: Harlan, yes, we will be lightening up the wafer starts in 2Q. I would caution you though that pulling back on the wafer starts doesn't necessarily mean that, that'll have a direct impact on our inventory as the work in progress in 1Q will become finished goods in 2Q. So we would expect our inventory probably still goes up a bit in 2Q even though we'll pull back on the wafer starts a little bit.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, Analog was up nicely 11% year-over-year despite the headwinds. Embedded was up only 2%, which is a pretty significant deceleration year-over-year versus the prior quarter. I'm assuming that the Embedded weakness was primarily driven
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, Analog was up nicely 11% year-over-year despite the headwinds. Embedded was up only 2%, which is a pretty significant deceleration year-over-year versus the prior quarter. I'm assuming that the Embedded weakness was primarily driven by DSPs given the muted wireless infrastructure spending environment?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That -- it's correct. It was impacted by the wireless infrastructure. And in fact, if you look at the businesses inside of Embedded, we had good growth in Microcontrollers and Connectivity both. But Processors were down for the exact reason that you ident
componenttext: That -- it's correct. It was impacted by the wireless infrastructure. And in fact, if you look at the businesses inside of Embedded, we had good growth in Microcontrollers and Connectivity both. But Processors were down for the exact reason that you identified now. So okay, thank you, Harlan.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We now go to Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We now go to Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: One other avenue to get at the broad-based demand trends, are you seeing any sort of difference in demand patterns from your distributor customers relative to the OEM customers? Are they getting any more nervous or excited and willing to carry inventory?
componenttext: One other avenue to get at the broad-based demand trends, are you seeing any sort of difference in demand patterns from your distributor customers relative to the OEM customers? Are they getting any more nervous or excited and willing to carry inventory? I realized the weeks of inventory data that you gave before, but from a bookings perspective, any color would be helpful.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think I'll just offer on that, Ross, is that on a year-over-year basis, bookings were up 5%. 60% of our revenue does go through disty [ph]. So clearly, we're seeing a lot of the bookings coming through the disty [ph] channel. The inventory levels they'r
componenttext: I think I'll just offer on that, Ross, is that on a year-over-year basis, bookings were up 5%. 60% of our revenue does go through disty [ph]. So clearly, we're seeing a lot of the bookings coming through the disty [ph] channel. The inventory levels they're carrying are about 4.5 weeks, which is down about a week from a year ago, so they continue to carry lean levels of inventory. And I think largely that's because they know that we carry inventory and consignments, we also maintain very short lead times, as we have for a number of years now. And so their ability to get inventory quickly is pretty reliable for them when they order with us. So I don't -- from those kinds of elements inside that space, there's no rule, again, signs that we can look at that says, "Gee, there's demand destruction going on because of ROE." That really can't put anything there, right?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'd add, Ross, that if you look at our resales overall, that was very consistent with our combined Analog and Embedded sales. So it was in the upper single digits, very close to the same number. Do you have a follow-on, Ross?
componenttext: And I'd add, Ross, that if you look at our resales overall, that was very consistent with our combined Analog and Embedded sales. So it was in the upper single digits, very close to the same number. Do you have a follow-on, Ross?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, a quick one, just to make sure that I have all the moving parts. It sounds like in answer to a prior question, Kevin, you said OpEx would be up a little. You also said that it sounds like utilization will be down. It seems like putting that together
componenttext: Yes, a quick one, just to make sure that I have all the moving parts. It sounds like in answer to a prior question, Kevin, you said OpEx would be up a little. You also said that it sounds like utilization will be down. It seems like putting that together with your earnings guidance it implies gross margin is going to be down a bit sequentially. Is that, one, is that math directionally correct? Two, is the cause of the gross margin simply utilization, or is there some mix effect that I also need to appreciate?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: You may be missing the mix effects inside there, Ross. I don't expect much change in the margin.
componenttext: You may be missing the mix effects inside there, Ross. I don't expect much change in the margin.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you for that question, Ross.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you for that question, Ross.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We go now to Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We go now to Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the markets that you see a weakness in PCs and wireless infrastructure, do you think it's an inventory or a demand problem? And I guess, what is -- we've seen other suppliers into the PC sector talk about a return to sort of better-than-seasonal second
componenttext: In the markets that you see a weakness in PCs and wireless infrastructure, do you think it's an inventory or a demand problem? And I guess, what is -- we've seen other suppliers into the PC sector talk about a return to sort of better-than-seasonal second half as you get past inventory correction. Where do you stand on that?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Joe, I'd just say, first of all, that the wireless infrastructure market is -- has notoriously been very choppy as you look at demand over the number of years. So there's usually a significant build as OEMs are planning to bid for the operators' spend. An
componenttext: Joe, I'd just say, first of all, that the wireless infrastructure market is -- has notoriously been very choppy as you look at demand over the number of years. So there's usually a significant build as OEMs are planning to bid for the operators' spend. And then, it typically surprises us and there's an overbuild that occurs. So one kind of begets the other. We think that the wireless infrastructure market, obviously, long term, is a good market for us and we've got a good position in. And just as the numbers come down, they'll come up again one day. On the PC side, that's only a couple of percent of our revenue, so I don't think we really have any unique insight on that. We believe that, that weakness is due to the inventory that's created because there wasn't as much demand in the XP refresh cycle. But really nothing beyond that. And we'll see how the rest of this quarter goes before we start making predictions on the back half. I'll just take it one quarter at a time. So you have a follow-on?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I guess, specifically, I think John Pitzer had mentioned the restructuring that you did, but just specifically, you did cut back on R&D and macro base stations. And I'm wondering if there's anything directly that would point to that decision vers
componenttext: Yes, and I guess, specifically, I think John Pitzer had mentioned the restructuring that you did, but just specifically, you did cut back on R&D and macro base stations. And I'm wondering if there's anything directly that would point to that decision versus revenue using hours, or completely separate from that?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, I think that when we look at those markets, they're very long-tailed in product cycles. We continue to make investments, they're just not at the same rates that we were making 5 and 10 years ago. And that's not unlike what we've done in other
componenttext: Yes. Again, I think that when we look at those markets, they're very long-tailed in product cycles. We continue to make investments, they're just not at the same rates that we were making 5 and 10 years ago. And that's not unlike what we've done in other markets as they've begun to mature. So there's other areas of wireless infrastructure that looks like it will be very promising growth, like small cells, and we continue to invest very -- at very high levels there while we have very little revenue today. So we just believe that we've got to throttle that investment based on the opportunity overall. So thanks for that question.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We go now to Timothy Arcuri with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: We go now to Timothy Arcuri with Cowen and Company.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions. First of all, I had a question about the channel. Do you see any meaningful cancels this quarter? And then I had a follow-up on the inventory.
componenttext: I had 2 questions. First of all, I had a question about the channel. Do you see any meaningful cancels this quarter? And then I had a follow-up on the inventory.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. We saw cancellations continue to run very, very low as we've seen it for a number of quarters now. And same is true with reschedules, too, by the way. Also, very, very low. So no patterns indicating change in demand there.
componenttext: No. We saw cancellations continue to run very, very low as we've seen it for a number of quarters now. And same is true with reschedules, too, by the way. Also, very, very low. So no patterns indicating change in demand there.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, Kevin, you said inventories are going to be up, I think, again you said in June despite loadings being down. I guess, my question is, what do you think is sort of the -- now that you've had a couple quarters to think about the mix,
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, Kevin, you said inventories are going to be up, I think, again you said in June despite loadings being down. I guess, my question is, what do you think is sort of the -- now that you've had a couple quarters to think about the mix, what do you think is the right normalized level of inventory? And do you think that we're going to come back down to sort of that more normalized level during the back half of the year?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tim. We are going to use 2015 to really kind of monitor the effect of all the changes we've been doing with the portfolio and with our operations to model what we think is a more appropriate overall level of average inventories to carry. What we did
componenttext: Yes, Tim. We are going to use 2015 to really kind of monitor the effect of all the changes we've been doing with the portfolio and with our operations to model what we think is a more appropriate overall level of average inventories to carry. What we did conclude was that the prior model, which has worked for us quite well of 105 to 115 days was appropriate given the mix that we had. But clearly, as we move to more and more consignment, as we move to keeping lead times very short across the vast abundance of our portfolio, that dictates that we've got to carry more inventory than we have in the past. And so what we use in 2015 to run various tests on what the appropriate level of inventories are to beat the service metrics that our customers have come to expect from us. And then probably by the time we get to early next year when we do our capital management update, we'll go ahead and articulate a new model of that same type.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Tim, thank you.
componenttext: Great. Tim, thank you.

componenttext: Yes. Kevin and Dave, I just wanted to clarify how these 2 segments that comprised 15% of revenue are driving what I estimate as a 500-basis-point miss relative to seasonality. Are you guys just being conservative in anticipation of maybe a fallout in some of your other end markets? Or am I just not fully incorporating other parts of the equation here?

componenttext: So I'll go ahead and just -- I think Dave attempted last time. I'll give it a try. There are several moving parts going on there. When you look at 2Q and it best compares on a year-over-year basis. So just the ROE alone impacts us about $50 million from a year-over-year compare for growth rate. Then you go beyond that and you've got continuing weakness in wireless infrastructure and PCs and then you've also got the absence of the benefit the DLP had a year ago, which was meaningful due to the World Cup and other -- and large sporting events. In fact, we saw some of that impact to DLP already begin to occur in first quarter. As we mentioned, DLP was down quite a bit in the first quarter. So you got those kinds of headwinds, ROE, wireless infrastructure, PC and DLP, and then we've got the rest of the portfolio basically doing fine, consistent with what we've been seeing in the economy for the last few quarters.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I just wanted to ask you about M&A. There's been, as you guys have seen, a lot of activity over the last year. When I think about TI, M&A has certainly been part of your DNA over the last 15 years. Can you just talk about how you're thinking about M&
componenttext: Yes. I just wanted to ask you about M&A. There's been, as you guys have seen, a lot of activity over the last year. When I think about TI, M&A has certainly been part of your DNA over the last 15 years. Can you just talk about how you're thinking about M&A specifically in this environment, relative to buying back your own stock?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Romit, the -- our M&A posture hasn't changed at all. Meaning, that the most important thing is that to the extent that we consider an acquisition, it's got to be something that fits into our strategy that's consistent with our portfolio interests and
componenttext: Yes, Romit, the -- our M&A posture hasn't changed at all. Meaning, that the most important thing is that to the extent that we consider an acquisition, it's got to be something that fits into our strategy that's consistent with our portfolio interests and something that we can generate long-term returns on and therefore excess free cash flow for our shareholders. If it kind of passes the strategy test, then it's got to pass the numbers test. And frankly, we have a hard time, with many of the companies that are out there today, making those kind of numbers work. Contrast that to when we bought National back in 2011 at a time when all semiconductor stock prices were considerably lower, you can certainly see in retrospect that was a very good return for our shareholders. So we tend to be very disciplined on that. We'll continue to be very disciplined on that. Buying back our own shares right now, especially as long as they trade below the intrinsic value of the company, is -- it also continues to be a good return for shareholders, especially from a free cash flow perspective.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Okay, thanks, Romit.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kevin, you mentioned if you look at the portfolio the rest of the business is doing fine outside of the factors that you highlighted. If you go back to history and look at such a sharp deceleration -- such a sharp destruction, let's use that word, on the
componenttext: Kevin, you mentioned if you look at the portfolio the rest of the business is doing fine outside of the factors that you highlighted. If you go back to history and look at such a sharp deceleration -- such a sharp destruction, let's use that word, on the exchange rate, when do you expect that to manifest itself in other parts of the business? So for instance, the distributors in Europe and other pieces, widgets that semis go into, for instance, in industrials and autos. What does past currency issues tell us on that front? And then I have a quick follow-up.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I wish I had some clever insight on that, but I'm afraid I don't just from an experience standpoint. I actually do not recall that my experience in this capacity, and I've been in this role for a very long time now, seeing currencies drop this sharpl
componenttext: Yes. I wish I had some clever insight on that, but I'm afraid I don't just from an experience standpoint. I actually do not recall that my experience in this capacity, and I've been in this role for a very long time now, seeing currencies drop this sharply in this short a period of time. So I have no history from which to try to get a reference point to answer your question like that. I think we're just all going to have to wait and see where this takes us. I think the encouraging part is, especially in industrial and automotive, is that the silicon content going into those spaces continues to increase year-over-year. And so despite ROE impacts, I don't think that's going to slow down the silicon content increases in those spaces. And frankly, if you look at the pricing of those end equipment, the cost of a $0.50 Analog chip going to $0.55 is pretty irrelevant to an automotive customer, I think. So if -- if you look at the more macro effects and especially where we see growth from semiconductors and auto and industrial, it doesn't seem likely that we would see a sharp impact in demand caused just because of ROE. There may be other factors that may lead to that kind of difference.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015

componenttext: Yes. And I'd just add that as many arguments as putting pressure on demand there's as many arguments that it could help demand on the other side. So it's really tough to be able to quantify each of those impacts. So Ambrish, you've got a follow-up?

componenttext: Yes, Doug. On the utilization, we typically will just talk about that if something drastic has occurred. So I won't go into that right now. I will remind you though on the Capital Management call, I did discuss for our fab in particular, that we have the majority of equipment necessary to support the buildout of that factory to a $5 billion revenue level. And that, in 2014, we had achieved about $2 billion worth of build for revenue in support of that. So call that roughly 40% utilized. But at the same time, we're also converting DMOS6 from its exclusive use by Embedded Processing to also be able to be used by Analog. And that'll add another $3 billion of 300-millimeter Analog capacity in DMOS6. So you could say in a sense that our utilization of 300-millimeter may actually decline, but that's not because of loadings, that's because of increasing our capacity.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The question really that I have, as my follow-up, is when you look at the year-on-year growth, last year clearly we had a nice year, but with the guidance you've just offered, we're actually down year-on-year. If we look at the long-term growth rate of yo
componenttext: The question really that I have, as my follow-up, is when you look at the year-on-year growth, last year clearly we had a nice year, but with the guidance you've just offered, we're actually down year-on-year. If we look at the long-term growth rate of your business, is there a point in time at which you might adjust what you think your long-term growth rate would be such that you felt factory consolidation would be part of the equation to drive higher efficiency?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, Doug. Factory consolidation is not in our radar. What we're really interested in is very inexpensive factory acquisition with extremely low carrying cost that allows us to grow into it in a very efficient manner. As we've been talking about Analog and
componenttext: No, Doug. Factory consolidation is not in our radar. What we're really interested in is very inexpensive factory acquisition with extremely low carrying cost that allows us to grow into it in a very efficient manner. As we've been talking about Analog and Embedded Processing for combined, for an extended period of time now, having grown at about a 9% compound annual growth rate. And in fact, even combined for this 1Q that we just closed out, they grew another 9% year-over-year. So they continue to grow quite healthy. I would expect that as we move forward in time, we'll look at those factories that provide us the best cost efficiency and cash flow delivery and keep those operating and loading those. That's probably going to be biased on loadings towards 300-millimeter.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll just add, too, that if you look at the growth rates in time and just look at what's happened in the second quarter, the overall numbers are very strong. I mean, if you look at our gross margins, you look at where our OpEx levels are, our ope
componenttext: Yes. And I'll just add, too, that if you look at the growth rates in time and just look at what's happened in the second quarter, the overall numbers are very strong. I mean, if you look at our gross margins, you look at where our OpEx levels are, our operating margins. With that 9% Analog and Embedded Processing growth, this quarter we turned in 27% free cash flow, right? So our financial performance isn't predicated on having to hit a certain growth level. We can do very well in a low growth environment. Or if things pick up, we can -- we're in a good position to be able to support that as well. So okay, thank you, Doug.
