headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'll just make a comment on both revenue and order linearity in the quarter. In both cases revenue and orders increased each month during the quarter. I think as you look at the end market detail as I just had walked through, in general, we saw a
componenttext: Okay. So I'll just make a comment on both revenue and order linearity in the quarter. In both cases revenue and orders increased each month during the quarter. I think as you look at the end market detail as I just had walked through, in general, we saw automotive was strong with all the sectors inside of that growing, all but one growing at double-digit rates. Industrial revenue was flat just contrasting that to last quarter's year-over-year growth. We didn't see growth there and it was incrementally weaker than we had expected. And as we had talked about inside of there, we really saw about half of the sectors increase. And that of course, was offset by declines in the other sectors. Our personal electronics, as we talked about, grew in total, due to specifically 1 large customer. And outside of the customer, actually saw almost every sector decline, including PCs as we were expected. Comms infrastructure, as we mentioned, was impacted by -- or comps equipment was impacted by Wireless infrastructure and that was down 50% from a year ago. So, and that actually was weaker than what we had expected when we started the quarter. And then the last, enterprise systems declined due to DLP projectors as we had expected. So that's kind of a summary of what we saw by end market. So thanks, Chris.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that call -- question will come from Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And that call -- question will come from Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: On the Q2 results, you talked about incrementally weaker trends in industrial. This has been a particular focus by the market. Can you just talk about the geographical trends within your industrial business? There's a lot of concern around demand trends i
componenttext: On the Q2 results, you talked about incrementally weaker trends in industrial. This has been a particular focus by the market. Can you just talk about the geographical trends within your industrial business? There's a lot of concern around demand trends in industrial in Europe and China. Love to get some color from you guys.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Harlan. So let me just tell you what happened with the revenue in the quarter. So year-over-year, revenue was down as we've mentioned before, 2% Europe was down the most and Japan was also down. Asia was flat while the U.S. was up. From a sequential
componenttext: Sure, Harlan. So let me just tell you what happened with the revenue in the quarter. So year-over-year, revenue was down as we've mentioned before, 2% Europe was down the most and Japan was also down. Asia was flat while the U.S. was up. From a sequential standpoint, revenue was up, led by the U.S., Asia and Europe were both about even, sequentially while Japan was down. So we're always cautious. We'll give you that information and walk through it, but we're always cautious because that's reflective of where we ship products versus where it's actually consumed so, and it's really hard for us to see regional weakness and also it extremely pronounced in a market like in industrial just because of the tens and thousands of customers that make up that market.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: So do you have a follow-on, Harlan?
componenttext: So do you have a follow-on, Harlan?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, so I think last quarter, you said that -- Kevin said that they were going to bring down utilizations. Did you in fact, bring them down? And directionally, what do you expect to head into the third quarter? And dollar inventory stayed relatively flat
componenttext: Sure, so I think last quarter, you said that -- Kevin said that they were going to bring down utilizations. Did you in fact, bring them down? And directionally, what do you expect to head into the third quarter? And dollar inventory stayed relatively flat, does the team expect this to come down in Q3, just given the weaker demand profile?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Harlan. In fact, we did reduced utilization in the factories in the second quarter and inventory actually came in right about where we expected at 126 days. And given the outlook that we have just described to you, we do intend to further reduce facu
componenttext: Yes, Harlan. In fact, we did reduced utilization in the factories in the second quarter and inventory actually came in right about where we expected at 126 days. And given the outlook that we have just described to you, we do intend to further reduce faculty utilization in the third quarter and we expect the result of that is that our inventories will probably come down somewhat in the third quarter as a result of the reductions that we're planning for 3Q as well as 2Q. It just takes a while for them to flow through the system.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Harlan.
componenttext: Thanks, Harlan.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to James Covello from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to James Covello from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question is on consolidation and you guys had been very clear in your articulation of what you look for and what the parameters are over time. But I have a couple of specific questions about consolidation in the current environment. Does the current
componenttext: First question is on consolidation and you guys had been very clear in your articulation of what you look for and what the parameters are over time. But I have a couple of specific questions about consolidation in the current environment. Does the current environment where revenues for the industry are on some pretty sharp declines, does that change the view on near-term consolidation in the sense that you worry about paying a multiple for a cash flow stream that's going to wind up being much lower over the next 12, 18 and 24 months, than what it currently is? Or does that create more of an incremental opportunity? I'd love your perspective on that.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jim. The timing doesn't enter into our thinking, so some of the points that you just brought up, although they'd make for an interesting discussion, they don't actually alter the way we tend to think about M&A. As we've discussed in the past, first,
componenttext: Yes, Jim. The timing doesn't enter into our thinking, so some of the points that you just brought up, although they'd make for an interesting discussion, they don't actually alter the way we tend to think about M&A. As we've discussed in the past, first, the most important thing is that any potential M&A consideration has to be consistent with our strategy and in our mind, that's going to be something that's going to be focused on helping drive our success in the Analog space. And then beyond that, as you were alluding to in your comments there, we have been and expect to continue to be quite disciplined on making sure that we can get a return on what we spend. Clearly, at some of the prices today that you might see as certain companies out there, factor in a premium, I'm looking at -- what I've seen in some other companies, getting the 3% return, 4% return doesn't seem like a good long-term strategy for maximizing shareholder value. And so our inclination is to make sure returns can see their way past our cost of capital in a reasonable timeframe, and we'll stay disciplined on that front.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And for the follow-up, how do you think about what the company's long-term growth rate is in this environment? I mean, it was good last year. We're in a tougher environment now, we're kind of down in a year-over-year basis for revenues this quarter and ma
componenttext: And for the follow-up, how do you think about what the company's long-term growth rate is in this environment? I mean, it was good last year. We're in a tougher environment now, we're kind of down in a year-over-year basis for revenues this quarter and maybe flattish for the year if we look at the normal seasonality in the back half. This might be overly negative to kind of take this snapshot in time for long-term growth, maybe last year was overly positive. Do you think something kind of in between what you'll achieve this year and what you achieved last year is a reasonable view on what long-term normalized revenue growth could be?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you're probably thinking about it right, Jim. You should look at over periods of time like that, not start from the wrong quarter. At a high level, we take a look and we make the assumption that some factor in the market will continue to grow. Let
componenttext: I think you're probably thinking about it right, Jim. You should look at over periods of time like that, not start from the wrong quarter. At a high level, we take a look and we make the assumption that some factor in the market will continue to grow. Let's call it, 2x global GDP and that's on increased content into industrial and automotive that will continue to drive demand. It's then a question of, what do you think GDP is going to do over the long-term? The global GDP. And clearly, it does appear that in certainly in the last 3 or 4 years and probably the next few years, it has been slower than what we saw in the prior decade or decade before that. So the overall industry, again in our view, will probably grow at about 2x global GDP and the global GDP is the real wild card here. Its trying to figure out how fast that will grow and we're preparing ourselves for the fact that it probably doesn't see any robust growth to help us and therefore, we have to focus on execution to making ourselves stronger internally.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I'd add to that, that our business model is robust even in a weak environment like this, [indiscernible] lots of cash and we've got the capacity to support much stronger rates of growth if that were to show up. So it'll be a lot more fun if we ge
componenttext: Yes, and I'd add to that, that our business model is robust even in a weak environment like this, [indiscernible] lots of cash and we've got the capacity to support much stronger rates of growth if that were to show up. So it'll be a lot more fun if we get into an environment where GDP growth is stronger and everyone can argue what the multiplier on semiconductor growth rates overall are. But we can still operate and produce lots of cash even in these weaker markets and we'll look forward to having more fun when it's stronger. So thanks, Jim.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And the next question comes from John Pitzer with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kevin, I guess, the first question is you took some utilization action in the June quarter, but gross margins are actually up sequentially and very healthy, is the way we're thinking about this is the June quarter utilization actions impact September, Sep
componenttext: Kevin, I guess, the first question is you took some utilization action in the June quarter, but gross margins are actually up sequentially and very healthy, is the way we're thinking about this is the June quarter utilization actions impact September, September impacts December, and specifically, can you help me think about how I should be thinking about the gross margin range in the September quarter, around some of the utilization action you're taking?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Jim, we've got a couple of things going on there. Clearly, as we see more of our revenue coming from industrial and automotive, that has an attractive profit mix and so you saw some of that in the second quarter. You heard Dave's prepared remarks
componenttext: Yes, so Jim, we've got a couple of things going on there. Clearly, as we see more of our revenue coming from industrial and automotive, that has an attractive profit mix and so you saw some of that in the second quarter. You heard Dave's prepared remarks talking about the strength that we saw in the quarter. That's clearly, having a benefit to our gross margins even in the light of -- lightening up on our utilization a little bit. You are correct that utilization changes don't have an immediate impact, they tend to -- it takes a few months worth to roll through the system, so some of that was in the second quarter. More of it will be in third quarter. But we also had lower overall manufacturing cost, as we begin to see depreciation starting to slowly trickle off. We're becoming much more efficient and our factories were getting more and more of our revenue off of much lower cost, 300-millimeter. So you got a number of things combined that are keeping those margins in a pretty healthy state. As we look into next quarter, I wouldn't expect a significant, any kind of material change in that particular metric in the third quarter.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then as for my follow up, you guys are constantly kind of trimming the portfolio. One of the things that's been talked about is whether or not you're going to plan to do sort of power on the new skylight platform. I'm just kind of curious as to how ki
componenttext: And then as for my follow up, you guys are constantly kind of trimming the portfolio. One of the things that's been talked about is whether or not you're going to plan to do sort of power on the new skylight platform. I'm just kind of curious as to how kind of the PC business and your desire to want to participate there is impacting either the June quarter results or more importantly, the guide in September. Is there sort of a hit coming because you're not going to participate there? Again, if there is, can you help us quantify the size of the PC business today and kind of where it goes over time.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So John, what you're seeing in our results is -- has nothing to do with the investments on a V-core product line. And I just -- I'll just say that we continually look at our investments and we want to obviously, invest in places where we think that,
componenttext: Yes. So John, what you're seeing in our results is -- has nothing to do with the investments on a V-core product line. And I just -- I'll just say that we continually look at our investments and we want to obviously, invest in places where we think that, that will lead to sustainable revenue, a differentiated position and solid return. So there's portions within V-core that are more attractive and less commoditized than others. So we're continuing to make those investments. So we know that there have been rumors out there that we're exiting the space in total, and that's not true. But again, these are fairly small tweaks to where we direct our R&D resources, and those teams are off investing in other areas and producing products that we believe will just give us longer-term, better results. So I'll contrast that to a market where we may have exited like wireless where we're actually reducing and exiting a market, and we're not doing that here. So I hope that helps.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: A product mix question first. Within your Analog space, you guys obviously, have done a great job over time. A little curious as to an explanation why the HVAL side is growing much faster year-over-year over the last couple of quarters versus HPA specific
componenttext: A product mix question first. Within your Analog space, you guys obviously, have done a great job over time. A little curious as to an explanation why the HVAL side is growing much faster year-over-year over the last couple of quarters versus HPA specifically? I recall asking questions about HPA investments in the past and that seemed to be an area of extreme focus, given its high profitability. But the growth doesn't seem to be keeping up with HVAL. So any color on that would be helpful.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ross. Yes, I think if you look at both HVAL as well as HPA, those businesses have different exposures to various end markets. And actually, both of those businesses have a higher exposure to both industrial as well as communications equipment. You'l
componenttext: Sure, Ross. Yes, I think if you look at both HVAL as well as HPA, those businesses have different exposures to various end markets. And actually, both of those businesses have a higher exposure to both industrial as well as communications equipment. You'll see a business like HVAL that will have a higher exposure to personal electronics and automotive. Yes, good point. So that's really what you're seeing in those results. Do you have a follow-up?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, switching gears quickly, but kind of a follow-on to John's earlier question. Any sort of color you can provide on the OpEx side? It's helpful to have gross margin relatively flattish, but how do you adjust the OpEx given that the revenues have been a
componenttext: Yes, switching gears quickly, but kind of a follow-on to John's earlier question. Any sort of color you can provide on the OpEx side? It's helpful to have gross margin relatively flattish, but how do you adjust the OpEx given that the revenues have been a little challenged looking forward.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. We've already taken action on the OpEx side. We have announced 1.5 years ago now, the actions we are taking in better processing in Japan. And those are pretty much complete now. You're seeing those benefits, OpEx in the results that we turned
componenttext: Yes, John. We've already taken action on the OpEx side. We have announced 1.5 years ago now, the actions we are taking in better processing in Japan. And those are pretty much complete now. You're seeing those benefits, OpEx in the results that we turned in the last couple of quarters. These short-term fluctuations in revenue, we don't let those lead us to rash decisions that could have a negative impact on us. We make longer-term decisions based upon strategy. As we look in the third quarter, if you look at the last couple of years, 2Q to 3Q, OpEx has been flat to roughly down. I don't expect anything different than recent history as we go into third quarter of this year.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ross.
componenttext: Thank you, Ross.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vivek Arya with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: For the first question, you mentioned this 50% decline in Wireless Infrastructure. If you could help us quantify what proportion of your sales that is now versus last year. And the thing that I'm really curious about is that, and it's not just Texas Instr
componenttext: For the first question, you mentioned this 50% decline in Wireless Infrastructure. If you could help us quantify what proportion of your sales that is now versus last year. And the thing that I'm really curious about is that, and it's not just Texas Instruments question we are seeing that from and others, there is really no slowdown in mobile data consumption, there is no slowdown in LTE users. So why are you seeing such a large decline in Wireless Infrastructure buildout? Is it just an excess inventory of base stations? Is it a move away from your products? Is it a share issue? If you could help me understand that, it'd be very helpful.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Vivek, our communications equipment market is at the end of last year was about 17%, the largest sector inside of that was Wireless infrastructure, about 10%. So we've given you the color on half the size. We haven't go through all the equipment
componenttext: Sure. So Vivek, our communications equipment market is at the end of last year was about 17%, the largest sector inside of that was Wireless infrastructure, about 10%. So we've given you the color on half the size. We haven't go through all the equipment percentages, but that'll get you into the ZIP code of the impact to our business. And it's interesting that you bring it up. It continues to be actually be a very good market for us. It's one that we're continuing to make investments. We have dialed back some of the investments a year or so ago, inside of Embedded Processing, but that's really a view that, that market over time, that carrier CapEx won't -- isn't going to go up, that it probably will decline slightly as we look over the next 5 and 10 years, and perhaps longer. But carrier CapEx isn't going to 0, and that revenue will return. It has been notoriously just a choppy market and it's just the dynamics of the market, the way the tenders go out and the way the OEMs have to prepare to deliver that product. Oftentimes, it's in a 30 or 60-day window. So this isn't new to us. We're use to it. We can still make a lot of money and generate a lot of cash from this market. So we'll continue to do that. But it is just choppy. So that's just a characteristic, and I think as you talk to other semiconductor suppliers that supply into that market, that's pretty consistent, I think with what all of us see. So do you have a follow-up, Vivek?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dave. So on my follow-up, I'm wondering if 75% is still that right incremental gross margin number to think of, because you are guiding sales to the midpoint to go up somewhat, but you're saying gross margins will be flattish. And as part of that, do
componenttext: Yes, Dave. So on my follow-up, I'm wondering if 75% is still that right incremental gross margin number to think of, because you are guiding sales to the midpoint to go up somewhat, but you're saying gross margins will be flattish. And as part of that, does this slowdown in sales have any impact on how soon you move your capacity over to 450-millimeter.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Vivek, the 75% fall through is still probably a pretty good one to use, but keep in mind, it is noisy from quarter-to-quarter, it's something you should look over a multiquarter period as we move through time. Clearly, you'll get good product margin
componenttext: Yes, Vivek, the 75% fall through is still probably a pretty good one to use, but keep in mind, it is noisy from quarter-to-quarter, it's something you should look over a multiquarter period as we move through time. Clearly, you'll get good product margin fall through as we go into next quarter. But as I mentioned, we're also dialing back some of the factory starts, we have moving parts inside there. But we took over a longer period of time just a quarter, that's when you start seeing that 75%. As to migrating product of to -- I think you said 450 million?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: He meant 300 [indiscernible] .
componenttext: He meant 300 [indiscernible] .

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't have that on the radar. The 300-millimeter, we will continue to do what we have been doing in the past, and that is many of our new products that are released are being released on 300-millimeter, and that becomes even more valuable to the c
componenttext: Yes, we don't have that on the radar. The 300-millimeter, we will continue to do what we have been doing in the past, and that is many of our new products that are released are being released on 300-millimeter, and that becomes even more valuable to the companies and move forward. Keep in mind what we talked back in the February call, and in addition to our fab, which is capable of about $5 billion of total 300-millimeter Analog revenue, we've also begun the conversion of our DMOS6 factory, which will provide an additional $3 billion of Analog revenue capability. So with that kind of conversion underway, clearly new products that we're releasing are being biased towards 300-millimeter versus 200. Active products on 200 for the most part, will continue where they're at.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add to that, as we had indicated before, the qualifications as Kevin said, DMOS6 that conversion is underway, and we expect the qualification to be completed by the end of the year, we're so on track for that. So thank you, Vivek.
componenttext: And I'll just add to that, as we had indicated before, the qualifications as Kevin said, DMOS6 that conversion is underway, and we expect the qualification to be completed by the end of the year, we're so on track for that. So thank you, Vivek.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Christopher Caso with Susquehanna Financial Group.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Christopher Caso with Susquehanna Financial Group.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig into the industrial markets a little more deeply. You had talked about that being a bit weaker-than-expected in the quarter and then recognize that you're going into one of the seasonally weaker quarters for industrial, and I'm sure you he
componenttext: I wanted to dig into the industrial markets a little more deeply. You had talked about that being a bit weaker-than-expected in the quarter and then recognize that you're going into one of the seasonally weaker quarters for industrial, and I'm sure you heard the commentary from one of your competitors earlier today. Can you help us to just get some perspective on what your customers are telling you in that market? And I know you don't like to give commentary going forward or what's baked into your guidance, but just to kind of help ground us and how you're thinking about that particular market at this point.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris, not a lot to add. It was again, I use the word incrementally weaker. We gave you the color that we saw growth in half the sectors and that was offset. So even inside of that, there's a bit of choppiness. I think as we look forward, and obvious
componenttext: Yes, Chris, not a lot to add. It was again, I use the word incrementally weaker. We gave you the color that we saw growth in half the sectors and that was offset. So even inside of that, there's a bit of choppiness. I think as we look forward, and obviously, as we get the demand signals both in orders as well as from what we can see from consignment through our distributors, there's signals that we look at there. And as Kevin mentioned earlier, I think people are just taking a more cautious outlook in the third quarter. So besides that, probably don't have too much to add.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The one thing I'd remind you of is that industrial is about 31% of our revenue in 2014, and our recollection is that no single sector in that market was bigger than 4%. So we're talking about a lot of really small customers. So it's not a really 1 custome
componenttext: The one thing I'd remind you of is that industrial is about 31% of our revenue in 2014, and our recollection is that no single sector in that market was bigger than 4%. So we're talking about a lot of really small customers. So it's not a really 1 customer that can give us a signal, what's going on it? It seems to be a broad-based reconsideration on the part of participants in that space as to their outlook for growth in the second half.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good point. Chris, you have a follow-on?
componenttext: That's a good point. Chris, you have a follow-on?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, as following on to that. Perhaps you could talk about what you think customers are doing with inventory now, and I know you had talked about your distributors, taking some inventory out of the channel, again as they will likely reconsider what's goi
componenttext: Sure, as following on to that. Perhaps you could talk about what you think customers are doing with inventory now, and I know you had talked about your distributors, taking some inventory out of the channel, again as they will likely reconsider what's going on the second half. Do you expect that the end customers are doing similar and on top of that, what do you expect the distributors do with inventory as the go forward? Do you think the inventory levels can get leaner than where they are right now?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in general, we believe that custom inventories are lean. As we work our way through the reports and some of the anecdotal from last quarter's report as well as the anecdotal information that we get from our sales teams. And of course, there's alwa
componenttext: Yes, so in general, we believe that custom inventories are lean. As we work our way through the reports and some of the anecdotal from last quarter's report as well as the anecdotal information that we get from our sales teams. And of course, there's always the exceptions like within Wireless Infrastructure as that market goes through, it's adjustments. So it is -- with inventory in our distributers, at 3.5 weeks, that is a historically low period in my tenure as well as Kevin's, so and we really think that's reflective, Chris, that of confidence from distributors that they believe that they can get the product that they need from us. Obviously, it's driven overall because of the consignment programs that allow them to just operationally to run it at those levels. And I think there is a belief that the confidence and stable lead times and the availability of product is probably working its way out into the customer base as well. It's harder for us to actually have that direct visibility as Kevin talked about, we're talking about 100,000 customers, so it's hard to have that collectively. So thanks, Chris.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Ian Ing with MKM Partners.
componenttext: And we'll go to Ian Ing with MKM Partners.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kevin, you talked about orders increasing every month in the quarter. Do you have any order commentary quarter-to-date? And I'm assuming we're entering Q3 with a relatively strong backlog, how much more conservative are turns assumptions to meet guidance?
componenttext: Kevin, you talked about orders increasing every month in the quarter. Do you have any order commentary quarter-to-date? And I'm assuming we're entering Q3 with a relatively strong backlog, how much more conservative are turns assumptions to meet guidance?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: As we did mention early on, orders increased each month in the second quarter, and I will just say as to orders for this quarter, they're consistent with the guidance range that we gave early in the call. We did have a book-to-bill in second quarter of 1.
componenttext: As we did mention early on, orders increased each month in the second quarter, and I will just say as to orders for this quarter, they're consistent with the guidance range that we gave early in the call. We did have a book-to-bill in second quarter of 1.01, so we did build a little bit of backlog, but I would call it a dramatic amount. It's consistent though, I think with the outlook that we have offered before in the third quarter.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I'll just remind you, Ian, I'm sure you probably know that we've got 60% of our revenues that go through distribution. 60% of that is supported by consignment and about 55% of TI's revenues overall is by consignment. Just be careful with the book
componenttext: Yes, and I'll just remind you, Ian, I'm sure you probably know that we've got 60% of our revenues that go through distribution. 60% of that is supported by consignment and about 55% of TI's revenues overall is by consignment. Just be careful with the book-to-bill and part of the reason why we don't highlight it is because it just applies to a smaller portion to -- of our actual revenues and that backlog isn't necessarily reflective, completely of the demand that we actually see. So do you have a follow-on?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think you've done a really good job of highlighting your competitive advantages, broad portfolio, growing into your manufacture assets. I mean what's the response to scenarios where there could be some demand in end markets on a permanent secular d
componenttext: Yes. I think you've done a really good job of highlighting your competitive advantages, broad portfolio, growing into your manufacture assets. I mean what's the response to scenarios where there could be some demand in end markets on a permanent secular decline? I mean if you look at it like comms infrastructure, PC, some of the consumer markets, I mean, how do you address the potential for some permanent declines in some of these end markets?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's -- I've been in this for quite a lot of time, Ian. There's always some markets that's in decline, other markets that are actually in the growth phase. So the examples you just offered, if in fact, they turn out to be in a secular decline, th
componenttext: Well, there's -- I've been in this for quite a lot of time, Ian. There's always some markets that's in decline, other markets that are actually in the growth phase. So the examples you just offered, if in fact, they turn out to be in a secular decline, the offsetting markets for that, the most obvious one is automotive, where we're seeing significant content growth, not just us, but many in the industry. Seeing significant content growth and we're still in the very early stages of that content, penetrating automobiles. So that's probably a secular growth market that I would suggest would probably add for a decade or more. So that's a great opportunity for the industry in general and for us, in particular because we've been focused there for a number of years now. And then there's the broader industrial market where we're seeing an increase in usage of semiconductors and equipments in those markets that simply we've never used before. And as people are using semiconductor in those spaces, they're finding new applications and needs for more semiconductors. So while there maybe some markets or sectors that could be in secular decline, there are others that are in secular growth and in general, that leads us to the belief that I commented on earlier in the call, that we think that the industry overall will grow at about 2x of global GDP because you've got these kind of underlying changes going on and how semiconductor are being used across our economy.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I could add too that, even if we look at a market like PCs that probably over the next 10 and 20 years will be on defined like that. We can take 2 actions. One is we'll spend differently today than we would've spent 10 and 15 years ago, inside of
componenttext: Yes, and I could add too that, even if we look at a market like PCs that probably over the next 10 and 20 years will be on defined like that. We can take 2 actions. One is we'll spend differently today than we would've spent 10 and 15 years ago, inside of that market. But we can still find opportunities where products will actually live through 1 product cycle to the next and still have long-lived positions even inside of a market like that. And certainly, PCs aren't going away any time soon, so there's still quite a bit of money that can be made in those markets. So thank you, Ian.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's actually not a bad way to think about it Ambrish, because in fact, the way that we are operating the 300-millimeter fab today, our fab is near full equipped utilization. In other words, it's -- we don't have it equipped to full capacity, but to the
componenttext: That's actually not a bad way to think about it Ambrish, because in fact, the way that we are operating the 300-millimeter fab today, our fab is near full equipped utilization. In other words, it's -- we don't have it equipped to full capacity, but to the extent that we have it equipped, we try to keep it quite highly loaded. So the adjustments that we take on loading, generally impact the 200. There may be some impact in 300 as well, but it generally impacts the 200 millimeter factories.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: And I'll make, just add that any product that runs any measurable volume will often source in multiple factories, so it could actually be sourced on a 200-millimeter fab as well as a 300-millimeter fab. And as you know, the economics of getting 40% lower cost per chip on a 300-millimeter obviously, will tilt us into starting that 300-millimeter wafer. So thank you, Ambrish.

componenttext: Actually I have 2. I guess, first of all, if you look at 2015 as the whole year, usually you're targeting for the -- to sort of grow roughly 2x GDP. We don't know what GDP is going to be, but if you assume a seasonal fourth calendar quarter, it implies that revenue this year is down like 250 basis points. It definitely seems to be under growing whatever GDP comes out to be this year. So I guess my question is, do you think that any of this share, will you end up to have lost any market share this year? I know you usually target up about 40 bps per year, and then I have a follow-up.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

componenttext: Yes, Tim. So what we're talking about, again long-term growth rate was how the question was asked earlier and long-term growth rate we believe will be about 2x global GDP. Just like you see noise in the quarter, as you probably can see noise in the year. For example, last year, the industry arguably grew considerably faster than 2x global GDP. This year, it is -- have to grow less than global GDP. But I think it is going to have that kind of noise to deal with. I don't think it's going to be mechanically imposed into a formula with precision. As we look out for the reasons that we talked about, increasing penetration in certain markets, especially in auto and industrial, that will continue to require some magnitude of content and there'll be growth inside that. From a market share standpoint, we'll be able to answer that at the end of the year, but I'd say were rough to a darn good start so far.

componenttext: Yes, Tim. We don't believe that there is something called a seasonal average in our space. When you go and take a look at any of those quarters, the variation is so wide that there's not really anything meaningful in there. I think if you look at those 2Q to 3Q growth rates, you see 0s to high single digits, and I don't think you can derive too much out of that. I think you have to look at it in the context of the current global environment, certainly a lot of negative news flow coming out of Europe and some out of China and so on. We had a slow start to the year in the Americas because of weather and the port issues on the West Coast. I think what we're seeing is what we talked about early in the call, which is that on a macro level, our customers are looking and adjusting their expectation for growth in the second half, and they're tweaking that down a little bit versus what they had anticipated coming into the year.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our second quarter '15 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining our second quarter '15 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.
For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations on our website at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through TI's website. A replay will be available through the web. 
This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectations. We encourage you to review the notice regarding forward-looking statements contained in the earnings release published today as well as TI's most recent SEC filings for a more complete description.
I'll start with a quick summary. Revenue declined 2% from a year ago, inclusive of notably weak demand in communications equipment and continued strong demand in automotive. In the quarter, we also had about a $45 million negative impact year-over-year from currency exchange rates, as expected. Even in this environment, our core businesses of Analog and Embedded Processing together grew slightly year-over-year and comprised 85% of second quarter revenue. 
Analog delivered its eighth consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth. Earnings per share were $0.65, up $0.03 from a year ago. With that backdrop, Kevin and I will move on to details of our performance, which we believe continues to be representative of the ongoing strength of TI's business model.
In the second quarter, our cash flow from operations was $820 million. We believe that free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long-term. Free cash flow for the trailing 12-month period was $3.6 billion, up 13% from a year ago. Free cash flow margin was 27% of revenue, consistent with our targeted range of 20% to 30%. This is a 2 percentage point improvement from a year ago period and we believe reflects our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy. The latter of which includes our growing 300-millimeter Analog output and the opportunistic purchases of assets ahead of demand. 
We also believe that free cash flow will only be valued if it's returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business. For the trailing 12-month period, we returned $4.1 billion of cash to investors through a combination of stock repurchases and dividends.
Analog revenue grew 3% from a year ago due to High Volume Analog & Logic. Power Management also grew. Silicon Valley Analog was even and High Performance Analog declined. As mentioned earlier, this is the eighth consecutive quarter of year-over-year growth for Analog. Embedded Processing revenue declined 2% from a year ago, after 10 consecutive quarters of year-on-year growth. This decline was due to the weakness in wireless infrastructure equipment for the Processor product line. In contrast, the Connectivity and Microcontroller product lines grew. 
In our Other segment, revenue declined 17% from a year ago due to custom ASIC products, which are highly concentrated in wireless infrastructure equipment. DLP products also declined while calculators grew. In distribution, resales increased 8% from a year ago. Weeks of inventory decreased by 1 week to just above 3.5 weeks, which is a historically low level. We believe this inventory level reflects an environment of good product availability due to healthy TI inventories and stable lead times, which together drive high customer service metrics. It's also important to note that inventory in our distribution channel has decreased over the past few years because we've structurally changed how inventory is managed with our consignment program. 
Now I'll provide some insight into our revenue performance by end markets versus a year ago, which in total, resulted in the revenue in the bottom half of our range due to more significant softness in communications equipment and incremental softness in industrial. Specifically, by end market, automotive had strong growth with almost all sectors inside this market growing at double-digit rates. Industrial revenue was about flat in contrast to last quarter's year-over-year growth and was incrementally weaker than we expected. More specifically, there was growth in about half the sectors inside of industrial, but these were offset by declines in others. 
Personal electronics grew, in total, due to 1 large customer. Outside of this customer, almost every sector inside of personal electronics declined, including PCs, as we expected. Communications equipment declined, primarily due to the wireless infrastructure sector, which was down about 50% from a year ago, even weaker than we had expected going into the quarter. And enterprise systems declined due to DLP projectors, as we had expected. 
In general, as we look to the third quarter, the strength in demand varies by end markets, but our market in total is expected to be weaker year-over-year and our outlook for TI revenue and earnings is consistent with this environment. While we don't control the near-term environment of our markets, we do control the focus on making TI stronger through our approach to manufacturing and technology, the breadth of our product portfolio, the reach of our market channels and our diverse and long-lived positions. These 4 attributes, taken together, are at the core of what makes TI unique and capable of long-term free cash flow growth. 
Kevin will now review profitability, capital management and our outlook.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $1.88 billion or 58.2% of revenue. Gross profit was even from the year ago quarter despite lower revenue, as we benefited from lower manufacturing costs. Gross margin was up 110 b
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave, and good afternoon, everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $1.88 billion or 58.2% of revenue. Gross profit was even from the year ago quarter despite lower revenue, as we benefited from lower manufacturing costs. Gross margin was up 110 basis points. 
Moving to operating expenses, combined R&D and SG&A expenses of $790 million, were down $31 million from a year ago. The decline reflects the targeted reductions in Embedded Processing in Japan, which have been completed. Acquisition charges were $82 million, almost all of which were the ongoing amortization of intangibles, which is a noncash expense. 
Operating profit was $1.01 billion, up 3% from the year-ago quarter. Operating profit margin was 31.3% of revenue, up 150 basis points from a year ago. Operating profit margin for Analog was 35.5%. Operating profit margin for Embedded Processing was 19.6%, almost 5 percentage points higher from a year ago, as we focused our investments for growth and now see the benefit from our plan to better align resources with the opportunities that we are pursuing. Net income in the second quarter was $696 million or $0.65 per share.
Let me now comment on our capital management results, starting with our cash generation. Cash flow from operations was $820 million in the quarter. Inventory days were 126, as we had expected. As our business model has evolved, we continue to evaluate our inventory model. Capital expenditures were $125 million in the quarter. 
As a reminder, in April, we retired $250 million of debt. In addition, we issued $500 million of 5-year debt at a coupon rate of 1.75%. Including the $750 million of debt due in August of this year, we'll have retired $1 billion, while having issued $500 million in debt this year. This is consistent with our practice over the past few years. This will leave total debt of $4.125 billion, with a weighted average coupon rate of 2.3%. 
On a trailing 12-month basis, cash flow from operations was $4.1 billion, up 14% from the same period a year ago. Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $476 million or 4% of revenue. As a reminder, our long-term expectation is for capital expenditures to be about 4% of revenue, which includes a 300-millimeter Analog plan discussed in our February capital management call. Free cash flow for the past 12 months was $3.61 billion or 27% of revenue. Free cash flow was 13% higher than a year ago. 
As we said, we believe free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long-term and will be valued only if it is returned to shareholders or productively invested in the businesses. And as we've noted, our intent is to return 100% of our free cash flow plus any proceeds we receive from the exercise of equity compensation, minus net debt retirement. 
In the second quarter, we paid $354 million in dividends and repurchased $654 million of our stock for a total return of $1.01 billion. Total cash returned in the past 12 months was $4.08 billion. Outstanding share count was reduced by 3.1% over the past 12 months and by 40% since the beginning of 2005. These returns demonstrate our confidence in TI's business model and our commitment to return excess cash to our shareholders.
Fundamental to our commitment to return cash are our cash management and tax practices. We ended the second quarter with $3.31 billion of cash and short-term investments. TI's U.S. entities own 82% of our cash. Because our cash is largely onshore, it is readily available for a variety of uses, including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock. TI's orders in the quarter were $3.26 billion, down 2% from a year ago. 
Turning to our outlook. We expect TI revenue in the range of $3.15 billion to $3.41 billion in the third quarter. As we said, while strength in demand varies by end markets, our market in total is expected to be weaker year-over-year in the third quarter than it was in the second. This includes a negative impact of about $40 million due to the changes in currency exchange rates. We expect third quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $0.62 to $0.72. 
Acquisition charges, which are noncash amortization charge, will remain even and hold at about $80 million per quarter until the third quarter of 2019. It will then decline to about $15 million per quarter for 2 additional years. Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate in 2015 remains about 30%, and this is the tax rate you should use for the third quarter and for the year. 
In summary, even in a weaker market environment such as we saw in the second quarter and expect in the third, our business model, which is built upon the 4 attributes that Dave mentioned earlier, delivered strong free cash flow. As a reminder, these attributes are our approach to manufacturing technology, the breadth of our product portfolio, the reach of our market channels and our diverse and long-lived positions. We believe these attributes in combination are unique to TI and they are sustainable, giving us the ability to provide continuing returns to our shareholders. 
With that, let me turn it back to Dave

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, a little bit of a longer-term question, could you just give us your sense, having the benefit of 6, 7 months of hindsight on, why the semi market is kind of sucking wind right now? And then, I think, the last time things were like this was '11 an
componenttext: I guess, a little bit of a longer-term question, could you just give us your sense, having the benefit of 6, 7 months of hindsight on, why the semi market is kind of sucking wind right now? And then, I think, the last time things were like this was '11 and '12, so if you could give us a sense of comparison on how things are right now versus 2011 and 2012? Is it better? Is it worse? Is it the same? Do we not know?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, I'll go ahead and take a stab at that, I guess. I think that what we're seeing right now is basically customers adjusting their expectations as to the growth rates for the remainder of the year and just toning down a little bit on where they're at.
componenttext: Chris, I'll go ahead and take a stab at that, I guess. I think that what we're seeing right now is basically customers adjusting their expectations as to the growth rates for the remainder of the year and just toning down a little bit on where they're at. We actually believe that what we're seeing is more a symptom of like a macro-based kind of events. Markets getting a bit more cautious, especially with all the news flow in the financial markets, things you heard in Europe, things you heard in China. But the fact is the signs that we're seeing suggest to us that we're in a traditional kind of market macro-driven, not necessarily a semi-cycle per se. We continue to see lead times reflect work, cancellations remain low, distributor inventory is at historically low levels, as Dave mentioned. So all things put together, I think, what we're just seeing is a growth rate on a macro level that's probably slower going into the second half than what people thought coming into the first half. As to comparisons to 2011, 2012, there were too many things going on back then. We had earthquake events in Japan that I can recall. We had flooding in Thailand. I don't think there's really comparable events that we can talk about on that front, Chris.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'll just make a comment on both revenue and order linearity in the quarter. In both cases, revenue and orders increased each month during the quarter. I think, as you look at the end market detail as I just had walked through, in general, we saw
componenttext: Okay. So I'll just make a comment on both revenue and order linearity in the quarter. In both cases, revenue and orders increased each month during the quarter. I think, as you look at the end market detail as I just had walked through, in general, we saw automotive was strong with all the sectors inside of that growing, or all but one growing at double-digit rates. Industrial revenue was flat. Just contrasting that to last quarter's year-over-year growth, we didn't see growth there and it was incrementally weaker than we had expected. And as we had talked about inside of there, we really saw about half of the sectors increase. And that, of course, was offset by declines in the other sectors. Personal electronics, as we talked about, grew in total, due to specifically 1 large customer. And outside of that customer, we actually saw almost every sector decline, including PCs, as were expected. Comms infrastructure, as we mentioned, was impacted by -- or comms equipment was impacted by wireless infrastructure, and that was down 50% from a year ago. So -- and that actually was weaker than what we had expected when we started the quarter. And then, the last, enterprise systems declined due to DLP projectors, as we had expected. So that's kind of a summary of what we saw by end market. So thanks, Chris.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2015
