componenttext: Yes, John, as we look into the fourth quarter, we're expecting our wafer starts will probably be flat to this quarter, so no significant change in starts there. And keep in mind that the wafers that we start in fourth quarter, other than the first few weeks of the quarter are mostly for what we expected in follow-on quarters. We built quite a bit forward to our expectation of when that inventory actually get sold.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then Kevin, my follow up, you guys probably one of the first to start the trend of M&A with the acquisition of National several years back. There's been a lot of speculation in the marketplace about more M&A within the semi space. I know you've talked
componenttext: And then Kevin, my follow up, you guys probably one of the first to start the trend of M&A with the acquisition of National several years back. There's been a lot of speculation in the marketplace about more M&A within the semi space. I know you've talked about this in the past and I'm kind of curious about getting some updated thoughts from your perspective about the advantage from here, given you're already the scale of M&A and how you guys are sort of thinking about that.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, so I guess it will take me a second to kind of go through those thoughts there. Of course, we acquired National back in 2011, so we probably got ahead of the game versus where people are at today. But we spent the intervening time period really
componenttext: Yes, John, so I guess it will take me a second to kind of go through those thoughts there. Of course, we acquired National back in 2011, so we probably got ahead of the game versus where people are at today. But we spent the intervening time period really driving hard to accelerate 4 attributes that we think in combination are pretty unique to TI and differentiate us quite a bit from our competitors, which may be impacting how some of they're thinking about how to approach their markets. And those 4 attributes are approach to a low cost manufacture and advanced technology. The sheer breadth of our overall portfolio, the reach we have to our customers through our market channels especially with arguably the largest sales force than anybody out there. And the diversity and long-lived positions that we enjoy in the markets with the products that we have. If we look at most companies that are doing today from an M&A front, it appears that some of them are maybe changing their focus and some of them are maybe trying to build scale. We already have what we believe is a significant scale advantage and we believe we're focused on the 2 best opportunities out there, being Analog and Embedded Processing. So we don't -- those 2 reasons are motivating us to think differently about M&A. When we think about M&A, our approach is really to focus on the right strategic fit, one that can generate long term returns and excess free cash flows. So we will focus on the numbers but then acquisition might lead us to and buy strategic fit, I'm talking really our bias is towards Analog. We look at an acquisition and will probably be a company that's broad and catalog, and the diverse customer base and have a large percentage of the revenue coming from industrial and automotive probably have a very talented R&D team. Those will be the sort of attributes that we would look at from a standpoint. From a return standpoint, we look at several metrics, including really making sure that the return on our investment is accretive to our weighted average cost of capital in say 4 years or so. And we also want to make sure that whatever we acquire will continue to expand our free cash flow. So with all that said, and we take a look at what's out there, we have been actually buying our favorite [indiscernible] semiconductor company. I know you don't like to hear it that way, but there are our home stock buybacks. Today, by buying back those share, we are given a 7% free cash flow yield on those acquisitions and we don't have any integration risk and no banker fees, just a whole lot easier way to run the business and focus on customers.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stacy Rasgon with the birds the research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stacy Rasgon with the birds the research.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: For my first question, I'd like to follow up on the industrial market. You said half of your markets were kind of up, year-over-year, half of them are down. That's pretty similar to the same as last quarter, but you do seem to be missing upside versus exp
componenttext: For my first question, I'd like to follow up on the industrial market. You said half of your markets were kind of up, year-over-year, half of them are down. That's pretty similar to the same as last quarter, but you do seem to be missing upside versus expectations. Within industrial, can you give us some idea of which end markets you're actually seeing relative strength versus weakness versus those expectations, and talk a little bit about how your end markets within industrial are concentrated or not?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So great question, Stacy. We've got 14 different sectors that make up our industrial market. And I'll just go through some of those because I think some investors that they focus on industrials is we mean something different than that. So it includes
componenttext: Yes. So great question, Stacy. We've got 14 different sectors that make up our industrial market. And I'll just go through some of those because I think some investors that they focus on industrials is we mean something different than that. So it includes things like factory automation and control, medical and healthcare, building automation, smart grid and energy test and measurement, motor drives, display, space avionics, appliance, power delivery system, point-of-sale lighting, industrial transportation and then a bucket of just other really small stuff. So last year as you know, Stacy, industrial was 31% of our revenues. The largest sector inside of there was 4%. So you can see it's very, very diverse very quickly. And even inside of each of these factors, we've got multiple and equipments that make each of those up. So it was very similar to last quarter where we did see about half of the sectors up and the other sectors down together flat, so there won't -- really any really huge movements and neither we would call out to say that it was an unusual so that's what it looked like. Do you have a follow-on, Stacy?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Around your OpEx, it seems like you came in fairly light in the quarter versus expectations. Why was that? And where do you see OpEx going next quarter?
componenttext: Around your OpEx, it seems like you came in fairly light in the quarter versus expectations. Why was that? And where do you see OpEx going next quarter?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Stacy, on OpEx, if you compare to a year-ago quarter that was really a -- we just had continued cost management going on across the company and we also had the benefit on the year-ago comparison to the actions that we previously announced the Embedded
componenttext: So Stacy, on OpEx, if you compare to a year-ago quarter that was really a -- we just had continued cost management going on across the company and we also had the benefit on the year-ago comparison to the actions that we previously announced the Embedded Processing in Japan, and those are not done. So we get that benefit year-over-year as it relates to sequentially even, as you say coming in the quarter better-than-expected, that's really cost management continuing and also in the second quarter, there were a few items that didn't recur in second and third quarter. And so that give us a good benefits there.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: In Q2, Embedded was up year-over-year for the first time, actually Q2 Embedded was down year-over-year for the first time, I think versus the prior 10 quarters. It inflected higher in Q3. I know you guys said MCU and connectivity drove the growth, but wha
componenttext: In Q2, Embedded was up year-over-year for the first time, actually Q2 Embedded was down year-over-year for the first time, I think versus the prior 10 quarters. It inflected higher in Q3. I know you guys said MCU and connectivity drove the growth, but what end markets helped to return this business back to year-over-year growth? And also what drove the 450 basis point improvement in operating margins?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, so I guess, 2 questions there. I'll take the first one. So as we said, Embedded Processing was driven by Microcontrollers and Connectivity and both of those businesses tend to be very broad market exposures, high exposure to industrial. We've also g
componenttext: Okay, so I guess, 2 questions there. I'll take the first one. So as we said, Embedded Processing was driven by Microcontrollers and Connectivity and both of those businesses tend to be very broad market exposures, high exposure to industrial. We've also got some exposure outside of processors to automotive. And what the -- what drove the weakness in second quarter and the reason why processors declined year-over-year was the exposure to Wireless infrastructure is probably the simplest way to say that, so.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: On operating margin, Harlan, the short answer is we have announced at the end of 2012, some restructuring actions aside. Embedded Processing that would wind up last year. And in fact, they have -- so a lot of that cost is out and so is Brazil's operating
componenttext: On operating margin, Harlan, the short answer is we have announced at the end of 2012, some restructuring actions aside. Embedded Processing that would wind up last year. And in fact, they have -- so a lot of that cost is out and so is Brazil's operating margins coming through very nicely.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll let you squeeze in a third question, but we'll make an exception for you.
componenttext: We'll let you squeeze in a third question, but we'll make an exception for you.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. Last quarter, you guys indicated that you were bringing down utilization in the third quarter to try and reduce inventories. It looks like you guys execute in that the that. Should we anticipate gross margins in Q4 down in line with the
componenttext: I appreciate that. Last quarter, you guys indicated that you were bringing down utilization in the third quarter to try and reduce inventories. It looks like you guys execute in that the that. Should we anticipate gross margins in Q4 down in line with the lower utilizations in Q3?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, Harlan. I'm not going to try to forecast individual lines of the P&L. I'll just bring you back to what I had mentioned when John asked this question. We expect utilization to decline probably utilizations to be above -- excuse me, starts to be about e
componenttext: No, Harlan. I'm not going to try to forecast individual lines of the P&L. I'll just bring you back to what I had mentioned when John asked this question. We expect utilization to decline probably utilizations to be above -- excuse me, starts to be about even in fourth quarter versus third quarter, so we don't expect starts to actually change. The starts are already down third quarter versus second, and third quarter versus a year-ago quarter and the we'll maintain those starts about even going into the second quarter -- going into the fourth quarter.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, yes and the other -- certainly, the other consideration with fourth quarter is what happens to revenue overall. So we have less revenue. So that'll impact gross margins.
componenttext: Thank you, yes and the other -- certainly, the other consideration with fourth quarter is what happens to revenue overall. So we have less revenue. So that'll impact gross margins.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Christopher Danely from Citigroup.
componenttext: Next question comes from Christopher Danely from Citigroup.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if we look at just some sort of normal are reasonable projections for Q4 for 2015, your revenue is going to be flat but your gross margins will be up and your OpEx will be down. If we assume that sort of LAN environment continues into 2016 and revenue
componenttext: So if we look at just some sort of normal are reasonable projections for Q4 for 2015, your revenue is going to be flat but your gross margins will be up and your OpEx will be down. If we assume that sort of LAN environment continues into 2016 and revenue is sort of whatever around the flattish or something like that. Is there anyway that gross margins could go up and OpEx go down again? Can you just kind of take us through the puts and pulls for next year on those?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll go ahead and take you through those sort of things, Chris. First off, I'm hoping that you're wrong in your theory about everything being [indiscernible] next year.
componenttext: Yes, I'll go ahead and take you through those sort of things, Chris. First off, I'm hoping that you're wrong in your theory about everything being [indiscernible] next year.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Me too. I want to keep my job.
componenttext: Me too. I want to keep my job.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: But under that scenario, I think it would -- I doubt that we'd see a whole lot of change in operating expenditures other than just normal annual pay and benefit increases. But on the margin side, on the gross margin side, we'll probably continue to see be
componenttext: But under that scenario, I think it would -- I doubt that we'd see a whole lot of change in operating expenditures other than just normal annual pay and benefit increases. But on the margin side, on the gross margin side, we'll probably continue to see benefit as we see more and more of our production moving to 300-millimeter, which as you will recall give us about 40% chip cost reduction, an overall cost of goods standpoint. So that will certainly benefit our gross margin line. In addition to that, we continue to see an expansion of revenue that's coming out of the industrial automotive space as a percent of total, and those tend to come through at higher gross margins as well as digital roll catalogs products versus custom products inside our mix. And then the last item is that as we talked about for a couple of years now, our CapEx has been running under our depreciation by a couple of points, and that is slowly beginning to close. And in fact, you can see that gap close in -- just in the past 12-month comparison period. So as we look out into 2016, you'll see that gap will close a bit more, so those with a continuation will give us continued tailwind on the gross margin line. You should follow all the way through the operating margin.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I just add to that even though this year, if the revenue projections come in as you said, Chris and our free cash flow margin continued to expand. So that's really what we're focused on. Do you have a follow-up, Chris?
componenttext: Yes, and I just add to that even though this year, if the revenue projections come in as you said, Chris and our free cash flow margin continued to expand. So that's really what we're focused on. Do you have a follow-up, Chris?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so if we look at what revenue did sequentially in Q3, what you're expecting for in Q4? It's pretty even with last year or so and it sounds like even though the business is still kind of, just getting a little bit better, would you characterize the en
componenttext: Yes, so if we look at what revenue did sequentially in Q3, what you're expecting for in Q4? It's pretty even with last year or so and it sounds like even though the business is still kind of, just getting a little bit better, would you characterize the environmental overall as kind of normal? And if it's not normal, then where would be your biggest area of concern or weakness?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, if you look at the midpoint of our guidance, it would suggest that our revenues would be down 2% from the year-ago. That's similar to the number that we just turned is as well as what we saw in the second quarter. So we just described the environme
componenttext: Chris, if you look at the midpoint of our guidance, it would suggest that our revenues would be down 2% from the year-ago. That's similar to the number that we just turned is as well as what we saw in the second quarter. So we just described the environment. It really hasn't changed very much. We just believe that we're operating in a week macroenvironment, and we continue to focus on execution. And I think the business is showing the results of that focus and the strength of the business model. But in general, that's really what we believe that we're operating in.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from William Stein with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from William Stein with SunTrust.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you had a 10% customer in the quarter or if you had any meaningful change in revenue from a single customer that would affect the overall trend of the business in the quarter?
componenttext: I wonder if you had a 10% customer in the quarter or if you had any meaningful change in revenue from a single customer that would affect the overall trend of the business in the quarter?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, we had -- if we look at last year, our largest customer was 8% of revenue. And we don't give customer size variety by quarter. But we expect that, that customer, as they've done well this year, that they could come in at around 10% of our reven
componenttext: Yes, well, we had -- if we look at last year, our largest customer was 8% of revenue. And we don't give customer size variety by quarter. But we expect that, that customer, as they've done well this year, that they could come in at around 10% of our revenue. And I'd say this as we look at that customer, we sell them 100s of devices across multiple products. And if I contrasted that to the last time that we had a customer, it was more than 10%. Most of that revenue was concentrated in just a few parts in a single application and even more specifically than that, it was really 1 function that maybe was that different to the different generation. So we really just had 1 function of that customer. So even inside of this customer, we've got quite a bit of diversity. Do you have a follow-on, Will?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's sort of related to this. You -- the company exited the Wireless apps processor and base band business a few years ago. And I suppose the answer is around the concentration at the part number level. But does the -- does what looks like a growing
componenttext: Yes, it's sort of related to this. You -- the company exited the Wireless apps processor and base band business a few years ago. And I suppose the answer is around the concentration at the part number level. But does the -- does what looks like a growing expansion to the handsets market through -- at least 1 but probably multiple customers, does that concern the company the way that -- in a similar way that caused you to exit some products previously?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, while I'd say that when you heard these opening remarks when we saw growth in personal electronics and without that 1 customer our growing [indiscernible] up-and-down, I think that's also telling us its handsets overall growth better to become the la
componenttext: Yes, while I'd say that when you heard these opening remarks when we saw growth in personal electronics and without that 1 customer our growing [indiscernible] up-and-down, I think that's also telling us its handsets overall growth better to become the larger piece of the personal electronic space. So what's important is to have a lot of different chips that you're selling into, a lot of different customers that you sell into that space and that's exactly what we have. And so from that standpoint, if it were going to participate in personal electronics, you're going to be a -- participating in handsets and there are a lot of very attractive chip opportunities inside handsets. Unlike what we had a number of years ago, as you remembered, the base processors where those parts were basically standardized and commoditizing and your ability to differentiate was diminished and therefore, your ability to attract profits from selling those parts is diminished. Consequently, I see this as kind of different today, given the diversity of products that we're talking about here than the example over the base band of processors 5, 6 [ph] years ago.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I'd add to that. If you look across personal electronics and you add smartphones and tablets and PCs and TVs, and things like that, you're probably -- if you added all those together, you're probably scaring 2.4 billion, 2.5 billion units and eve
componenttext: Yes, and I'd add to that. If you look across personal electronics and you add smartphones and tablets and PCs and TVs, and things like that, you're probably -- if you added all those together, you're probably scaring 2.4 billion, 2.5 billion units and even though that unit pool probably isn't going to grow much, because as Kevin said, there is opportunities to find products that will live through multiple generations that you could sell to multiple customers and places where we'll continue to try to steer our investments overall. So thank you, Will.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Blayne Curtis with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Blayne Curtis with Barclays.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really 2 related questions, one is clarification to the upside in the quarter, it came from Wells, restructuring in industrial, but was that part of what you were calling industrial? And then maybe drew a picture from a geographic perspective is obviously
componenttext: Really 2 related questions, one is clarification to the upside in the quarter, it came from Wells, restructuring in industrial, but was that part of what you were calling industrial? And then maybe drew a picture from a geographic perspective is obviously, that's a negative data point kind of the U.S. industrial market, just any change over the summer with China and I understand some U.S. issues. Just any perspective from a geographic basis.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So let me answer your first question, which if you look at HVAL, HVAL both have a high exposure to automotive, which will help drive those resident revenues and also have exposure to personal electronics as well. It does have some industrial exposur
componenttext: Okay. So let me answer your first question, which if you look at HVAL, HVAL both have a high exposure to automotive, which will help drive those resident revenues and also have exposure to personal electronics as well. It does have some industrial exposure. But I think that those are the areas that will drive that revenue. And you had a follow-up?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The question was just what you're seeing from a geographic perspective, obviously, China is really -- yes.
componenttext: The question was just what you're seeing from a geographic perspective, obviously, China is really -- yes.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if I just look at our regional results year-over-year, revenue was down in Asia and Europe and in U.S. In Japan, it was up. If you look at the broader China market, it really wasn't down differently than what broader Asia was, and that was kind of
componenttext: Yes. So if I just look at our regional results year-over-year, revenue was down in Asia and Europe and in U.S. In Japan, it was up. If you look at the broader China market, it really wasn't down differently than what broader Asia was, and that was kind of down, consistent with our overall revenue. So really didn't see much different. The second thing I'll add is that a lot of times, we're asked by investors, what our exposure to China is or to a particular market. And in our 10-K, we give a very precise number of what we shipped into China, being 44%. But we always like to point out that if you're looking for what exposure to a particular market is, I think most investors are asking, how much of our products is actually consumed there. And so it's a very different number than 44, it's much lower than that because obviously, some of those products that we ship there end up getting shipped into other regions. I'll also point out that we may ship product into a Tier 2 OEM that gets into a European automobile in Europe and then shipped into China, so you can't really look at any of our regional results and understand that. So but overall, probably a good proxy to begin to start the analysis would be to look at what China is as a percentage of GDP and any kind of starter analysis from there.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about your customer inventories. You give us very helpful theory and resale and inventory numbers. But just in general, you had a pretty good year in 2014, a weaker year this year, but my perspective is that the cus
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about your customer inventories. You give us very helpful theory and resale and inventory numbers. But just in general, you had a pretty good year in 2014, a weaker year this year, but my perspective is that the customer inventory management lead time, days held hasn't really changed. Can you just talk about whether you're seeing any inflection there in the last few quarters?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Joe. I would say that of course, the distribution inventory as you said, we could see very well. We've got 55% of our revenues that are on consignment. So for those portions, which will include 60% of our distributor revenue. But we know for that po
componenttext: Sure, Joe. I would say that of course, the distribution inventory as you said, we could see very well. We've got 55% of our revenues that are on consignment. So for those portions, which will include 60% of our distributor revenue. But we know for that portion of our revenue, there is no inventories, so it's exactly 0. So obviously, that's in really good shape. And if you look at the overall, the classic kind of book shift carrying inventory, type portion of our revenue is really about 20% of our revenue and that's where we will carry backlog. Customers will have inventory. So we really don't see any signs that customer inventories are significantly out of whack, I'm sure you can always find pockets here and there. But we believe that they're fairly lean with very few exceptions such as the Wireless infrastructure.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have any follow-on, Joe?
componenttext: Do you have any follow-on, Joe?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I just wanted to follow on infrastructure, you said it was up sequentially recovering from a lower level. Do you have visibility as to whether that sort of China deployments or Western deployments and what do you see the trajectory for that business
componenttext: Yes, I just wanted to follow on infrastructure, you said it was up sequentially recovering from a lower level. Do you have visibility as to whether that sort of China deployments or Western deployments and what do you see the trajectory for that business going forward?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe, so we have -- I would say our exposure in the Wireless infrastructure, if you look at the major OEMs that make up the majority of that market, we'll have a different products exposure, but a fairly consistent exposure across them. So if there's
componenttext: Yes, Joe, so we have -- I would say our exposure in the Wireless infrastructure, if you look at the major OEMs that make up the majority of that market, we'll have a different products exposure, but a fairly consistent exposure across them. So if there's demand in any of the regions, we'll typically participate in that. If you look at by technology, that's often time another constant people to look and we've got a strong position in 3G, slightly stronger position in 4G and even in newer areas that we expect growth in the future that we've been investing in, as an example of small cells. We've been investing, believe we'll have a very strong position there as well. So our numbers aren't so much impacted by a specific region. Firstly, it won't escape either if there's weakness in any particular region.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congrats on the strong results. I know in the past, Dave, you gave the year-over-year. I Think You mentioned that the Wireless infrastructure sequentially was up. I was hoping you could give the sequential direction by the other markets, and I think from
componenttext: Congrats on the strong results. I know in the past, Dave, you gave the year-over-year. I Think You mentioned that the Wireless infrastructure sequentially was up. I was hoping you could give the sequential direction by the other markets, and I think from the math that you gave earlier and for the last year by the end markets, it seems to imply that the combination of your industrial and your come infrastructure, your wireless infrastructure must've been up the better part of 15%, sequentially. So if you could just comment on the directional color by segment and if there was magnitudes or anywhere close? That would be helpful.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I've got -- I can share with you some color sequentially, the automotive market grew sequentially, led by our ADAS and infotainment structure. Industrial, again, was about even and personal electronics was up with the growth in most of the sector
componenttext: Okay. So I've got -- I can share with you some color sequentially, the automotive market grew sequentially, led by our ADAS and infotainment structure. Industrial, again, was about even and personal electronics was up with the growth in most of the sectors that make up that market. Communications equipment was up as we talked about earlier due to Wireless infrastructure and enterprise systems was about even. So as we talked about most of those areas, were stronger than we had expected, but specifically Wireless infrastructure and industrial.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just on the year-over-year growth, I'm not sure Ross on the numbers you were citing there. But industrial overall, year-over-year was probably about 1%.
componenttext: And just on the year-over-year growth, I'm not sure Ross on the numbers you were citing there. But industrial overall, year-over-year was probably about 1%.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I was talking sequentially.
componenttext: I'm sorry, I was talking sequentially.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Wireless down year-over-year sequentially, industrial was actually down about 1% overall. And then Wireless infrastructure was single-digit, so really not much growth there.
componenttext: Wireless down year-over-year sequentially, industrial was actually down about 1% overall. And then Wireless infrastructure was single-digit, so really not much growth there.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you have a follow-up, Ross?
componenttext: Do you have a follow-up, Ross?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one, one more housekeeping. I know you're not going to give exact guidance on the gross margin, you said earlier. But as far as OpEx directionally in the fourth quarter and first quarter, I know you guys tend to have some year-end phenomenons
componenttext: Just a quick one, one more housekeeping. I know you're not going to give exact guidance on the gross margin, you said earlier. But as far as OpEx directionally in the fourth quarter and first quarter, I know you guys tend to have some year-end phenomenons that impact that. So Kevin, any sort of color on those 2 quarters will be helpful.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ross, it's been pretty normal as you've seen in past quarters, your memory is quite correct on that. 4Q is typically down lower to mid-single digits percentage-wise just because of seasonality of holidays around Thanksgiving and Christmas. And then f
componenttext: Yes, Ross, it's been pretty normal as you've seen in past quarters, your memory is quite correct on that. 4Q is typically down lower to mid-single digits percentage-wise just because of seasonality of holidays around Thanksgiving and Christmas. And then first quarter is typically up in a reverse direction again because of the absence of holidays and also because of the implementation of our annual pay and benefits increases. So I think if you look at the past couple of years, 3Q to 4Q to 1Q, that's probably the best proxy for you to try to model into your spreadsheets right now.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tori Vandenberg with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tori Vandenberg with Stifel.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: Sarah calling in for Tory. A lot of questions have been asked, but going back to the 300 millimeter strategy, can you give us an update on that? Exiting the year, maybe how much of Analog would you expect to be coming out of the fab to support that?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Erik. I'll just say that we'll give an update to that in our February call -- capital management call. I can just say that part of our plan was to qualify our 6 factories, so that qualification is planned to be done before the end of the year and so
componenttext: Hey, Erik. I'll just say that we'll give an update to that in our February call -- capital management call. I can just say that part of our plan was to qualify our 6 factories, so that qualification is planned to be done before the end of the year and so we're close to tracking to that. And we've been releasing products to our fab, the Richardson fab for some time. And so we're going to continue to do that and we still have quite a bit of capacity to be able to grow into. headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: Erik, let me just tell you that are working very hard for a number of years now to grow their revenue. We've talked about their mission over the last couple of years. It's really been cost-containment and growing the revenue and they are achieving very good results on that now. Importantly, very strong contributor to our free cash flow growth and just as our free cash flow at the company level, tends to be weaker in the first of couple of quarters and strong in the second couple of quarter, I don't think it's any different from when we take a look at how some of the business units underneath will follow that metric, being contributing to our free cash flow. We attempt to look at these things over a longer period of time because quarter-to-quarter can be pretty noisy. But I think that team has done a pretty good job at getting those margins up to where we think it's entitlement is that, and they should be performing at that level in the foreseeable future and in the long term is what we expect.

Yes, David, we put in place that 300-millimeter capacity in the Richardson fab and put together the plans inside of the most 6, the second 300 millimeter factory to be able to support growth. And that's why that's there. But we're really releasing new products into those factories and that's what they're there for and that'll help us maximize free cash flow. 
So okay, well, thank you, David. And thank you all for joining us. I was expecting Marty to actually get in the queue, but he didn't. So a replay of this call is available and you can find it on our new and improved website. Good evening.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Texas Instruments 3Q '15 Earnings Release Conference Call. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Dave Pahl. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and thank you for joining our third quarter '15 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations o
componenttext:
Good afternoon and thank you for joining our third quarter '15 earnings conference call. As usual, Kevin March, TI's Chief Financial Officer, is with me today.
For any of you who missed the release, you can find it and relevant non-GAAP reconciliations on our website at ti.com/ir. This call is being broadcast live over the web and can be accessed through TI's website. A replay will be available through the web. This call will include forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause TI's results to differ materially from management's current expectation. We encourage you to review the notice regarding forward-looking statements contained in the earnings release published today as well as TI's most recent SEC filings for a more complete description.
I'll start with a quick summary. Revenue declined 2% from a year ago. While our overall demand remained weak, most areas were stronger than we had expected, especially wireless infrastructure and industrial. In addition, our demand for automotive continued to be strong. I'll elaborate in a few moments. Even in this environment, each of our core businesses of Analog and Embedded Processing grew year-over-year. Together, they comprised 85% of third quarter revenue and have delivered 9 consecutive quarters of year-over-year growth. Earnings per share were $0.76. 
With that, backdrop, Kevin and I will move on to the details of our performance, which we believe continues to be representative of the ongoing strength of TI's business model. 
In the third quarter, our cash flow from operations was $1.4 billion. We believe that free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term. Free cash flow for the trailing 12-month period was $3.6 billion, up 4% from a year ago. Free cash flow margin was 28% of revenue, up from 27% a year ago and consistent with our targeted range of 20% to 30% of revenue. 
We continue to benefit from our improved product portfolio and the efficiencies of our manufacturing strategy, the latter of which includes our growing 300-millimeter Analog output and the opportunistic purchase of assets ahead of demand. We also believe that free cash flow will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business. For the trailing 12-month period, we returned $4.2 billion of cash to investors through a combination of stock repurchases and dividends. 
Analog revenue, which achieved a record level in the quarter, increased 2% from a year ago. The growth was due to High Volume Analog & Logic. Silicon Valley Analog also grew. Power Management was about even and High Performance Analog declined. Embedded Processing revenue increased by 2% from a year ago due to Microcontrollers and Connectivity. Processors declined. Our investments in Embedded are translating into tangible results as this quarter's revenue is also a record. 
In our Other segment, revenue declined 19% from a year ago, primarily due to custom ASIC products and DLP products. Compared with a year ago, distribution resales increased 6% and inventory decreased by less than 1 week to just below 4 weeks. We believe this inventory level continues to reflect an environment of good product availability due to healthy TI inventories and stable lead times, which together drive high customer service metrics. 
As a reminder, inventory in our distribution channel has decreased over the past few years because of our consignment program. Now I'll move -- I'll provide some insight into this quarter's revenue performance by end market versus a year ago. Automotive remains strong with all sectors growing and 3 of the 5 sectors growing double digits. Industrial revenue was about even with about 1/2 of the 14 sectors growing and about 1/2 declining. 
Personal electronics was up because of demand from 1 customer. Excluding that 1 customer, Personal Electronics was down. Communications equipment was down, driven by Wireless infrastructure, which was down about 30% from a year ago. Although weak, it did grow sequentially. And finally, enterprise systems declined primarily due to DLP projectors. 
We continue to focus on making TI stronger through manufacturing and technology, the breadth of our product portfolio, the reach of our market channels and our diverse and long-lived positions. These 4 attributes taken together are at the core of what puts TI in a unique class of companies, capable of long-term free cash flow growth. 
Kevin will now review profitability, capital management and our outlook.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dave and good afternoon, everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $2.00 billion or 58.2% of revenue. Gross profit declined 2% due to lower revenue. Operating expenses were a total of $750 million, down $45 million from a year ago primarily in SG&
componenttext:
Thanks, Dave and good afternoon, everyone. Gross profit in the quarter was $2.00 billion or 58.2% of revenue. Gross profit declined 2% due to lower revenue. Operating expenses were a total of $750 million, down $45 million from a year ago primarily in SG&A. The decline reflects continued cost management across the company, including the previously announced targeted reductions in Embedded Processing and Japan. Acquisition charges were $83 million, almost all of which were the ongoing amortization of intangibles, which is a noncash expense. 
Operating profit was $1.16 billion or 33.9% of revenue. Operating profit was down 1% from the year ago quarter. Operating margin for Analog was 37.2%. Operating margin for Embedded Processing was 24.0%, 8 percentage points higher versus a year ago as we focused our investments on the best growth opportunities. Net income in the third quarter was $798 million or $0.76 per share. 
Let me now comment on our capital management results, starting with our cash generation. Cash flow from operations was $1.41 billion in the quarter. Inventory days were 111, down 15 days, sequentially. This reduction was the combination of lower factory starts as well as higher-than-expected revenue in the quarter. 
As our business model evolves we continue to evaluate our inventory model. We plan to provide an update on our inventory model to you in our Capital Management call next February. 
Capital expenditures were $139 million in the quarter. As a reminder, in the second quarter, we retired $250 million of debt and issued $500 million of 5-year debt at a coupon rate of 1.75%. In August, we retired an additional $750 million of debt. As a result, we have reduced net debt by $500 million this year, which is consistent with our practice over the past few years. This leaves total debt of $4.125 billion with a weighted average coupon rate of 2.3%. 
On a trailing 12-month basis, cash flow from operations was $4.11 billion, up 8% from the same period a year ago. Trailing 12-month capital expenditures were $512 million or 4% of revenue. As a reminder, our long-term expectation is for capital expenditures to be about 4% of revenue, which includes the expansion of our 300-millimeter Analog capacity as discussed in our Capital Management call earlier this year. 
Free cash flow for the past 12 months was $3.60 billion or 28% of revenue. Free cash flow was 4% higher than a year ago. As we said, we believe free cash flow growth, especially on a per share basis, is most important to maximizing shareholder value in the long term and will be valued only if it's returned to shareholders or productively invested in the business. 
As we've noted, our intent is to return 100% of our free cash flow plus any proceeds we receive from exercises of equity compensation minus net debt requirement. 
In September, we announced a quarterly dividend increase of $0.04, a 12% increase. This was the 12th consecutive year in which we've increased the dividend to our shareholders. We also announced a $7.5 billion increase to our share buyback authorization. In the third quarter, TI paid $348 million in dividends and repurchased $790 million of our stock for a total return of $1.14 billion. Total cash returned in the past 12 months was $4.23 billion. 
Outstanding share count was reduced by 3.5% over the past 12 months and by 41% since the end of 2004. These returns demonstrate our confidence in TI's business model and our commitment to return excess cash to our shareholders. Fundamental to our commitment to return cash are our cash management and tax practices. We ended the third quarter with $2.74 billion of cash and short-term investments with TI's U.S. entities owning 82% of our cash. Because our cash is largely onshore, it is readily available for a variety of uses, including paying dividends and repurchasing our stock. TI orders in the quarter were $3.44 billion, up 3% from a year ago. 
Turning to our outlook. We expect TI revenue in the range of $3.07 billion to $3.33 billion in the fourth quarter, which includes about a $35 million negative impact from changes in foreign currency exchange rates versus a year ago. We expect fourth quarter earnings per share to be in the range of $0.64 to $0.74. Acquisition charges, which are noncash amortization charges, will remain about even and hold about $80 million to $85 million per quarter until the third quarter of 2019. They will then decline to about $50 million per quarter for 2 additional years. 
Our expectation for our annual effective tax rate in 2015 remains about 30% and this is the tax rate that you should use for the fourth quarter and for the year. In summary we believe our third quarter results demonstrate the strength of TI's business model. With that, let me turn it back to Dave

componenttext: I guess for the first one, I'm a little curious when you said demand was weak but the revenue was strong. And then you mentioned that industrial, I think you said, Dave, was even year-on-year but was stronger than you expected. If you could just give us some more color around the demand environment because you have such wide exposure, what is better or worse versus 3 months ago? And what does it really mean that demand is weak but your revenue is strong?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what we are saying, Vivek, is that if you look, our revenue declined 2% from a year ago. Obviously, we described that as a weak demand. That's actually similar to what we saw last quarter. But in spite of that, certainly it was stronger than what we
componenttext: Well, what we are saying, Vivek, is that if you look, our revenue declined 2% from a year ago. Obviously, we described that as a weak demand. That's actually similar to what we saw last quarter. But in spite of that, certainly it was stronger than what we had expected. There were a couple of areas that were stronger than we had expected. Wireless infrastructure and industrial were both stronger than what we had expected. So that's really what we're trying to say. We continue to operate in what we would consider to be just a weaker macroeconomic environment and that's where we came in. Do you have a follow-up?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Dave. On gross margin, I understand that sequentially they were sort of flattish because I assume you took some utilization down. But why are they sort of flat to down versus last year? Because I assumed throughout this period there's been a
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Dave. On gross margin, I understand that sequentially they were sort of flattish because I assume you took some utilization down. But why are they sort of flat to down versus last year? Because I assumed throughout this period there's been a mix shift towards your core Analog and Embedded markets and a mix shift, I guess, towards more 300-millimeter capacity. So why aren't gross margins up versus last year?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Vivek, the short answer is, is that the wafer starts were down in the third quarter versus the last quarter also versus last year. And so the utilization was a little bit higher than it was a year ago.
componenttext: Well, Vivek, the short answer is, is that the wafer starts were down in the third quarter versus the last quarter also versus last year. And so the utilization was a little bit higher than it was a year ago.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: Kevin, just to follow up on that gross margin comment. So utilization went down in the third quarter. I know you're saying you're going to update us on your inventory targets, but I think the one that's outstanding right now is about 105 to 115 and you got there pretty quickly, sequentially. headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: Yes, John, as we look into the fourth quarter, we're expecting our wafer starts will probably be roughly flat to what they were this quarter, so no significant change in starts there. And keep in mind that the wafers that we start in fourth quarter, other than for the first few weeks of the quarter are mostly for what we expect in follow-on quarters. So we built quite a bit forward to our expectation of when that inventory actually gets sold.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Kevin, my follow up, you guys are probably one of the first to start the trend of M&A with the acquisition of National several years back. There's been a lot of speculation in the marketplace about more M&A within the semi space. I know you've t
componenttext: And then, Kevin, my follow up, you guys are probably one of the first to start the trend of M&A with the acquisition of National several years back. There's been a lot of speculation in the marketplace about more M&A within the semi space. I know you've talked about this in the past but I'm kind of curious about kind of getting some updated thoughts from your perspective about the advantage from here, given you're already at the scale of M&A and how you guys are sort of thinking about that.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, so I guess it will take me a second to kind of go through those thoughts there. Of course, we acquired National back into 2011, so we probably got ahead of the game versus where people are at today. But we spent the intervening time period real
componenttext: Yes, John, so I guess it will take me a second to kind of go through those thoughts there. Of course, we acquired National back into 2011, so we probably got ahead of the game versus where people are at today. But we spent the intervening time period really driving hard to accelerate 4 attributes that we think in combination are pretty unique to TI and differentiate us quite a bit from our competitors, which may in fact be impacting some of those thinking about how they approach their markets. And those 4 attributes are our approach to low cost manufacture and advanced technology. The sheer breadth of our overall product portfolio, the reach we have to our customers through our market channels especially with arguably the largest sales force of anybody out there and the diversity and long-lived positions that we enjoy in the markets with the products that we have. If we look at what most companies are doing today from an M&A front, it appears that some of them are maybe changing their focus and some of them are maybe trying to build scale. We already have what we believe is a significant scale advantage and we believe we're focused on the 2 best opportunities that are out there today being Analog and Embedded Processing. So we don't -- those 2 reasons aren't [ph] motivating us to think differently about M&A. When we do think about M&A, our approach is really to focus on the right strategic fit, one that can generate long term returns and excess free cash flows. So we really do focus on the numbers that, that acquisition might lead us to. And by strategic fit, I'm talking really our bias is towards Analog. If we ever look at an acquisition it will probably be a company that's going to be broad and catalog and a diverse customer base and have a large percentage of its revenue coming from industrial and automotive, probably have a very talented R&D team. Those will be the sort of attributes we'd look at from a strategic standpoint. From a return standpoint, we look at several metrics including really making sure that the return on our investment is accretive to our weighted average cost to capital within, say, 4 years or so. And we also want to make sure that whatever we acquire can continue to expand our free cash flow. So with all that said, and we take a look at what's out there, we have been actually buying our favorite semiconductor company. I know you don't like to hear it that way but through our own stock buybacks. Today, by buying back those shares, we're given a 7% free cash flow yield on those acquisitions of those shares and we don't have any integration risk and no banker fees, just a whole lot easier way to run the business and focus on customers.

componenttext: For my first question I'd like to follow up on the industrial market. You said 1/2 of your markets were kind of up year-over-year, 1/2 of them were down. That's pretty similar to the same as last quarter but you do seem to be seeing upside versus expectations. Within industrial, can you give us some idea of which end markets you're actually seeing relative strength versus weakness versus those expectations, and talk a little bit about how your end markets within industrial are concentrated or not?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So great question, Stacy. We've got 14 different sectors that make up our industrial market. And I'll just go through some of those because I think some investors that they focus on industrials, we mean something different than that. So it includes t
componenttext: Yes. So great question, Stacy. We've got 14 different sectors that make up our industrial market. And I'll just go through some of those because I think some investors that they focus on industrials, we mean something different than that. So it includes things like factory automation and control, medical and healthcare, building automation, smart grid and energy test and measurement, motor drives, display, space avionics, appliance, power delivery systems, point-of-sale lighting, industrial transportation and then a bucket of just other really small stuff. So last year as you know, Stacy, Industrial was 31% of our revenues. The largest sector inside of there was 4%. So you can see it gets very, very diverse very quickly. And even inside of each of these sectors, we've got multiple and equipments that make each of those up. So it was very similar to last quarter where we did see about 1/2 of the sectors up and the other sectors down together flat, so there weren't really any really huge movements in either of that we would call out to say that it was unusual. So that's what it looked like. Do you have a follow-on, Stacy?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: So Stacy, on OpEx, if you compare to a year ago quarter that was really -- we just had continued cost management going on across the company and we also had the benefit on the year ago comparison to the actions that we previously announced, Embedded Processing in Japan, and those are now done. So we get that benefit year-over-year as it relates to sequentially even as you say coming in the quarter a little bit better than expected. That's really just cost management continuing. And also in second quarter, there were a few items that didn't recur in second and third quarter, and so that gave us a good benefit in second and third.

componenttext: Okay. So I guess, 2 questions there. I'll take the first one. We've also had some exposure inside of Processors to Automotive. componenttext: On operating margin, Harlan, the short answer is we have announced at the end of 2012, some restructuring actions inside Embedded Processing that would wind up last year and in fact they have, so a lot of that cost is out and so as a result our operating margins are coming through very nicely.
