componenttext: All right. Thank you, yes and the other -- certainly, the other consideration with fourth quarter is what happens to revenue overall. So we'll have less revenue. So that'll impact gross margins.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next question comes from Chris Danely with Citigroup.
componenttext: Next question comes from Chris Danely with Citigroup.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So if we look at just some sort of normal or reasonable projections for Q4, for 2015 your revenue is going to be flat but your gross margins will be up and your OpEx will be down. If we assume that sort of blah environment continues into 2016 and revenue
componenttext: So if we look at just some sort of normal or reasonable projections for Q4, for 2015 your revenue is going to be flat but your gross margins will be up and your OpEx will be down. If we assume that sort of blah environment continues into 2016 and revenue is sort of whatever around the flattish or something like that, is there any way that gross margins could go up and OpEx go down again? Can you just kind of take us through the puts and pulls for next year on those?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll go ahead and take you through on those sort of things, Chris, from a -- first off, I'm hoping that you're wrong in your theory about revenue going to be flat again next year. But under that scenario, I think we would -- I doubt that we'd see a w
componenttext: Yes, I'll go ahead and take you through on those sort of things, Chris, from a -- first off, I'm hoping that you're wrong in your theory about revenue going to be flat again next year. But under that scenario, I think we would -- I doubt that we'd see a whole lot of change in operating expenditures other than just normal annual pay and benefit increases. But on the margin side, on the gross margin side, we'll probably continue to see benefit as we see more and more of our production moving to 300-millimeter, which as you recall gives us about a 40% chip cost reduction, an overall cost of goods standpoint. So that will certainly benefit our gross margin line. In addition to that, we continue to see an expansion of revenue that's coming out of the industrial and automotive space as a percent of total, and those tend to come through at higher gross margins as well as just overall catalog products versus custom products inside our mix. And then the last item is that as we talked about for a couple of years now, our CapEx has been running under our depreciation by a couple of points, and that is slowly beginning to close. In fact, you can even see that gap close in just in this past 12-month comparison period. So as we look out into 2016, you'll see that gap close a bit more. So those in combination will give us continued tailwind on the gross margin line, it should follow all the way through to the operating margin.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll just add, too, that even with this year, if the revenue projections come in as you said, Chris, that our free cash flow margin continue to expand, so, and that's really what we're focused on. Do you have a follow-up, Chris?
componenttext: Yes. And I'll just add, too, that even with this year, if the revenue projections come in as you said, Chris, that our free cash flow margin continue to expand, so, and that's really what we're focused on. Do you have a follow-up, Chris?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so if we look at what revenue did sequentially in Q3 and what you're projecting for in Q4, it's pretty even with last year or so and it sounds like even though business is still kind of blah, it's getting a little bit better, would you characterize t
componenttext: Yes, so if we look at what revenue did sequentially in Q3 and what you're projecting for in Q4, it's pretty even with last year or so and it sounds like even though business is still kind of blah, it's getting a little bit better, would you characterize the environmental overall as kind of normal? And if it's not normal then where would be your biggest area of concern or weakness?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chris, if you look at the midpoint of our guidance, it would suggest that our revenues would be down 2% from the year ago. That's similar to the number that we just turned in as well as what we saw in second quarter. So we just described the environment.
componenttext: Chris, if you look at the midpoint of our guidance, it would suggest that our revenues would be down 2% from the year ago. That's similar to the number that we just turned in as well as what we saw in second quarter. So we just described the environment. It really hasn't changed very much. We just believe that we're operating in a weak macroenvironment and we continue to focus on execution. I think the business is showing the results of that focus and the strength of the business model, but in general that's really what we believe that we're operating in.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from William Stein with SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from William Stein with SunTrust.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you had a 10% customer in the quarter or if you had any meaningful change in revenue from a single customer that would have affected the overall trend in the business during the quarter?
componenttext: I wonder if you had a 10% customer in the quarter or if you had any meaningful change in revenue from a single customer that would have affected the overall trend in the business during the quarter?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, when we had -- if we look at last year, we had -- our largest customer was 8% of revenue, and we don't give customer size by quarter. But we expect that, that customer, as they've done well this year, that they could come in around 10% of our r
componenttext: Yes, well, when we had -- if we look at last year, we had -- our largest customer was 8% of revenue, and we don't give customer size by quarter. But we expect that, that customer, as they've done well this year, that they could come in around 10% of our revenue. And I'd say this as we look at that customer, we sell them hundreds of devices across multiple products. And if I contrasted that to the last time that we had a customer that was more than 10%, most of that revenue was concentrated in just a few parts in a single application and even more specifically than that, it was really 1 function that maybe was that different generation. So we really just had 1 function at that customer. So even inside of this customer, we've got quite a bit of diversity. Do you have a follow-on, Will?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's sort of related to this. You -- the company exited the wireless apps processor and baseband business a few years ago. And I suppose the answer is around the concentration at the part number level. But does the -- does what looks like a growing e
componenttext: Yes, it's sort of related to this. You -- the company exited the wireless apps processor and baseband business a few years ago. And I suppose the answer is around the concentration at the part number level. But does the -- does what looks like a growing exposure to the handset market through at least 1 but probably multiple customers, does that concern the company the way that -- in a similar way that caused you to exit some products previously?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, I'd say that when you heard Dave's opening remarks that we saw growth in Personal Electronics and without that 1 customer growing, Personal Electronics would have been down. I think that's also telling us that as handsets overall grow, it will
componenttext: Yes, well, I'd say that when you heard Dave's opening remarks that we saw growth in Personal Electronics and without that 1 customer growing, Personal Electronics would have been down. I think that's also telling us that as handsets overall grow, it will really becoming the larger piece of the personal electronic space. And so what's important is to have a lot of different chips that you're selling into, a lot of different customers you sell into that space and that's exactly what we have. And so from that standpoint, if it we're going to participate in personal electronics, you're going to be participating in handsets and there are a lot of very attractive chip opportunities inside handsets, unlike what we had a number of years ago, as you remembered, with base band and processors where those parts were basically standardized and then commoditized in and your ability to differentiate was diminished. And therefore, your ability to attract profits from selling those parts was diminished. So consequently, I see this as quite a bit different today, given the diversity of products that we're talking about here than the example of when we were baseband processors 5-plus years ago.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'd add to that, if you look across Personal Electronics and you add smartphones and tablets and PCs and TVs, and things like that, you're probably -- if you added all those together, you're probably scaring 2.4 billion, 2.5 billion units and eve
componenttext: Yes. And I'd add to that, if you look across Personal Electronics and you add smartphones and tablets and PCs and TVs, and things like that, you're probably -- if you added all those together, you're probably scaring 2.4 billion, 2.5 billion units and even though that unit pool probably isn't going to grow much there's, as Kevin said, there's opportunities to find products that will live through multiple generations that you can sell to multiple customers and places where we'll continue to try to steer our investments overall. So thank you, Will.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Blayne Curtis with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Blayne Curtis with Barclays.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really 2 related questions, one is a clarification. So the upside in the quarter came from Wireless Infrastructure and Industrial, it seems like HVAL is up a lot, was that part of what you're calling Industrial? And then maybe bigger picture from a geogra
componenttext: Really 2 related questions, one is a clarification. So the upside in the quarter came from Wireless Infrastructure and Industrial, it seems like HVAL is up a lot, was that part of what you're calling Industrial? And then maybe bigger picture from a geographic perspective, there's, obviously, been some negative data point in kind of the U.S. industrial market, just any change over the summer with China, now you're seeing some U.S. issues, just any perspective from a geographic basis.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So let me answer your first question, which, if you look at HVAL, HVAL will have a high exposure to automotive, which will help drive those resident revenues and also have exposure to Personal Electronics as well. It does have some industrial exposu
componenttext: Okay. So let me answer your first question, which, if you look at HVAL, HVAL will have a high exposure to automotive, which will help drive those resident revenues and also have exposure to Personal Electronics as well. It does have some industrial exposure. But I think that those are the areas that will drive that revenue. And you have a follow-up?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The question was just what you're seeing from a geographic perspective, obviously, China is really -- yes.
componenttext: The question was just what you're seeing from a geographic perspective, obviously, China is really -- yes.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So yes, if I just look at our regional results year-over-year, revenue was down in Asia and Europe and in U.S. In Japan, it was up. If you look at the broader China market, it really wasn't down differently than what the broader Asia was, and that wa
componenttext: Yes. So yes, if I just look at our regional results year-over-year, revenue was down in Asia and Europe and in U.S. In Japan, it was up. If you look at the broader China market, it really wasn't down differently than what the broader Asia was, and that was kind of down, consistent with our overall revenue, so really didn't see much different. The second thing I'll add is that a lot of times we're asked by investors what our exposure to China is or to a particular market, and in our 10-K, we give a very precise number of what we shipped into China, being 44%. But we always like to point out that if you're looking for what exposure to a particular market is, I think most investors are asking how much of our products is actually consumed there. And so it's a very different number than 44%, it's much lower than that because, obviously, some of those products that we ship there end up getting shipped into other regions. I'll also point out that we may ship product into a Tier 2 OEM that gets put into a European automobile in Europe and then shipped into China, so you can't really look at any of our regional results and understand that. So but overall, probably a good proxy to begin to start an analysis would be to look at what China is as a percentage of GDP and any kind of -- start an analysis from there.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joe Moore with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about your customer inventories. You gave us very helpful just the resale and inventory numbers, but just in general, you had a pretty good year in 2014, a weaker year this year, but my perception is that the custom
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk a little bit about your customer inventories. You gave us very helpful just the resale and inventory numbers, but just in general, you had a pretty good year in 2014, a weaker year this year, but my perception is that the customer inventory management lead time, days held, hasn't really changed. Can you just talk about whether you're seeing any inflection there in the last few quarters?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Joe. I'd say that of course, the distribution inventory is as you said, we can see very well. We've got 55% of our revenues that are on consignment. So for those portions, which will include 60% of our distributor revenue. But we know for that porti
componenttext: Sure, Joe. I'd say that of course, the distribution inventory is as you said, we can see very well. We've got 55% of our revenues that are on consignment. So for those portions, which will include 60% of our distributor revenue. But we know for that portion of our revenue, there is no inventories, it's exactly 0. So obviously, that's in really good shape. And if you look overall, the classic kind of book shift [ph] tiering inventory-type portion of our revenue is really about 20% of our revenue and that's where we'll carry backlog. Customers will have inventory. So we really don't see any signs that customer inventories are significantly out of whack, I'm sure you can always find pockets here and there. But we believe that they're fairly lean with very few exceptions, such as the Wireless infrastructure.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you have any follow-on, Joe?
componenttext: So you have any follow-on, Joe?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I do want to follow up on Wireless infrastructure. You said it was up sequentially recovering from a lower level. Do you have visibility into whether that's sort of China deployments or Western deployments and what do you see as the trajectory fo
componenttext: Yes, and I do want to follow up on Wireless infrastructure. You said it was up sequentially recovering from a lower level. Do you have visibility into whether that's sort of China deployments or Western deployments and what do you see as the trajectory for that business going forward?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Joe, we have -- I'd say that our exposure in Wireless Infrastructure, if you look at the major OEMs that make up the majority of that market, we'll have a different product exposure, but a fairly consistent exposure across them. So if there's dema
componenttext: Yes, so Joe, we have -- I'd say that our exposure in Wireless Infrastructure, if you look at the major OEMs that make up the majority of that market, we'll have a different product exposure, but a fairly consistent exposure across them. So if there's demand in any of the regions, we'll typically participate in that. If you look at by technology, that's often time another cut that people will look at. We've got a strong position in 3G, slightly stronger position in 4G and even in newer areas that we expect growth in the future that we've been investing in, as an example like small cells we've been investing, I believe, we'll have a very strong position there as well. So our numbers aren't so much impacted by a specific region. Of course, we won't escape it either if there's weakness in any particular region.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Seymore with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congrats on the strong results. I know in the past, Dave, you gave the year-over-year. I think you mentioned that the Wireless infrastructure sequentially was up. I was hoping you could give the sequential direction by the other markets, and I think from
componenttext: Congrats on the strong results. I know in the past, Dave, you gave the year-over-year. I think you mentioned that the Wireless infrastructure sequentially was up. I was hoping you could give the sequential direction by the other markets, and I think from the math you gave earlier for last year by the end markets, it seem to imply that the combination of Industrial and your comm infrastructure, your Wireless Infrastructure must've been up the better part of 15%, sequentially. So if you could just comment on the directional color by segment and if those magnitudes are anywhere close, that would be helpful.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. So I've got -- I can share with you some color sequentially, the automotive market grew sequentially, led by our ADAS and infotainment sectors. Industrial, again, was about even and Personal Electronics was up with growth in most of the sectors
componenttext: Okay, yes. So I've got -- I can share with you some color sequentially, the automotive market grew sequentially, led by our ADAS and infotainment sectors. Industrial, again, was about even and Personal Electronics was up with growth in most of the sectors that make up that market. Communications Equipment was up, as we talked about earlier, due to Wireless Infrastructure and Enterprise Systems was about even. As we talked about most of those areas, were stronger than we had expected but specifically Wireless Infrastructure and Industrial.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just on the year-over-year growth, I'm not sure Ross, on the numbers you were citing there, but Industrial overall, year-over-year, was probably down about 1%.  And...
componenttext: Just on the year-over-year growth, I'm not sure Ross, on the numbers you were citing there, but Industrial overall, year-over-year, was probably down about 1%.  And...

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I was talking sequentially.
componenttext: I'm sorry, I was talking sequentially.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, Wireless Infrastructure is still down year-over-year. Sequential, Industrial was actually down about 1% overall. And then Wireless Infrastructure was up in single digit, so really not much growth there.
componenttext: Okay. Yes, Wireless Infrastructure is still down year-over-year. Sequential, Industrial was actually down about 1% overall. And then Wireless Infrastructure was up in single digit, so really not much growth there.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Do you have a follow-up, Ross?
componenttext: Okay. Do you have a follow-up, Ross?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a quick one, more housekeeping. I know you're not going to give exact guidance on the gross margin you said earlier. But as far as OpEx directionally in the fourth quarter and first quarter, I know you guys tend to have some year-end phenomenon
componenttext: Yes, just a quick one, more housekeeping. I know you're not going to give exact guidance on the gross margin you said earlier. But as far as OpEx directionally in the fourth quarter and first quarter, I know you guys tend to have some year-end phenomenon that impact that. So Kevin, any sort of color on those 2 quarters will be helpful.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ross, it's going to be pretty normal to what you've seen in past quarters, your memory is quite correct on that. 4Q is typically down low to mid-single digits percentage-wise just because of seasonality of holidays around Thanksgiving and Christmas.
componenttext: Yes, Ross, it's going to be pretty normal to what you've seen in past quarters, your memory is quite correct on that. 4Q is typically down low to mid-single digits percentage-wise just because of seasonality of holidays around Thanksgiving and Christmas. And then first quarter is typically up in a reverse direction again because of the absence of holidays and also because of the implementation of our annual pay and benefits increases. So I think that if you look at the past couple of years, 3Q to 4Q to 1Q, that's probably the best proxy for you to try to model into your spreadsheets for now.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Tore Svanberg with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Tore Svanberg with Stifel.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Erik calling in for Tore. A lot of questions have been asked, but going back to the 300 millimeter strategy, can you give us an update on that? Exiting the year, maybe how much of Analog would you expect to be coming out of the fab to support that
componenttext: This is Erik calling in for Tore. A lot of questions have been asked, but going back to the 300 millimeter strategy, can you give us an update on that? Exiting the year, maybe how much of Analog would you expect to be coming out of the fab to support that?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Hey, Erik. I'll just say that we'll give an update to that in our February call, Capital Management call. I can just say that part of our plan was to qualify our DMOS6 factories, so that qualification is planned to be done before the end of the year and s
componenttext: Hey, Erik. I'll just say that we'll give an update to that in our February call, Capital Management call. I can just say that part of our plan was to qualify our DMOS6 factories, so that qualification is planned to be done before the end of the year and so we're still tracking to that. And we've been releasing products to our fab, or the Richardson fab for some time, so we're going to continue to do that and we still have quite a bit of capacity to be able to grow into. So do you have a follow-on?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The Embedded Processing. obviously, the operating margins looked very good this quarter. Going forward, and I know you probably don't want to give too much guidance on this, but what are the expectations for this business? Will it be lumpy in terms of the
componenttext: The Embedded Processing. obviously, the operating margins looked very good this quarter. Going forward, and I know you probably don't want to give too much guidance on this, but what are the expectations for this business? Will it be lumpy in terms of the improvements? Was this a little bit more of an outsized quarter in terms of the improvement? Or should we see -- what are some of the expectations for that group?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Erik, let me just tell you that our teams are working pretty hard for a number of years now to grow the revenue. We've talked about their mission over the last couple of years has really been cost containment and growing the revenue and they are achi
componenttext: Yes, Erik, let me just tell you that our teams are working pretty hard for a number of years now to grow the revenue. We've talked about their mission over the last couple of years has really been cost containment and growing the revenue and they are achieving very good results on that now. Importantly, they're strong contributor to our free cash flow growth and just as our free cash flow at the company level tends to be weaker in the first of couple of quarters and stronger in the second couple of quarters, I don't think it's any different from when we take a look at how some of the business units underneath will be performing that metric, being as though they're the ones contributing to that free cash flow. We tend to look at these things over a longer period of time because quarter-to-quarter can be pretty noisy. But I think that team has done a very good job of getting those margins up to where we think its entitlement is at, and they should be performing at that level in the foreseeable future, in fact in the long term, is what we would expect on them.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I'll just add that as Kevin mentioned, the growth has been coming through from the investments that we've made. We've highlighted that they, as well as Analog, had achieved record levels of revenue as a result of those investments. Together, Anal
componenttext: Yes. And I'll just add that as Kevin mentioned, the growth has been coming through from the investments that we've made. We've highlighted that they, as well as Analog, had achieved record levels of revenue as a result of those investments. Together, Analog and Embedded have grown for 9 quarters in a row year-over-year. And I think there was 1 quarter where Embedded actually did well, but didn't grow year-over-year and that was last quarter that it had the big headwind from Wireless Infrastructure. But other parts of that business, obviously, did very well. Okay, I think we have time for one last caller, operator.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our last question from David Wong with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And we'll take our last question from David Wong with Wells Fargo.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just the detail of your earlier answer, so you noted Personal Electronics was up because of demand from 1 customer. What about your broader segments, would you still have seen year-over-year growth in both Analog and Embedded if it hadn't been for that sa
componenttext: Just the detail of your earlier answer, so you noted Personal Electronics was up because of demand from 1 customer. What about your broader segments, would you still have seen year-over-year growth in both Analog and Embedded if it hadn't been for that same 1 customer?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I actually don't have that data broken out between the 2 segments. But I think that Personal Electronics is mostly inside of Analog. And so our Personal Electronics business, without that customer obviously, wasn't up. So that would've impacted Analo
componenttext: Yes, I actually don't have that data broken out between the 2 segments. But I think that Personal Electronics is mostly inside of Analog. And so our Personal Electronics business, without that customer obviously, wasn't up. So that would've impacted Analog.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to remind you the other side of that, too, we had a significant change in foreign exchange rates at the end of the year. So actually in the third quarter and again in the fourth quarter, we saw and expect about a $35 million negative top line impac
componenttext: I want to remind you the other side of that, too, we had a significant change in foreign exchange rates at the end of the year. So actually in the third quarter and again in the fourth quarter, we saw and expect about a $35 million negative top line impact due to foreign exchange rates. So we can always pick out individual pieces, the beauty of the TI model is that we have tens of thousands of customers, buying tens of thousands of parts into almost every electrical and electronic market that's out there and the diversity is what is really paying out for our shareholders and in free cash flow generation.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess, you don't have a follow-up, David?
componenttext: And I guess, you don't have a follow-up, David?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, actually one quick one . As you move more to 300 millimeters, are you vacating any specific 200-millimeter facilities you might be able to close down or sell eventually?
componenttext: Well, actually one quick one . As you move more to 300 millimeters, are you vacating any specific 200-millimeter facilities you might be able to close down or sell eventually?

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, we put in place that 300-millimeter capacity in the Richardson fab and put together the plants inside of DMOS6, the second 300 millimeter factory to be able to support growth. And that's why that's there. We're really releasing new products in
componenttext:
Yes, David, we put in place that 300-millimeter capacity in the Richardson fab and put together the plants inside of DMOS6, the second 300 millimeter factory to be able to support growth. And that's why that's there. We're really releasing new products into those factories and that's what they're there for and that'll help us maximize free cash flow. 
So okay, well, thank you, David. And thank you all for joining us. I was expecting Marty McFly to actually get in the queue, but he didn't. So a replay of this call is available and you can find it on our new and improved website. Good evening.

headline: Texas Instruments Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
